instruction: Explain: Google Play Removes 21 More Apps From Play
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Google Play Removes 21 More Apps From Play:

Malicious apps continue to make their way into the Google Play store. Twenty-one games have been found to have malicious ad-related software within them. The apps in question are games that present themselves as fun or useful. According to the report, the games have been downloaded more that 8 million times. It was discovered the apps contained adware from HiddenAds. The apps hide their icons upon installation so they are not easily removed and these apps also present relevant advertisements making them more difficult to identify. This discovery comes on the heels of September's discovery of stalkerware apps in the Android marketplace. The continued onslaught of malicious apps within these mobile app stores makes stopping these types of efforts much more difficult.

instruction: What is Telerik UI Exploitation Leads to Crypto-miner, Cobalt Strike Infections
output: Here is an overview on Telerik UI Exploitation Leads to Crypto-miner, Cobalt Strike Infections: Sophos researchers have observed an unknown threat actor that is targeting a three-year-old vulnerability (CVE-2019-18935) in the Telerik UI web application framework to deploy Cobalt Strike beacons and cryptominers. Once deployed and communicating with its C&C server, Cobalt Strike is used to execute encoded PowerShell commands that achieve persistence via Active Directory GPOs and scheduled tasks, download the cryptominer, and potentially download further malware. The attacker also attempted to move laterally. Sophos also reports that the attack has similarities to prior attacks attributed to a threat actor known as Bule Mockingbird.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Adobe Security Bulletins - November 10?
output:
Adobe has released two Security Bulletins that provide updates for Adobe Connect and Adobe Reader Mobile.

APSB20-69: This bulletin addresses reflected cross-site scripting vulnerabilities in Adobe Connect. A remote attacker may be able to exploit the vulnerabilities to execute arbitrary JavaScript within the context of the victim's browser.

ASPB20-71: This bulletin addresses a single vulnerability in Adobe Reader Mobile for Android. Successfully exploited, the vulnerability could allow an attacker to obtain sensitive information.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Lyceum APT Group Deploying Backdoor That Uses DNS for Command and Control
output: Sure. Here is a description for Lyceum APT Group Deploying Backdoor That Uses DNS for Command and Control: Lyceum is reported by Zscaler ThreatLabz as being an Iranian-sponsored APT group that has been operating since sometime in 2017. This threat group is known to target organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East. The group has been using a .NET-based backdoor which is a modified version of the open-source tool, DIG.net. The modifications allow the backdoor to use DNS Hijacking to provide the backdoor's C&C communications. The backdoor uses DNS queries to a DNS server under the control of the attackers and the server's responses provide commands for the backdoor to carry out. In the campaign observed by Zscaler, the backdoor is delivered via a malicious Word document that uses the AutoOpen() and AutoClose() functions to drop the embedded backdoor onto the system. The backdoor, named "DnsSystem" is also copied to the system's startup folder to achieve persistence.

instruction: What is Android Malware PhoneSpy Targeting South Korea
output: Here is an overview on Android Malware PhoneSpy Targeting South Korea: A campaign targeting residents of South Korea who use Android devices delivers an Android RAT named PhoneSpy. According to Zimperium zLabs, PhoneSpy is disguised as various Korean language apps, some 23 of the fake apps have been observed by zLabs. Only a few of the simpler apps actually provided any of the apps advertised functionality with most simply being a facade. Unusually, the Trojanized apps have not been observed in the Play store, or in third-party app stores. This suggests the actors behind the campaign rely on techniques such as social engineering or web traffic redirection to infect their victims. Once one of the malicious apps has been installed it will request significant permissions and then open a fake login page for a well-known South Korean messaging app named Kakao Talk. Through single sign-on, Kakao credentials can be used to log into other South Korean services. The app can also deliver fake login pages for Facebook, Google, and Instagram. Aside from the aforementioned phishing, PhoneSpy can also list the apps installed on the device, steal documents, images, contacts, call logs, and SMS messages. It can also take photos and record real-time video and audio using the device's camera, and provide the PhoneSpy operators with the device's GPS location, and remote control of the device.

instruction: Describe the following: Fake Adobe Flash Updater via Google Alerts
output: Threat actors are using Google Alerts to trick victims into clicking on fake stories in an effort to redirect them to downloading a fake Adobe Flash updater. The fake stories use popular keywords in their titles which Google will index and then alert users who follow the keywords. With Flash being end of life, the ruse relies on unwitting victims to install the update. The updater install a program called 'One Updater'. One Updater will, periodically, install unwanted programs. While no malicious payloads have been observed, there exists the potential for future malicious infections.

instruction: Tell me about Solarmarker Malware Updates
output:
Certainly.
Solarmarker Malware Updates

The Solarmarker malware is known by multiple names including JupyterInfostealer, Polazert, and YellowCockatoo. A report from Binary Defense notes changes to Solarmarker that have been made by its developers over the last few months. Solarmarker previously used the Unique ID (UID) "Solarmarker" but this has now changed to a UID that is generated for the infected host. The backdoor module that was named Mars.Deimos is now named using random strings. The infostealer module, previously named Jupyter.Jupyter, is now named Module.Main. PowerShell code, used in the registry has also changed from previous versions. The payload that was previously delivered as a .exe file is now a .msi file which has been observed using various .msi package builders. Binary Defense notes that despite the changes, a Yara rule (included below) by Luke Acha still detects Solarmarker's backdoor.

instruction: What is Confluence Vulnerability Being Exploited In-The-Wild
output: Here is an overview on Confluence Vulnerability Being Exploited In-The-Wild: Researchers at Fortinet have been tracking a new vulnerability affecting confluence instances. The vulnerability is being tracked as CVE-2021-26084 and enables threat actors to run arbitrary code on unpatched confluence servers and Data Center instances. Since the disclosure of this vulnerability, Fortinet has seen massive scanning across the internet, as well as POC, exploit code. Fortinet has observed several attack attempts using this vulnerability, including cryptojacking attacks, backdoor downloads, and fileless attacks leveraging PowerShell. It has also been seen in attacks spreading the Mushtik botnet. The exploit is used to download malware onto the hosts, and in one case, further reconnaissance tools are downloaded. In another attack, a PowerShell command was used to set up a reverse shell, allowing the attacked access to the machine. The patch has already been released, but public attacks are ongoing.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Mirai Variant Exploiting Realtek SDK Vulnerability
output: Sure. Here is a description for Mirai Variant Exploiting Realtek SDK Vulnerability: According to SAM, within two days of vulnerabilities in a Realtek SDK being disclosed, an attacker had created a Mirai variant that exploited one of the vulnerabilities. The vulnerability (CVE-2021-35395) can be exploited, without authentication, through the web interface of an affected device. Successfully exploited, an attacker can execute arbitrary code with the highest level of privilege. The SAM report notes that two weeks prior, the same attacker weaponised another vulnerability (CVE-2021-20090) within two days of disclosure.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Credphish Links Stuffed in Benign Attachments Are on the Rise?
output: Cofense has published a report regarding phishing campaigns using links within benign attachments. This technique is used to bypass security email gateways that scan URLs in the body of the email but not network indicators contained within files. The example covered in the blog post specifically uses an XLSX attachment. The majority of the content in the file is benign, with no malicious macros present to detect. It contains OneDrive-themed content and requests the user click on a button to view the full file. Clicking the link leads to a phishing site requesting Microsoft login credentials. If a user enters their credentials, they are exfiltrated via a POST request to a different server. Victims are then redirected to the legitimate Office webpage. This is just one example of similar campaigns using links in benign attachments to hide their activities. Other file types observed in such campaigns include DOC, HTML, HTM, and PDF.

instruction:
Given the description:
Minerva labs has published a report on a new malicious installer that drops the Purple Fox Rootkit. In this example, the installer was pretending to be for Telegram. Upon execution, the installer creates a new folder and drops both the legitimate Telegram installer and a malicious downloader named 'TextInputh.exe'. The malicious downloader drops more small malicious files and executes them to continue the attack. The use of lots of small files means that this attack is fairly stealthy, as researchers found that these files had a very low detection rate. If the malware detects antivirus, it drops five more files which work together to shut down and block the antivirus processes, allowing the attack to continue without detection. Once the files have been dropped and executed, the malware sends all the host information including what security software is running to the C2 server. The researchers analyzed the C2 IP in the sample they were investigating and found that the last stage of the attack was the download and execution of the Purple Fox rootkit. The researchers speculate that the installer was likely being spread through both phishing emails and phishing websites.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: Provide an overview for: New APT Targeting MENA
output: Sure. Here is a description for New APT Targeting MENA: A new, possibly Iranian, APT named FIREPLACE has been seen targeting MENA using mostly off-the-shelf software and backdoors. Researchers observed the attackers using a modified, publicly available web shell called AspxSpy2014Final.aspx. This web shell is used after exploiting a web vulnerability within the web application. From there, attackers used tools such as Plink, Winrar, PsExec, and procdump for lateral movement. Persistence is gained through a VBS, Powershell, and C# developed back doors. This step is used to contact the C2 node. If the victim server is unable to contact the Internet, the attackers employ a new backdoor implanted in the OWA (Exchange web server) to hide. Typically, endpoint security does not monitor OWA directories. This provides attackers with a cover against detection. Backdoors, C2, data exfiltration, and SOCKS proxy use different servers. The attackers do not attempt to hide their tracks nor remove the tools used in the attack. Additionally, backdoors are not obfuscated. Despite this, attackers were able to remain in the target environment for an extended period of time. Because of similar tactics to APT34, there is speculation this group may be tied to Iran. For more information, see the Shells.

instruction: Describe the following: How Chinese Threat Actors Utilize BPFDoor
output: The report identifies the Chinese threat actor that is connected to BPFDoor as Red Manchin. This Chinese threat actor has been targeting sectors in the Middle East and Asia. Although primarily focusing on compromising telecommunication companies, they have also been targeting government and education. The threat actor is utilizing BPFDoor to target Linux for remote code execution. This is accomplished without utilizing network ports or alerting any firewall rules. BDFDoor utilizes web apps that are already running on ports. BDFDoor also obfuscates its activities by renaming its designed process on Linux and therefore does not utilize inbound ports or outbound command and control infrastructure.

The threat actor is utilizing BPFDoor to target Linux for remote code execution. This is accomplished without utilizing network ports or alerting any firewall rules. BDFDoor utilizes web apps that are already running on ports. BDFDoor also obfuscates its activities by renaming its designed process on Linux and therefore does not utilize inbound ports or outbound command and control infrastructure.

instruction: Explain: Vandal Community Hacking and Website Defacement
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Vandal Community Hacking and Website Defacement:

A group of hackers have taken to brazenly defacing websites worldwide. An uptick in recent defacement activity has caught the eye of Comparitech researchers. It is hypothesized that hackers have more time to accomplish these sorts of hacks due to the COVID-19 pandemic to keep boredom at bay. Whether for sport or profit (often through ransomware), these hackers boast of the exploits across social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, and ICQ profiles. The defaced websites are often mirrored as proof of the act and shared across underground forums and on public servers. These servers are crawled with aggregators such as Zone-H. While reverting to an earlier version of a website can get the victim back online, these mirrors are used to boast the reputation of the hacker(s) in question. As of the date of the article, Zone-H had more than 14 million defacement attacks logged. Within the Zone-H catalog, high profile attacks are denoted by a star which boosts the reputation of the hacker responsible. There is another way to boost reputation: through re-defacement of an already defaced website. During the research into these defacements, 89 zero-day vulnerabilities were discovered in content management systems (CMS) and plugins. More than 100,000 sites were identified with vulnerable plugins. WordPress has 78,430 sites, Joomla has 16,360, Drupal has 300, and Opencart about 6,240 websites, all of which contain these vulnerable plugins. Most of the mass hacking bots take advantage of between 40-80 of these exploits based on the the five bots analyzed. A total of 154 exploits had no associated CVE. Hackers use target searches through specially crafted search engine terms in an effort to locate vulnerable targets. Additionally, IP scanning bots or IoT search engines can be employed to identify potential targets. In most of these defacements, hackers use bots and scripts created to take advantage of specific vulnerabilities. Commonly, these bots exploit the ability to upload arbitrary files. These files are often shell scripts used to carry out the act of remote code execution on the server. Wiping out websites, replacing content with adult-themed material, database theft, and other actions are usually at the hacker's disposal. Although open source and free bots and shell scripts are available, there are paid scripts as well. These paid scripts are available for about $2-$4. The origins of these hackers and their tools cannot be pinpointed; however, significant numbers of these tools have documentation in Arabic. While there are tools on the market for scanning your website for vulnerabilities, these tools can be extremely inaccurate. In fact, two of the more popular tools were employed against a website with known vulnerabilities and neither identified the vulnerabilities in place.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Buer Loader Distributed in COVID-19 Themed Malspam?
output: According to the Cofense Phishing Defense Center, a variant of the malware-as-a-service Buer Loader is being distributed via COVID-19 themed malspam that has a password-protected Excel file attached. The password for the file is included in the email. If the file is opened, and macros enabled, a loader will be dropped onto the system. In turn, the loader downloads a file with an .xls extension but which is actually an executable file. This Buer variant is written in the Rust programming language and utilizes a number of anti-analysis functions but the C&C communication structure is the same as prior versions. Once installed the Buer Loader provides its operators with backdoor access to the infected system and can be used to download further payloads, including ransomware.

instruction:
Given the description:
ESET researchers have discovered a new version of the ArguePatch loader. This has been used by the threat group 'Sandworm' in multiple attacks in Ukraine. ArguePatch has been seen in an Industroyer attack against a Ukrainian energy provider, as well as in multiple CaddyWiper attacks. The new variant contains a feature allowing it to execute the next stage of an attack at a specific time. This means it does not set up a scheduled task, allowing it to be more stealthy and evade detection. The researchers also noted that the new variant uses an official ESET executable to hide ArguePatch and further evade detection.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: Describe the following: Phishing Campaign Threatens Job Security, Drops Bazar and Buer Malware
output: Area 1 Security published their analysis of a phishing email using a job security lure to ultimately deliver the Bazar and Beur malware. The email claims to come from an HR professional at the recipient's company and notifies them that due to economic impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic, they are being let go. A link to a PDF supposedly containing the details of the termination is provided. Visiting the link leads to a document hosted on Google Docs or Constant Contact providing a secondary link. The secondary link, in turn, delivers a PE binary to the victim system. Contained in the PE is an encrypted Trickbot payload that is run in order to install the BazarLoader or Buer loader. These loaders download the final backdoor using blockchain DNS lookup tables hosted on the EmerDNS .bazar TLD. With backdoor access, the attackers can carry out post-compromise actions, such as remote code execution, data exfiltration, or deploying additional payloads.

instruction: Tell me about Latest RATs Targeting macOS
output:
Certainly.
Latest RATs Targeting macOS

Mac users are no longer considered safe from malware just by simply practicing "safe behavior". SentinelOne has recognized the trends they pointed out in 2021 continuing into 2022 in regards to the malware targeting macOS. In a recent blog, they provide a brief overview of two new malware families, referred to as SysJoker and DazzleSpy. MacOS is included in targeting by malware that crosses multiple platforms such as SysJoker which has Windows, Linux, and macOS variants and DazzleSpy is exploiting vulnerabilities within macOS. The primary purpose of SysJoker is to await commands from a C2. Capabilities of DazzleSpy are designed for espionage and include dumping the keychain, running a remote desktop, and running shell commands.

instruction: Tell me about Purple Fox EK Abuses Cloudflare and Exploits CVE-2019-1367
output:
Certainly.
Purple Fox EK Abuses Cloudflare and Exploits CVE-2019-1367

Trend Micro has published a report analyzing recent Purple Fox EK activity. Although originally delivered by the Rig exploit kit, the Purple Fox malware has since moved to leveraging its own exploit kit, which has been growing in its sophistication. The landing page was hosted on Cloudflare in order to hide behind a legitimate cloud service's infrastructure. The content of the landing page was encrypted and obfuscated. Several JavaScript libraries are referenced to perform the decryption and decoding. The encrypted code is responsible for exploiting CVE-2019-1367, an Internet Explorer vulnerability, in order to deliver and execute the Purple Fox malware to a victim host. After successful exploitation, users are redirected to the Google search engine, likely to avoid raising the victim's suspicions. Trend Micro notes they reported their discovery to Cloudflare who have since blocked communication with the discovered exploit pages.

instruction: Describe the following: Cracked Software Leads to CoinMiner Malware
output: The "Crackonosh" malware is distributed along with cracked, illegal, copies of popular software. It disables Windows Defender and Windows Update and also removes antivirus software from a variety of vendors. Part of the install involves adding XMRig coinmining software in order to mine Monero cryptocurrency. The malware modifies the system registry in order to maintain persistence by initiating a connection into the mining pool after every system startup. There is a P2P network of infected machines which it uses to exchange version information and update itself, if needed.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Russian GRU Conducting Global Brute Force Campaign?
output: Beginning in mid-2019 and probably ongoing, the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) has been conducting a brute force campaign. The private sector has typically attributed the GRU activity to the well-known names APT28 or Fancy Bear, though a number of other names including Group 74, Iron Twilight, Pawn Storm, Sednit, Snakemackerel, Sofacy, Strontium, Swallowtail, Tg-4127, Threat Group-4127, Tsar Team, are also associated. IBM X-Force tracks the activity under ITG05. While the campaign has principally targeted Europe and the U.S., it is global in nature. The targeted entities include defense contractors, energy companies, government and military organizations, higher education institutions, law firms, logistics companies, media companies, political consultants and party organizations, and think tanks. The attacks are carried out using a Kubernetes cluster. The primary service targeted in the attacks has been Microsoft Office 365 cloud services, though other service providers and on-premise email servers are also targeted. If credentials are obtained they are typically used to gain an initial foothold before attempts are made to escalate privileges and move laterally. The attackers are also known to exploit vulnerabilities such as CVE-2020-0688 and CVE-2020-17144 for remote code execution or to further lateral movement within an environment. To anonymize the attacks, they are usually routed through Tor or VPN services, including those provided by CactusVPN, IPVanish, NordVPN, ProtonVPN, Surfshark, and WorldVPN. In some cases, the attacks have come directly from the Kubernetes cluster. Once an organization has been compromised, the attackers will attempt to gain a persistent foothold and exfiltrate data.

instruction: Describe the following: Lazarus Using BMP Files With Malicious HTA Objects
output: The first stage of an attack, attributed to the Lazarus APT group by Malwarebytes Labs, probably began with phishing emails. Lazarus is known by many names including Guardians of Peace, Hidden Cobra, Nickel Academy, and Zinc. A malicious document attached to the emails contained macros that would kick off the infection process by dropping a loader. The loader was contained in a PNG file present in the document, which was then converted to a BMP file. During the conversion from PNG into the uncompressed BMP format, the malicious HTA objects are also decompressed. The HTA objects provide a JavaScript file that creates an executable file, in this case, "AppStore.exe". In turn, AppStore.exe loads a base64-encrypted payload into memory. The second stage payload initiates communication with the C&C servers.

instruction: Describe the following: Indian Vaccine Makers Targeted by Chinese Hackers
output: Indian vaccine makers SII and Bharat Biotech have recently come under attack from Chinese hackers. The Chinese state-sponsored group APT 10, or Stone Panda, are suspected of the attacks on the biochemical companies. The group was able to identify vulnerabilities in the IT infrastructure and supply chain software. The goal of the attacks is to exfiltrate intellectual property in an effort to gain an edge in vaccine development. In the case of SII, public servers running vulnerable web servers are to blame for the attacks. It is not known how the attackers gained access to the Bharat company's infrastructure. This targeting is another in the long line of hacks to biotech companies, particularly those associated with the creation, distribution, and marketing of COVID-19 vaccines.

instruction: What is IronNetInjector
output: Here is an overview on IronNetInjector: Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing IronNetInjector, a new malware loading tool attributed to Turla. IronNetInjector is composed of IronPython scripts and an injector used to load a final payload. IronPython is an open-source project that allows Python code to use .NET framework APIs without compiling a .NET assembly. The IronPython script in this case executes the .NET injector. The injector and the malicious payloads are both Base64-encoded and Rijndael-encrypted. The injector is able to load either PE files or .NET assemblies into either its own process or a remote process. The main malware family being loaded by IronNetInjector samples identified by Palo Alto was ComRAT, however an RPC backdoor and unknown malware were also identified. The researchers were unable to determine the initial infection vector used to deliver this tool.

instruction: What is Another Molerats Campaign Targeting the Middle East
output: Here is an overview on Another Molerats Campaign Targeting the Middle East: The threat group named Molerats is also identified by a number of other names including Aluminum Saratoga, Extreme Jackal, Gaza Cybergang, Gaza Hackers Team, Moonlight, and Operation Molerats. The group has been active since 2012 and has been described as politically motivated. Molerats primarily target the Middle East though attacks against the U.S. and U.K. governments have been attributed to the group. The campaign, reported on by Cybereason's Nocturnus Team, has primarily targeted Arab speakers in Egypt, the Palestinian Territories, and the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Non-Arabic speakers in Turkey were also targeted. The emails used in the campaign are politically-themed with a focus on relationships between Israel and Arab countries. Three new malwares were discovered while investigating the campaign, two backdoors named SharpStage and DropBook, and a dropper named MoleNet. A notable feature of SharpStage is that it uses DropBox as an exfiltratration destination. DropBook is interesting as Facebook accounts are used to provide its command and control instructions. Other malware involved in the attacks includes a new variant of the Pierogi backdoor, the Spark backdoor, and the Quasar RAT.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Chaos Ransomware Variant Sides with Russia?
output: Fortinet Labs has conducted research on how a new variant of Chaos ransomware is being utilized. Their assessment is that the ransomware may be distributed by email and forum posts that masquerade as updates on the Russian/Ukrainian conflict. Fortinet also assesses that there is a ransomware builder available that the latest version of Chaos came from. Indications are, based on reporting, that the perpetrator(s) of this ransomware have no intent on providing decryption keys. Fortinet believes that Chaos malware is being used to destroy information rather than for monetary gain.

instruction: Provide an overview for: An Analysis of Trickbot and Modules
output: Sure. Here is a description for An Analysis of Trickbot and Modules: The Trickbot malware has been around since 2016 and despite a significant takedown of the core servers used for Trickbot operations in October 2020, it remains active. A report from Check Point provides some statistics on Trickbot activity and an analysis of some of Trickbot's twenty modules. A list of the financial and technology companies whose users are currently targeted by Trickbot is provided in the report. Most of the targeted companies are located in the United States however Trickbot is active in many geographies. The report also provides an analysis of three Trickbot modules, injectDll, tabDLL, and pwgrabc, and details of some of the anti-analysis anti-deobfuscation techniques Trickbot uses.

instruction: Describe the following: The Maxtrilha Banking Trojan
output: Phishing emails, constructed from customized templates, are used to lure customers of banks in Europe and South America to install a banking Trojan named Maxtrilha, according to a report from Segurança Informática. There are two stages in the infection chain. When the first stage (a loader) executes, it opens a legitimate banking page to distract the victim while it sets up persistence, disables Internet Explorer's security settings, modifies software policy settings, and downloads the second stage, the Maxtrilha banking Trojan. Maxtrilha monitors Internet Explorer's windows and matches the pages against a hard-coded list. When a match is found, window overlays are used to obtain the victim's credentials. Other credentials are also obtained from the victim's system. Maxtrilha is capable of loading additional payloads using DLL injection. Data is uploaded to a C&C server that is believed to be located in Russia.

There are two stages in the infection chain. When the first stage (a loader) executes, it opens a legitimate banking page to distract the victim while it sets up persistence, disables Internet Explorer's security settings, modifies software policy settings, and downloads the second stage, the Maxtrilha banking Trojan. Maxtrilha monitors Internet Explorer's windows and matches the pages against a hard-coded list. When a match is found, window overlays are used to obtain the victim's credentials. Other credentials are also obtained from the victim's system. Maxtrilha is capable of loading additional payloads using DLL injection. Data is uploaded to a C&C server that is believed to be located in Russia.

instruction: What is SVCReady - A New Loader Malware
output: Here is an overview on SVCReady - A New Loader Malware: HP Research provided an analysis of the SVCReady malware that has been distributed in phishing campaigns that began in April. The initial compromise is via a Microsoft Word document attached to the phishing emails. Once opened, this document uses VBA AutoOpen macros to execute shellcode stored in the document properties that downloads and then executes the SVCReady malware using rundll32.exe. Once SVCReady is executed it collects certain system information and sends it to the C&C server using HTTP.  Initially, the C&C communications were unencrypted but in May, SVCReady began using RC4 to encrypt them. The malware then sets a registry key used to provide persistence but due to an apparent coding error, the malware does not execute after a system reboot. SVCReady then collects the same system information again but this time also includes a screenshot and sends it to the C&C server. Lastly in the infection chain, SVCReady uses two WMI queries to check if it is running in a virtualized environment and communicates its finding to the C&C server. In the early stages of the campaign, the RedLine Stealer malware was delivered as an additional payload. The report goes on to note the similarities between the campaigns delivering SVCReady and prior campaigns conducted by the financially-motivated threat group known as TA551.

instruction:
Given the description:
A security bug, tracked as CVE-2020-17049, has been shown to be exploitable with a POC code. The exploit has been named Kerberos Bronze Bit. The attack uses S4U2self and S4U2proxy, which are added as AD Kerberos protocol extensions. This allows the attack to gain access to the service ticket of the target. The forwardable flag in the ticket is set to 1. The ticket is used in the S4U2proxy to obtain the service ticket for the targeted user to the targeted service. With the ticket obtained, impersonation can be used, requests can be sent to the service, and requests processed by the user's authority. This exploit bypasses Kerberos delegation, thus allowing the attacker to escalate privilege. This, then, allows the requests to proceed under the escalated authority. Microsoft is releasing a two-stage rollout. The first was released on December 8, 2020. The second is a forced enforcement on February 9, 2020. Microsoft did release an out-of-band update to fix Kerberos authentication issues. Mitigation suggestions were released the week after CVE-2020-17049 was released. We and Microsoft recommend immediately patch all systems affected by this vulnerability.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Windows Kerberos Vulnerability Exploited

instruction: What is The WayBack Campaign
output: Here is an overview on The WayBack Campaign: The WayBack Campaign, named by Yoroi for its use of the Wayback Machine Internet Archive to store malicious code, has been active since at least April 2021. The campaign uses malspam to deliver weaponized PowerPoint documents. The malspam emails have been sent in at least six waves, the most recent listed in Yoroi's report being sent in the second week of June. The malicious PowerPoint document uses shortened URLs that point to Blogspot pages that contain obfuscated JavaScript code executed using MSHTA. In turn, this leads to malicious PowerShell scripts that have been stored in the Wayback Machine's pages. The PowerShell scripts are used to deliver the final payload which is typically either Agent Tesla or Oski information stealers or the Cobian RAT. Persistence is achieved using registry keys and a scheduled task. A registry key is used to trigger the download of a PowerShell script which is used to disable system protection mechanisms including the Firewall, Windows Defender, UAC controls, and whitelisted processes needed by the malware. Yoroi attributes the campaign to a threat actor they refer to as Aggah that may be associated with the Gorgon group.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for APT41 Back as Earth Baku and New Campaign?
output: APT41 has resurfaced as Earth Baku along with a new cyberespionage campaign. The campaign can be traced back as far as July 2020. Using attack vectors designed to exploit different infrastructures, the group is using SQL injection to upload malicious files, installing through InstallUtil.exe using a scheduled task, a possible malicious link file in an email attachment, and exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability (CVE-2021-26855) to upload the China Chopper web shell. In addition to the above, the campaign is using unidentified shellcode loaders named StealthVector and StealthMutant, as well as a backdoor called ScrambleCross. These tools, developed by Earth Baku, are used to facilitate targeted attacks on entities in specific industries within the Indo-Pacific region. Countries affected include India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam. StealthVector is a shellcode loader designed to be configurable for the threat actor's needs including disabling Event Tracing for Windows allowing for stealth mode execution. StealthMutant uses AES-256-ECB for decryption, whereas an earlier version uses XOR. This allows StealthMutant to perform process hollowing for execution remotely. ScrambleCross is a newly discovered backdoor. Instructions are received from a C2 server that allows it to receive and change plug-ins. The researchers have yet to obtain a plug-in to study. In addition to the tools mentioned, both StealthVector and StealthMutant contain a payload for Cobalt Strike beacons.

instruction: What is Povlsomware Ransomware
output: Here is an overview on Povlsomware Ransomware: Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing the Povlsomware ransomware. This ransomware is open-source, hosted on GitHub, and advertises itself as a proof-of-concept (POC) designed to test security vendor products. It operates much like most ransomware families, deleting backups, encrypting user files while avoiding system directories, and displaying a ransom note to the victim. Interestingly, the ransomware does not append a new extension to the encrypted file names, so the files do not look different when viewed in a directory. One of the most significant features of this ransomware that the researchers note is particularly concerning is its compatibility with Cobalt Strike. Specifically, it is capable of being executed by Cobalt Strike's execute-assembly function, which allows a payload to be run through memory from a Cobalt Strike server without dropping a payload onto the victim system. This decreases the chances of detection and analysis. Due to its purpose as a POC tool, the code does not include any capabilities to spread across a network or destroy devices, but its open-source nature could allow a malicious actor to add that functionality. While there is no evidence of this ransomware being used in the wild by malicious threat actors, its public availability presents the threat of such activity.

instruction:
Given the description:
NFTs are the latest trend in blockchain technology, and Fortinet researchers have discovered a campaign using this as a lure to spread malware. The researchers aren't certain what the initial delivery mechanism for the file is, but the file does contain information about NFTs. The first page of the file contains links to legitimate Discord groups that deal with NFTs, and the researchers speculated that this file may be sent to NFT enthusiasts in Israel in a phishing message. The file contains a macro that uses an obfuscated PowerShell script to download a file from a Discord server. This file resets the network connection in an attempt to stop any cloud-based analysis and downloads another file. This file injects the final payload into a copy of a legitimate Windows file, which has been determined to be BitRAT. This trojan can steal credentials from applications, mine for cryptocurrency, log keystrokes, and download files.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: BitRAT Distributed Using NFT Lure

instruction:
Given the description:
A large e-commerce platform's customers have been targeted in an active holiday season campaign spreading a multi-stage malware package called Chaes, Cybereason notes. Chaes is designed to steal consumer information, such as login credentials, credit card numbers, and other financial information. The e-commerce platform is a Brazilian company called MercadoLivre. Initial infection is from a phishing email that contains a DOCX file. Should the victim click on the attachment, this begins a template injection attack. Such an attack uses Microsoft Word's built-in feature to download the payload from a remote server. Once executed, additional files are dropped on the system needed for the infection. Persistence is gained through the use of a registry key.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Holiday Season At Risk From Chaes Malware

instruction: Tell me about Attackers Fight for Control of Sites Targeted in File Manager Vulnerability
output:
Certainly.
Attackers Fight for Control of Sites Targeted in File Manager Vulnerability

Wordfence previously reported on exploit activity targeting a vulnerability in the Wordpress File Manager plugin. After further monitoring of this activity, they discovered two key threat actors behind the attacks. The first actor, dubbed "bajatax," injects malicious code into multiple files in order to exfiltrate credentials of users logging into the victim site. Credentials are exfiltrated via the Telegram API and are likely either sold for profit or used to access other accounts using the same credentials. The second attacker is installing backdoors onto victim servers. This actor also leverages a different method of exploitation than bajatax. With backdoors installed on the system, the attacker injects additional malicious code into WordPress files. Possible final goals include cryptomining, SEO spam, or leasing access to a botnet. Both threat actors are adding password protection to the vulnerable file in order to prevent other attackers from infecting the server, allowing them to maintain control. Numerous additional threat actors have been observed, but these two actors are most prevalent and most successful.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Watering Hole Targeting Florida Water Utilities?
output: Dragos published a blog post analyzing a watering hole discovered while investigating a water poisoning attempt, which they determined were unrelated. The watering hole was present on a Florida water utility contractor's website; however, this was likely for the purpose of reducing chance of detection, not an attempt to eventually compromise ICS networks. Unlike many watering holes that attempt to exploit vulnerabilities or compromise victim hosts, this one simply attempted to gather system information, such as the OS version, CPU and video card details, settings, and more. Additionally, TLS and JA SSL fingerprint hashes were generated for each visitor. This information was then sent back to the attacker via a Heroku app. The researchers discovered similar code hosted on a supposed dark web marketplace that also acted as a check-in system for victims of the Tofsee botnet malware, specifically a variant dubbed "Tesseract" by Dragos due to a unique user-agent string. Based on this information, it is believed the activity being performed by the watering hole is an attempt to gather data in order to improve Tofee's ability to mimic legitimate browser traffic.

instruction: Describe the following: ZShlayer Malware
output: SentinelOne reports on ZShlayer, a Shlayer variant that leverages a different shell language in its infection chain. Specifically, the first-stage script, which previously was written in Bash, is now written in Zsh instead. This script arrives as part of an application bundle inside a DMG. It is heavily obfuscated but not notarized, unlike other recent versions of Shlayer. Zsh takes a base64-encoded file from the application bundle as its input. This file is a Bash script, specifically a Shlayer Bash script, which takes a secondary base64-encoded file from the application bundle and moves it to a newly-created application bundle. Further Bash scripts are executed in order to retrieve the final payload from a remote server. The specific payload delivered is based on OS version and other system information gathered by the script. In the end, the Shlayer payload is delivered to and installed on the victim host. SentinelOne references previous analyses of this malware family as the final payload is similar to those delivered in previous campaigns.

instruction:
Given the description:
An automated campaign targeting Magento stores, from September 11th through to the 14th, infected 1,904 stores with skimmers. At least some of the stores were running an outdated version of Magento that reached end of support in June 2020. According to the report, while Sansec researchers are still investigating the vector used to compromise the stores, it is speculated that the campaign may be using a 0-day remote code execution exploit that was recently offered for sale. It appears that after a store was compromised, the Magento admin panel and Magento Connect were used to download and install files. The code to load the skimmer was injected in prototype.js which is a legitimate Magento file.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: Provide an overview for: TA551 Abuses Sliver Red Team Tool
output: Sure. Here is a description for TA551 Abuses Sliver Red Team Tool: Proofpoint published a blog post on TA551's recent use of the Sliver red team tool in their operations. Email thread hijacking is used to send a password-protected ZIP to targets. Within the ZIP is a Word document that leverages malicious macros to download Sliver. With Sliver installed on the system, the attackers can take advantage of its infosteal, C2, token manipulation, and process injection capabilities. Proofpoint notes that this behavior is different from TA551's typical tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) as they usually act as an initial access broker, selling access to the compromised system rather than gaining direct access and interaction capabilities.

instruction:
Given the description:
According to Kaspersky, Emotet was first discovered in June 2014 by Trend Micro. Emotet is a malware package designed to steal banking credentials. Initial targets were German and Austrian bank users. At that time, the infection vector was bank-related spam with either weaponized attachments or links to ZIP files with the loader install. November of that year saw additional modules added that could modify HTTP(s) traffic, collect Outlook email addresses, and steal credentials in Mail PassView, among others. December saw unresponsive command and control servers as attacks dropped off. The following January saw a public RSA key and encrypted embedded strings. Swiss bank clients were also added to the victim list. June 2015 saw the beginning of another shutdown of the command and control servers. December of 2016 saw a new outlook for Emotet with the ability to infect victims using the RIG-E and RIG-V exploit kits. In February 2017, it was discovered that Emotet had included a spam module in its tool set. Banking clients in Poland were added in April's spam emails. May saw a change in the spam attachment used in the attack. This was the first time a weaponized Microsoft Word document (or a link to one) required the victim to enable macros. It was also the first time that Emotet began installing the banking Trojan Qbot (or QakBot), although the number of installs were not numerous. June saw Emotet begin to use a network spreading technique to infect other systems on the local network. In July, Emotet changed from using GET requests to using POST requests. The list of brute-force passwords used significantly increased in August. IBM X-Force announced in November that Emotet was now spreading IcedID. In January of 2018, Emotet began installing the banking Trojan Panda (also known as Zeus Panda). In April, Emotet added a module to spread laterally over wireless networks. In June, Emotet began a relationship with Trickbot (also known as Trickster). The ability to access computers behind NAT and convert them into command and control proxies was added in July. Installing Ryuk by Emotet began in August. October saw a brief suspension of command and control servers as well as an update to the Outlook exfiltration module. Another suspension of command and control servers began in November with a resumption beginning in January of 2019. March saw modifications to the HTTP protocol used in command and control communication. In April, data exfiltration (topics, mailing lists, message contents) began showing up in Emotet spam emails. From May until August, command and control servers went down once more. In November and February, additional minor changes were made to the headers in the HTTP protocol. Infections declined in February, not to resume until July. After starting back up in July, public reports indicated that the links in the spam emails were replaced with benign images and memes instead of the malicious Emotet payload. In a few days, this issue was corrected and Emotet began flowing again.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Emotet Chronicles

March saw modifications to the HTTP protocol used in command and control communication. In April, data exfiltration (topics, mailing lists, message contents) began showing up in Emotet spam emails. From May until August, command and control servers went down once more. In November and February, additional minor changes were made to the headers in the HTTP protocol. Infections declined in February, not to resume until July. After starting back up in July, public reports indicated that the links in the spam emails were replaced with benign images and memes instead of the malicious Emotet payload. In a few days, this issue was corrected and Emotet began flowing again.

instruction: Explain: NobleBaron Activity
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for NobleBaron Activity:

SentinelOne is tracking a cluster of activity, dubbed "NobleBaron," associated with the Nobelium threat actor and involving a convoluted multi-stage infection chain. Their blog post focuses on the NativeZone downloaders used to install final payloads. Most interestingly is the discovery of a NativeZone payload bundled with an installer for Ukrainian government security applications. It is not currently known how this installer is being distributed. The ZIP file for the installer contained both the legitimate application components and a malicious DLL. A LNK file is used to launch the downloader, similar to the ISO infection chain observed in previous reports on Nobelium. Once on the system, the malware connects drops a Cobalt Strike Beacon and connects to its C2 server. It is likely that these Cobalt Strike Beacons are being used as a first-stage to identify victims of interest. With more specific targets identified, the threat actors can deploy additional malware to carry out their ultimate goals.

instruction: Explain: Scammers Using MalwareBytes Renewals for Phishing
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Scammers Using MalwareBytes Renewals for Phishing:

A series of fake renewal notices and offers to remove security services offered by MalwareBytes has led their analysts to a phishing campaign. Several reports indicate the receipt of an email stating the product for which the customer may or may not have a legitimate license for has been seen in the wild. The email states that a subscription service offered by the company has been renewed at a rate much higher than the actual rate the company charges for this product. The threat actors show a charge of between $300-500. A typical yearly subscription for the product is actually about $100. The scam uses these emails in the hopes the victim will call and try to get the charges reversed. Should victims call, they're pointed to a website wherein a technician will remotely connect to their computer and 'uninstall' the product in question. Once the product is 'removed', the promise of a refund is given. Instead, the actors ask the victim to download TeamViewer and to share their ID and password to connect to the victim machine. The actors then install a second program to achieve persistence. In the same way as a tech support scheme, the threat actors use notepad to concoct a note telling the victim of the risks of not continuing with the product. Using SysKey, the actors place a password known only to them is installed on the computer. Should this be the case, a VBS script is downloaded and placed in the Startup folder. Upon completion of these acts, the scammers attempt to have the victim restart their machine in order to complete the 'uninstall' process. After restart, a Windows license expiration is displayed with a button to click. This button opens many browser windows to give the appearance of a malware infection. The hope is that some of the victims will call the number and ask that their service be reinstated.

instruction: Explain: FlyTrap Compromises Thousands of Facebook Accounts
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for FlyTrap Compromises Thousands of Facebook Accounts:

Seen as early as March 2021, the Android Trojan, FlyTrap, has been used to capture and compromise Facebook account for individuals that have downloaded certain applications from the Google Play store. While the applications are no longer available on the official Google Play store, they remain available from unofficial repositories. Using coupon code, voting, and other types of apps that entice victims into clicking links to sign in to Facebook in order to collect their "rewards." The threat actor has employed JavaScript injection in order to collect session information, cookies, user account details, location, and IP addresses. The malicious applications were meticulous created to present the impression of a legitimate application with realistic lures. In order to claim the offers, the victim is asked to login using a button disguised as a Facebook login connection. Once the victim enters their login information, a legitimate URL is displayed in a WebView window with JavaScript injection capabilities. This capability allows for the theft of the aforementioned information. The information is transferred to a C2 server that has been left open through a security vulnerability on the internet thus giving anyone with knowledge of the C2 server address access to the stolen information. Researchers were able to ascertain that more than 10,000 victims spanning 144 countries have been compromised.

instruction:
Given the description:
Proofpoint published a blog post analyzing new activity related to the TinyNuke malware. The campaign is leveraging invoice-themed phishing emails to target French organizations in manufacturing, industry, technology, finance, and other industries. The emails contain a link leading to a ZIP archive hosted on a compromised website. A JavaScript file within the archive leverages PowerShell to download a secondary ZIP containing the TinyNuke PE file. Persistence is established via a Registry Run key. TinyNuke is capable of performing form grabbing and web injects to steal credentials. Additionally, it can act as a loader for follow-on payloads. Proofpoint notes that the samples observed in this campaign use Tor for C2 communication, a modification to the original payload that indicates at least some of the original threat actors behind TinyNuke are involved still, despite the fact the malware is now publicly available.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: Tell me about New Threat Group - UNC3524
output:
Certainly.
New Threat Group - UNC3524

UNC3524 is a newly discovered threat group that focuses on collecting the emails of its targets. According to a report from Mandiant, the group targets employees working in the fields of acquisitions, corporate development, mergers, IT security staff, or that deal with large corporate transactions. Mandiant notes that UNC3524's targeting suggests a financial motivation, the level of tradecraft displayed by the group is more suggestive of an espionage actor. How UNC3524 gain their initial access to an organization is, at the time Mandiant's report was published, unknown. Once the group has gained access, they typically install a backdoor named QUIETEXIT on devices such as load balancers, SAN arrays, and wireless access point controllers. QUIETEXIT establishes an SSH connection to a C&C server, and once connected QUIETEXIT provides the functionality of an SSH server. It is also capable of setting up a SOCKS tunnel that allows the attackers to execute their tools on their local system thus leaving no traces of tools on the compromised systems. The C&C servers used by the group are a botnet of compromised IoT devices. The IoT devices are typically legacy conference room camera systems from a specific vendor. The IP addresses of the C&C servers are typically obtained using Dynamic DNS providers though an IP address and port can be specified in the command-line arguments used when executing QUIETEXIT.

instruction: Provide an overview for: South Eastern Asian Government Institutions Targeted By Chinese APT Group
output: Sure. Here is a description for South Eastern Asian Government Institutions Targeted By Chinese APT Group: In a recently published whitepaper, Bitdefender dissects the antics of a Chinese APT group's attacks on South Eastern Asian Government institutions. The paper indicates that these attacks have been going on since at least late 2018. Although proof was not found, Bitdefender suspects that social engineering via spam may be the source of infection. Chinoxy backdoor is first loaded and gains persistence on the infected system. Chinoxy then deploys additional modules, including in some cases, an open source Chinese RAT called PcShare. Lateral movement was also observed to some extent through the uses of credentials. How the credentials were obtained is unknown. System information is gathered through the use of a number of Windows command line tools such as tasklist.exe, ipconfig.exe, among others. Data gathered is sent back to the command and control servers on a daily basis.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Kimsuky Phishing Hard at Work
output: Sure. Here is a description for Kimsuky Phishing Hard at Work: Targeting everything from journalism to civil society organization, the Kimsuky group is ramping up their phishing efforts. Initial hypothesis indicates the group is harvesting credentials for espionage but also other objectives not yet known. A malicious document discussing North Korean defectors is used to lure victims. The document contains a UPX packed binary. The binary attempts to contact a C2 server. The document closely matches past documents in that it uses the same obfuscation technique, the C2 matches, contains VBA code similarities, and the digital signature signer name is dropped into the file. By all appearances, it looks as though the IP responsible for hosting the domain is dedicated to a single user. A secondary technique is to pivot from similar subdomains using unique strings. According to VirusTotal, the malicious document serves a specific link which is believed to be the pivot point. This pivot point leads to several other domains with each ending in a .work URL. These .work domains lead to several subdomains used in the campaign. Two entries containing rya in the domain are believed to lead to Radio Free Asia - a potential target. Another contains ohchr, believed to be the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. Additional targets can be gleaned from the list of domains uncovered. Analysis uncovered efforts dating back as far as December 2019 and continuing as recently as August of this year.

instruction: What is Evasive Maneuvers in Data Stealing Gateways
output: Here is an overview on Evasive Maneuvers in Data Stealing Gateways: Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a PHP script that seems to be used to exfiltrate sensitive data. This PHP script is only several lines long and uses cURL to establish a session with a remote gateway and exfiltrate information from a specified stream via POST parameters. This allows attackers to send data from a victim website to a gateway script hosted at another location, which would, subsequently, relay the stolen data to the attacker. Notably, the variable to set the external gateway contains the string "AZORult," a well-known information stealer. Furthermore, the PHP script was found alongside a series of data-stealing scripts, further bolstering the theory that the PHP file acts as an exfiltration method for data stolen by malicious stealers.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Zoho ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus Vulnerability Exploited in the Wild
output: Sure. Here is a description for Zoho ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus Vulnerability Exploited in the Wild: Zoho's ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus is IT help desk software that includes asset management features. Versions 11305 and prior (ServiceDesk Plus Cloud versions are not affected) are affected by a vulnerability (CVE-2021-44077) that could allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary code. The vulnerability was addressed in an update that was released by Zoho on September 16. According to a joint alert (AA21-336A) from CISA and the FBI, the vulnerability is being exploited in the wild. APT actors are noted as being among those who have been exploiting the vulnerability.

instruction: Tell me about Kubernetes Targeted By TeamTNT
output:
Certainly.
Kubernetes Targeted By TeamTNT

Widely adopted applications are often at most risk for attack. Kubernetes is one such application. Used for the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications, Kubernetes is the most widely adopted of these platforms. TeamTNT has been actively scanning for open Kubernetes cluster for some time. According to the report, nearly 50,000 IPs have been compromised as a result of this targeting and the subsequent attacks by TeamTNT. Some of the IPs were targeted repeatedly with success in exploiting these IPs. Most of the activity covered in the report occurred between March and May 2021. According to ISP lists, most of the targeted nodes/IPs were located in China and the US. Other countries were targeted but with 71% coming from China and the US, it can be assumed these countries were the main targets of the attacks. Initially, the bash history is disabled and environment variables are set for C2 server communication. The script used to disable bash history is also used to install two free, open-source tools - masscan and Zgrab. Also installed are a crypto miner and XMRig Monero miner. Additionally, an IRC bot is installed, similar to Kaiten. Using Masscan, the threat actor checks for any host with port 10250 open. This port is part of the Kubelet API and is open by default. The Kubelet server lists running pods, thus giving the attacker a target of opportunity. The API is then set to update the package index of the container, instal bash, wget, and curl, download a shell script, and begin the mining process for Monero cryptocurrency. The pwn function within the script subsequently attempts to find new targets in much the same way a worm would behave.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Operation EmailThief
output: Sure. Here is a description for Operation EmailThief: Volexity published a blog post analyzing a spear-phishing campaign targeting European government and media organizations. The threat actor exploits a zero-day cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the Zimbra email platform to carry out their ultimate goal of steal email data. An initial wave of phishing emails was observed seemingly being used go identify valid email addresses to be used in the second wave. The second wave used more sophisticated content using a variety of themes, and some were targeted while others were not. If a user clicked the link while signed into a Zimbra via the web browser, the attacker was able to execute arbitrary JavaScript. This actor specifically used the exploit to run code that iterates over the victim's inbox and sent folders and exfiltrate the email content and attachments via an HTTP POST request. At the time of writing, no patch is available for this vulnerability.

instruction:
Given the description:
ICS-CERT has released two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in B. Braun Melsungen AG products. 

ICSMA-20-296-01 addresses three vulnerabilities in B. Braun OnlineSuite. These vulnerabilities include: relative path traversal, uncontrolled search path element, and improper neutralization of formula elements in a CSV file. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include privilege escalation, arbitrary file upload and download, and remote code execution. 

ICSMA-20-296-02, addresses eleven vulnerabilities in B. Braun SpaceCom, Battery Pack SP with Wi-Fi, and Data module compactplus. The vulnerabilities include, cross-site scripting, hard-coded credentials, XPath injection, and several other vulnerability types. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include: information disclosure, privilege escalation, arbitrary file upload, and remote code execution.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction:
Given the description:
The usage of LNK files to deliver malware increased in the second quarter of 2022 according to a report from McAfee Labs. The report provides an analysis of recent LNK infection chains that have been used by Emotet, IcedID, and Qakbot. The Emotet infection chain uses an LNK file with arguments that calls cmd.exe and results in the creation of a .VBS file. The file is then executed by wscript.exe and downloads a payload in the form of a DLL file which is executed using Regsvr32.exe. The IcedID, and Qakbot chains use LNK files to invoke PowerShell. In the Qakbot chain, PowerShell is used directly to download and execute the DLL payload. The IcedID uses PowerShell to invoke mshta.exe which downloads a .exe payload. The report notes that the use of LNK files is not limited to the three examples provided.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Use of LNK Files to Deliver Malware Increases

instruction: Tell me about Threat Actors Using Voter Registration Themes in Phishing Lures
output:
Certainly.
Threat Actors Using Voter Registration Themes in Phishing Lures

Proofpoint has published their analysis of a threat actor who is using voter registration lures after a history of using other phishing kits with different themes. The voter registration emails claim that the recipient's application could not be confirmed and provides a link to re-confirm the application. It appears to come from the Election Assistance Commission (EAC) but the phishing page the user is taken to impersonates ServiceArizona instead, despite being sent to users in multiple states. Analysis of the phishing kit reveals an email address that gathered data is sent to. By pivoting off of this email address, the researchers were able to find several more phishing kits used by the same actor. One used a generic PayPal theme, while another took advantage of the COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 page appeared to target UK users instead of US users. Lastly, based on code similarity, a secondary voter registration page was identified. This one impersonated the EAC instead of ServiceArizona. Both of the pages attempted to gather personal information. In all cases, the phishing kits appeared to be hosted on compromised WordPress sites.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for SMAUG Ransomware as a Service?
output: SentinelOne published their analysis of the SMAUG RaaS offering. It has some interesting characteristics not commonly seen with other RaaS offerings. It first appeared in the threat landscape at the end of April 2020. Similar to other ransomware services, a percentage of the profit made by the purchasers is provided to the operators in order to receive the payload and services. Additionally, the operators charge a registration fee, one that is quite a bit higher than those charged by competitors (.2 BTC or $1,800). One of the most unique features of SMAUG is its multi-platofrm support, allowing encryption of Windows, Linux and macOS systems. Additionally, when building the malicious payload, an option is provided to allow a single encryption key to be used across all victim hosts in a single company. Anti-analysis, offline execution, customizable campaigns are all features advertised in their forum posts. The payloads are generated via a web-based management interface as opposed to the more common offline builder. This web portal also allows victims to decrypt a single file for free. The generated payloads for Windows are obfuscated Go binaries. On Windows, persistence is established via the LoadAppInit_DLLs Registry key. A ransom note is dropped in all folders containing encrypted files. The researchers also note that the SMAUG portal provides detailed walkthroughs for victims and affiliates.

It first appeared in the threat landscape at the end of April 2020. Similar to other ransomware services, a percentage of the profit made by the purchasers is provided to the operators in order to receive the payload and services. Additionally, the operators charge a registration fee, one that is quite a bit higher than those charged by competitors (.2 BTC or $1,800). instruction: Explain: DarkSide Ransomware on Linux
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for DarkSide Ransomware on Linux:

A Linux variant of the DarkSide ransomware that was analyzed by Trend Micro exhibits significant differences over the Windows version. One of the more notable differences is that the Linux variant specifically targets files (vmdk, vmem, vswp, log, and vmsn) related to virtual machines running on VMware ESXI servers. DarkSide also executes several ESXCLI commands to gather information and powers off VMs before encryption. The root directory specified in the analyzed version's configuration is "/vmfs/volumes/". This is an ESXi server's default location for VM files. Aside from its hard-coded configuration, DarkSide can also accept parameters passed at runtime. Files are encrypted using a ChaCha20 stream cipher and an RSA 4096-bit key. The ransom notes left on the system are named "darkside_readme.txt" and files that are encrypted have a suffix of ".darkside" added to their names. Both the name and extension were hard-coded in the sample's configuration but can also be configured with runtime parameters. The C&C servers to which information is sent are hard-coded in the configuration. The strings and configuration in the Linux variant are not obfuscated.

instruction: Explain: Adobe Security Bulletins - October 20th, 2020
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Adobe Security Bulletins - October 20th, 2020:

Adobe has published 10 security bulletins addressing vulnerabilities in various products.

APSB20-53 addresses seven critical vulnerabilities in Adobe Illustrator that could lead to arbitrary code execution.

APSB20-55 addresses a privilege escalation vulnerability in Adobe Dreamweaver.

APSB20-60 addresses a cross-site script (XSS) vulnerability in Adobe Marketo that could allow for JavaScript execution in the browser.

APSB20-61 addresses four critical vulnerabilities in Adobe Animate that could lead to arbitrary code execution.

APSB20-62 addresses two critical vulnerabilities in Adobe After Effects that could lead to arbitrary code execution.

APSB20-63 addresses a critical vulnerability in Adobe Photoshop that could lead to arbitrary code execution.

APSB20-64 addresses a critical vulnerability in Adobe Premiere Pro that could lead to arbitrary code execution.

APSB20-65 addresses a critical vulnerability in Adobe Media Encoder that could lead to arbitrary code execution.

APSB20-66 addresses a critical vulnerability in Adobe InDesign that could lead to arbitrary code execution.

APSB20-68 addresses a critical vulnerability in Adobe Creative Cloud Desktop Application that could lead to arbitrary code execution.

Adobe has released updates to patch each of these issues.

instruction: Provide an overview for: COVID-19 Themed Phishing Attacks and the Fake Websites Created for Them
output: Sure. Here is a description for COVID-19 Themed Phishing Attacks and the Fake Websites Created for Them: Palo Alto's Unit 42 revisits the phishing trends they observed over the past year, gaining deeper insight into the various COVID-related topics that attackers might try to exploit.Attackers continued to change their tactics to adapt to the latest pandemic trends. They are constantly creating new websites to host their phishing campaigns. Topics in COVID-19-themed phishing included testing (including test kits and scheduling), personal protection equipment (PPE), government stimulus programs, treatment using pharmaceutical drugs, prevention via vaccines, and vaccine distribution. Some attacks were phishing for credentials from employees working in organizations such as Walgreens drug stores and pharmaceutical research, development, and production companies.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for IndigoZebra APT Group Attacking Central Asia?
output: The IndigoZebra APT group (named by Kaspersky) has been targeting Central-Asian countries since at least 2014, according to Check Point. The Afghan government was a recent target of a spearphishing campaign carried out by the group. The emails purported to be from an employee of the Administrative Office of the President in Afghanistan. They were sent to a number of employees of the Afghanistan National Security Council and had a password-protected RAR archive attached. The archive contained an executable file which is a dropper that installs the BoxCaon backdoor. BoxCaon uses Dropbox for C&C services. A check for the presence of Kaspersky antivirus software is carried out and if it is not present, a registry key is added for persistence. Once the backdoor was installed, the operators installed and executed a NetBIOS scanning tool named ntbscan, along with a number of Windows networking utilities. Other backdoors used by IndigoZebra are Poison Ivy and xCaon.

instruction: Describe the following: Egregor Ransomware, Used in a String of High-Profile Attacks
output: Recorded Future analyzed a surge of ransomware attacks associated with the ransomware variant Egregor, a part of the Sekhmet ransomware family. Egregor ransomware is an intricate piece of malware that employs obfuscation and anti-analysis, initiating both ransomware and double extortion attacks, according to analysts at Recorded Future. The security team at Recorded Future found the initial surge of attacks started in September and continued to increase in attack tempo, with their sights on high profile targets across multiple industries. According to Recorded Future, first, the threat actors exploit poorly-secured RDP services to initiate intrusion tactics. Once that is successful, threat actors begin to launch their payload with elements of SHA256 hashing and the lesser-known Rabbitcryptographic cipher combined to decrypt the payload. Further analysis revealed the ransomware having the capability to collect victim’s system information, including username, computer name, general system information, domain name, workgroup, and installed AV programs. In conclusion, analysts at Recorded Future address the severity behind recent developments in threat actors TTPs as it relates to the ransomware and the various tools they use and make several recommendations to help end-users stay protected.

instruction: Provide an overview for: XcodeSpy Malware Targets Xcode Developers with EggShell Backdoor
output: Sure. Here is a description for XcodeSpy Malware Targets Xcode Developers with EggShell Backdoor: SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the XcodeSpy malware. This malware targets Xcode developers using a Trojanized version of the "TabBarInteraction" Xcode project hosted on Github. In the build phase of this project, an obfuscated run script has been added to carry out malicious activities. Specifically, a hidden file is created in the /tmp directory to pipe a command via a reverse shell to the attacker's C2. Once C2 communication is established, the EggShell backdoor is dropped on the victim host and executed. It first creates persistence via a user LaunchAgent. When successfully installed on the host, the attacker can use this backdoor to download files, steal information, record the microphone, camera, and keyboard, and more. Based on VirusTotal file submissions and whois data for the C2 domains, this campaign was active from at least July to October 2020 and primarily targeted developers in Asia. SentinelOne believes that since there are associated EggShell backdoor samples that were uploaded to VirusTotal prior to the XcodeSpy malware, there may be additional XcodeSpy samples not yet discovered.

instruction: Describe the following: Cyberpunk 2077 Release Hoax is Actually Data Theft Attempt
output: With the much anticipated impending release of the PC game Cyberpunk 2077 comes a scam being perpetrated against impatient users. The scam involves the download of a fake installer, which is used to steal data through a series of redirects and phishing pages. When the user visits one of the fake sites, they are presented with the option to download a copy of the game, which, in actuality, is an executable that masquerades as the real game installer. This executable contains legitimate looking splash screens and buttons. Though some buttons are unusable, it's a convincing enough fake that users are clicking on the install link. Once the install link is clicked, a window is displayed that shows the "game" being downloaded and unpacked. The program doesn't actually perform an install action; instead, the program only emulates the install process. From here, the user is presented with the option of entering a license key. Since the game is not yet released, the actors decided to include a link in the installer, which will allow the victim to obtain a key. The link takes the victim to another site that leads to a survey or giveaway entry. A new prompt is displayed asking a set of questions, such as requests for phone number and email addresses. This information, it is hypothesized, is the target data set of the threat actors. The site does provide a key, which has been hard coded into the installer' however, the game will not start as a DLL is missing from the installation. The user would have to click the download button again. They are taken to a dead end site with another survey.

instruction: Tell me about ICS-CERT Security Advisories - October 15th, 2020
output:
Certainly.
ICS-CERT Security Advisories - October 15th, 2020

ICS-CERT has released two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in Advantech devices.

ICSA-20-289-01 addresses an external control of file name or path vulnerability in Advantech WebAccess/SCADA. If successfully exploit, an remote attacker may be able to execute code as an administrator on the target device.

ICSA-20-289-02 addresses an SQL Injection vulnerability in Advantech R-SeeNet applications. If successfully exploited, a remote attacker may be able to retrieve sensitive information from the R-SeeNet database.

Advantech has patch both vulnerabilities. We recommend reviewing the advisories for patches and mitigation advice.
