instruction: Tell me about WordPress and SEO Shop Malware
output:
Certainly.
WordPress and SEO Shop Malware

A strain of malware used to set up SEO shops in WordPress environments is making the rounds according to a researcher. Attacking a honeypot, the threat actor was able to guess the credentials of the site owner and upload a malware-infected plug-in. The index.php file was overwritten and checks for a certain string where implemented. If this string is found, a different site is presented to the user. The code is gzip obfuscated, base64 encoded, and contains ROT13 encoding in some cases. The malware adds an .htaccess file to redirect the user to the malicious code. A GET request is sent to the site and the code rewrites the request in order to present the different site. The headers of the request are presented out of order and the User-Agent string is presented as a Google bot. This technique gives the threat actor a way to hide amongst the logs. This obfuscation attempt is weak, at best. Additionally, a Do-Not-Track request header is seen. The malware is most likely obfuscated through an obfuscation app, identified by its use of many variables typically seen in obfuscation apps. The code check for "nobotuseragent" in an effort to show the C2 is the sending computer. The malware also uses password authentication to verify the C2 is legitimate. The password is verified through an MD5 hash.

instruction:
Given the description:
Proofpoint has published an analysis of campaigns that began in late 2021 and targeted governments, foreign policy think tanks, and a state-affiliated airline located in the Middle East. Proofpoint attributes the campaigns to a threat group they refer to as TA402 who is also known as Molerats and the Gaza Cybergang. IBM X-Force tracks the activities of the group using the identifier Hive0022. The threat group is believed to be Arabic-speaking, politically motivated, and acting in the interests of the Palestinian Territories. The campaigns typically began with phishing emails that contained links that, in two of the three analyzed cases, led to a host that used geolocation to redirect connections that did not originate from the target countries to a news site. Of the two examples that used the redirection based on geolocation, one used a website masquerading as Quora on an attacker-controlled domain, and the other involved an actor-controlled domain and WordPress site that carried out the redirections. In the third case, the group was using Dropbox to host the malicious files but were unable to conduct the geolocation redirection due to not having control of the domain. Dropbox was also used for C&C services in some cases. If a connection originated from one of the targeted countries, the victim was led to an RAR file that contained malicious executables. The payload was a new Trojan developed by TA402 that Proofpoint has named NimbleMamba and has features typical of malware used in intelligence gathering and initial access. In some cases, a second payload, the BrittleBush Trojan, was also deployed.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: Describe the following: VMware ESXi OpenSLP Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
output: Rapid7 expands on the ESXI vulnerabilities CVE-2020-3992 and CVE-2019-5544 that Microsoft indicated evidence of active exploitation existed. These two remote code execution vulnerabilities existed in VMware's service location protocol (SLP) service. The initial October patch did not adequately correct the issue and an update was issued on November 4th. VMware has issued a document describing how to disable the CIM server, as well as a workaround document.

instruction: What is Analysis of a Quantum Ransomware Attack
output: Here is an overview on Analysis of a Quantum Ransomware Attack: Beginning with an email that had an ISO attachment that contained the IcedID malware, attackers installed the Quantum ransomware, domain-wide, in under 4 hours, according to a DFIR Report analysis. The ISO file contained two files, the IcedID malware in the form of a DLL and an LNK file that was used to execute it. Once executed, IcedID carried out a number of discovery tasks using built-in Windows utilities and created a scheduled task for persistence. Later, using process hollowing and injection, Cobalt Strike was installed on the host and later used to access LSASS memory to obtain credentials. The attackers carried out a number of discovery operations and then tested the credentials they had obtained on a server using WMI. RDP was then used to connect to the server and deploy a Cobalt Strike Beacon. Other servers were then connected to using RDP and then the ransomware was copied into the C$ share folder on each server. The ransomware was executed using WMI and PsExec.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Resurgence of The Emotet Botnet Malware
output: Sure. Here is a description for Resurgence of The Emotet Botnet Malware: Emotet is one of the most prolific malware types utilized by threat actors. Past reporting indicates that the Emotet botnet malware has been utilized by a number of threat actors to compromise endpoints and networks. Emotet has also been utilized to create a botnet that is marketed as malware as a service (MaaS). After the international law enforcement operation known as Ladybird, it was assessed that the botnet and the adjacent infrastructure had been taken down. TrendMicro now believes that the Emotet botnet malware returned and is once again operational. The newest version of Emotet now utilizes Excel 4.0 to execute downloads. Emotet malware has continued to change and uses several techniques to avoid detection. Two techniques employed by the latest version of Emotet include using .ocx on the file extension and deploying carets in URLs.

instruction: What is Industry Attack Trends from IBM Network Telemetry Data
output: Here is an overview on Industry Attack Trends from IBM Network Telemetry Data: IBM Security’s network data from monitored devices provides a wealth of insight into attack trends across industries and time. While the majority of the data events in our telemetry represent attempted attacks - rather than successful intrusions - these metrics are helpful in identifying the methods attackers are using in an attempt to gain unauthorized access or conduct unauthorized activity on clients’ networks, and how those trends are changing over time. This report discusses the top attack trends X-Force has observed by industry from telemetry data throughout all of 2020 as well as the first quarter of 2021.

instruction: Tell me about New Targeting of National Oil Company’s Ongoing Development and Exploration Projects
output:
Certainly.
New Targeting of National Oil Company’s Ongoing Development and Exploration Projects

In mid-September 2020, IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence observed a wave of phishing emails targeting companies likely having an interest in the pipeline offshore Sarawak, Malaysia project led by Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) Exploration and Production Public Co. Ltd’s (PTTEP). instruction: Provide an overview for: Magniber Ransomware Exploiting PrintNightmare Vulnerability
output: Sure. Here is a description for Magniber Ransomware Exploiting PrintNightmare Vulnerability: The Magniber ransomware originally targeted users in South Korea but later widened its scope to include other countries in the Asia Pacific region. In early 2021, CrowdStrike observed Magniber targeting South Korean users and exploiting an Internet Explorer vulnerability, CVE-2020-0968. CrowdStrike is reporting that Magniber is still targeting South Korean users but in July was observed exploiting the PrintNightmare vulnerability, CVE-2021-34527. While the delivery method is not specified in CrowdStrike's report, in the past Magniber is known to have been distributed through malvertising. Once the PrintNightmare vulnerability has been successfully exploited, a loader is used to inject the ransomware payload that handles file traversal and encryption into a process. The ransom note directs the victim to a .onion site for information on the ransom amount and obtaining a decryption key.

instruction: What is Linux Malware Agent Targeting eCommerce Sites
output: Here is an overview on Linux Malware Agent Targeting eCommerce Sites: Sansec published a blog post analyzing a Linux backdoor discovered on a compromise eCommerce site. A file upload vulnerability was exploited to upload a webshell and intercept customer data. With their access, the attacker also installed a backdoor in the form of a Linux executable. The executable was written in Golang and masquerades as the ps process. Once running on the system, the backdoor is capable of receiving commands from its C2 server. Persistence is established via crontab using a curl command that will re-download and execute the malware on reboot. The researchers note that skimming code was also uncovered on the server, although whether this malware is connected to the same threat actor is not specified.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Nokoyawa Ransomware
output: Sure. Here is a description for Nokoyawa Ransomware: In February 2022, SentinelLabs observed two samples of what they conclude is a variant of Nemty that has been named Nokoyawa. SentinelLabs has now published an analysis of Nokoyawa which looks at the similarities between Nemty and Nokoyawa. Some of the similarities are both manage multi-threaded encryption in the same way. Additionally, both types of malware accept command line parameters though Nokoyawa has additional options, and both generate keys in the same manner. Nokoyawa however has flaws in its encryption routine which may result in excluding multiple folders from encryption.

instruction: Tell me about Apple Security Updates May 3 2021 - Exploitation in the Wild Reported
output:
Certainly.
Apple Security Updates May 3 2021 - Exploitation in the Wild Reported

Apple has published security updates which take macOS Big Sur to 11.3.1, iOS (for older devices) to 12.5.3, iOS and iPadOS to 14.5.1, and watchOS to 7.4.1. In total, four vulnerabilities are addressed in the updates, one of which is common to all updates. All four vulnerabilities are WebKit issues and are all reported as being actively exploited in the wild. All four vulnerabilities, if successfully exploited, could potentially allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code. We recommend updating to the latest versions as soon as possible.

instruction: Explain: A Compromise, BazarLoader, and an Apparent Conti Affiliate
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for A Compromise, BazarLoader, and an Apparent Conti Affiliate:

An article from the DFIR Report follows the activities of a threat actor from the initial compromise until their eviction from the system some three days later. While it is not absolutely certain, it is believed that the initial compromise was gained through a malicious document attached to a spearphishing email. A short time after the initial compromise, the actor was observed using standard Microsoft utilities for discovery and a Cobalt Strike beacon was installed shortly thereafter. While attempting to enumerate the network, the actor mistyped a lot of commands. In addition, they were seen to be following the instructions, in order, from some documents that are provided to Conti affiliates. In some cases, even using the same passwords from the documents for accounts they created. Adfind, native Windows utilities, and the Cobalt Strike beacon were used for further discovery. Credentials used for privilege escalation were obtained by dumping LSASS. When satisfied with their discovery phase the actor, using a reverse proxy, connected to the compromised host using RDP. Next, they moved laterally to the domain controller using RDP, downloaded and executed AdFind, executed two separate Cobalt Strike beacons, created two local administrator accounts, and installed a copy of the AnyDesk remote access software. They continued enumerating the network using PowerSploit and began searching for documents of interest on hosts connected to the domain. Another tool, the Advanced IP Scanner was used to scan for other subnets on the LAN. Later, they again enumerated the domain controller, this time using Seatbelt and then pivoted to another domain controller and carried out the same steps as they had done on the previous domain controller. After a period of inactivity, the actor returned to the system and used Rclone to exfiltrate the data they had collected to the public file-sharing service, Mega. Their access to the system was terminated not long after this. Amongst the data the actor collected, was an active directory backup they created, made in “IFM” media mode. All these steps and the apparent use of Conti affiliate instructions suggest the intended outcome of the attack was the deployment of the Conti ransomware, prevented in the case when the actor was evicted from the systems prior to Conti deployment.

instruction: Tell me about BotenaGo Source Code Uploaded to GitHub
output:
Certainly.
BotenaGo Source Code Uploaded to GitHub

AT&T published a blog post analyzing the BotenaGo source code that has been uploaded to GitHub by an unknown actor. The researchers note that malware source code is written is such a way that other attackers are likely to use it as a starting point for their own malware. There are two primary aspects to the malware's functionality. First, it is able to install a reverse shell and telnet loader in order to create a backdoor for remote command execution. The second part of the malware is the scanner and exploits allowing for the compromise of additional systems. In total there are 33 exploits primarily targeting routers and internet of things (IoT) devices. Each exploit has a configuration allowing for customization by the operator.

instruction:
Given the description:
Intezer published a blog post analyzing a Golang worm being used to distribute the XMRig miner to victim servers. Since it is written in Golang, a cross-platform language, it is capable of infecting both Linux and Windows systems. Specifically, it targets MySQL, Tomcat, and Jenkins servers by brute-forcing weak credentials. In addition, older versions supported the exploitation of a WebLogic vulnerability as an initial infection vector. Once on a system, the worm checks for existing infections and, if not present, installs the miner. The miner is embedded within the Golang binary. To spread across infected networks, the worm performs a scan to identify servers running MySQL, Tomcat, or Jenkins and carries out its brute force functionality. Once access is obtained, exploitation of vulnerabilities on the server are used to execute either a bash script or PowerShell script that retrieves the worm payload. This cycle repeats in an attempt to infect as many hosts as possible in order to increase mining profits.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction:
Given the description:
In a BlackBerry posting, they indicated that MountLocker, a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) malware package, now allows their affiliates to doubly extort their victims. Not only are the victim's files encrypted, but prior to encryption, they are exfiltrated back to the attackers. Thus, if the victim does not pay the ransom to decrypt their locked files, they are then threatened with the exposure of their files to the Internet at large. The affiliates appear to be using off-the-shelf tools, such as CobaltStrike Beacon, as a means of distributing their licensed version of MountLocker. RDP with compromised credentials to access the victim's system was another means of distribution observed in some of the MountLocker campaigns. A site on the Dark Web contains the list of current victims and potential links to their private data. MountLocker is generally installed in one of two ways - as a 32-bit or 64-bit Windows portable executable (PE) or as a Microsoft Installer (MSI) package. Prior to beginning encryption, MountLocker attempts to disable a number of security products as well as products known for keeping files open, such as databases or Microsoft Office applications. This is done to ensure that those files are encrypted and not skipped due to an application lock.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Double Extortion Offer From MountLocker Ransomware

instruction:
Given the description:
Xen has published ten security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in their software. The advisories also provide patches to fix the issues.

XSA-333 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25602, resulting from the handling of guest access to MSR_MISC_ENABLE. They note that only x86 systems are vulnerable, not ARM systems. Additionally only x86 PV guests can exploit the vulnerability, while x86 HVM/PVH guests cannot.

XSA-334 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25598, resulting from a missing unlock in XENMEM_acquire_resource error path. This could allow a buggy or malicious HVM stubdomain to cause an RCU reference to be leaked. As stated by Xen, "Only VMs using HVM stubdomains can exploit the vulnerability. VMs using PV stubdomains, or with emulators running in dom0 cannot exploit the vulnerability."

XSA-336 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25604, resulting from a race when migrating timers between x86 HVM vCPU-s. This requires an x86 system with more than one vCPU and an x86 HVM guest account.

XSA-337 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25595, due to PCI passthrough code reading back hardware registers. Risk of privilege escalation and information leaks also exists. Exploitation requires an x86 system that supports PCI passthrough, a guest account with guests with passed through PCI devices, and out-of-spec functionality.

XSA-338 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25597, resulting from logic in the handling of event channel operations. Xen states "only systems with untrusted guests permitted to create more than the default number of event channels are vulnerable."

XSA-339 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25596, caused by the SYSENTER instruction leaving various state sanitization activities to software. Only x86 systems supporting the SYSENTER instruction in 64bit mode are vulnerable and only x86 PV guests can exploit the vulnerability.

XSA-340 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25603, resulting from missing memory barriers when accessing/allocating an event channel. Risk of privilege escalation and information leaks also exists.

XSA-342 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25600, resulting from out of bounds event channels available to 32-bit x86 domains. Only x86 32-bit domains servicing other domains are vulnerable.

XSA-343 addresses a privilege escalation vulnerability, CVE-2020-25599, resulting from races with evtchn_reset(). Denial of service conditions and information leaks are also possible.

XSA-344 addresses a denial of service vulnerability, CVE-2020-25601, due to lack of preemption in evtchn_reset().

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Xen Security Advisories - September 22, 2020

instruction: Explain: Studying Skidmap's DNS Requests
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Studying Skidmap's DNS Requests:

Netlab 360 has published a paper where they tracked down a mining operation, using a miner named skidmap, based on its DNS requests. They used a tool called DNSMon to analyze DNS data to track down the infrastructure in use. Three domains were discovered in May of 2019, followed by one in November. In September and October of 2020, three more domains were added to their list. Similarities in domain name structure, choice of subdomains, and the consistent nature of the behavior patterns of the DNS requests indicated that they belonged on the list. Sample code from URLs discovered were quite similar to those analyzed by Trend Micro, which were published about four months later.

instruction: Explain: LockBit: Using Automated Attacks
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for LockBit: Using Automated Attacks:

According to researchers at Sophos, threat actors have begun utilizing the ransomware Lockbit to attack small organizations and detect systems with sensitive data they can leverage. They are using improved tactics to avoid detection, such as utilizing scripts from a remote Google document, manipulating PowerShell to thwart efforts at monitoring and logging to initiate a persistent backdoor, and employing renamed copies of PowerShell.exe. Initially, combining these tools allows threat actors to escalate privileges by avoiding User Account Controls. For example, during analysis researchers observed the attack scripts attempting to divert Window 10’s built-in anti-malware interface by instantly applying malicious patches onto its memory in an effort to collect valuable data before launching the LockBit ransomware. Researchers at Sophos also assessed the threat actors leveraging LockBit ransomware favor PowerShell Empire. This is because it provides them the ability to easily manipulate modifications, which threat actors have already begun doing by building new sets of customized tools they can leverage for future attacks, according to researchers at Sophos.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Sharp Uptick in Emotet Activity Beginning September 2020?
output: In September 2020, X-Force observed a significant spike in Emotet activity. This activity continued to remain relatively high in October and as of the publication of this report, remains high. This spike mirrored a similar spike seen in January 2020. The spike was primarily observed targeting the financial and manufacturing sectors. This dramatic increase in activity could be explained by a variety of factors. Threat actors commonly use Emotet to drop additional malware payloads, and with the recent Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) advisory on Trickbot usage, threat actors may have shifted to using Emotet to avoid scrutiny.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for z0Miner Cryptominer Exploits Confluence RCE Vulnerability?
output: Trend Micro has published a report on the z0Miner Trojan exploiting the remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability CVE-2021-26084 in Atlassian’s Confluence. On successful exploitation of the vulnerability, web shells are installed. The web shells are used to download further files. The actual mining tools are downloaded using a URL contained in one of the files downloaded by the web shells. Multiple mechanisms are used to achieve persistence including a scheduled task and a fake integration service. There are also multiple methods employed to evade detection. As seems to be common amongst cryptomining malware, z0Miner also deletes any other cryptominers it detects on the system.

instruction: Describe the following: Commodity .NET Packers use Embedded Images to Hide Payloads
output: Proofpoint published their analysis of two commodity .NET packers that leverage steganography to distribute payloads. The first, dubbed "CyaX," is delivered as a .NET executable with a PNG image in its resources. When the image is decoded using Blue, Green, Red, and Alpha (BGRA) channels, a secondary executable is revealed. This secondary executable also contains a .NET resource, often packed with ConfuserEx or .NET Reactor, that can be decoded to reveal the final payload. Two additional variants are discussed: one which uses Red, Green, and Blue (RGB) channels instead of BGRA and compresses the immediate executable with gzip, and one that uses proper steganography against a secondary PNG image. The samples they analyzed were seen either dropping the Agent Tesla malware or Remcos RAT. The second packer analyzed, Hectobmp, contains several hundreds of images in the .NET resources, each of which contains part of the payload. Previously the images were stored in BMP file format, but more recent versions use PNG. Once decoded using RGB channels and reassembled in the correct order, a zlib Deflate compressed payload is dropped on the system. In this case, decoding the payload revealed an Agent Tesla sample.

instruction: Describe the following: Vulnerabilities in Western Digital Replay Protected Memory Block
output: Western Digital's Replay Protected Memory Block is a protocol used to provide the ability for a host to store data in specific memory areas in an authenticated and replay-protected manner. This protocol has been found to have two separate vulnerabilities. The first prompts the host to conclude the data write failed. The data request contains a write value, address, and a MAC on those values. If the actor is able to intercept the request, they can modify it, which, subsequently, causes the MAC verification to fail. This action prevents the request from being committed to the RPMB. The adversary is then able to forward the initial request and intercept its status. The memory contents are updated without notification to the host. The second vulnerability allows the host to believe a portion of the data was, in fact, written. However, a different piece of data was written than initially thought. The attacker could cause the host to lose state, such as cutting power. The uncommitted write is kept with the attacker. Once online again, the host may attempt to issue an authenticated data write request to the previous location with different data. The attacker could intercept the new request and, instead, forward the old request.

instruction: What is QR Codes Delivering Malicious Chrome Extension
output: Here is an overview on QR Codes Delivering Malicious Chrome Extension: This G Data blog post analyzes the malware being distributed on Twitter via QR codes. These QR codes are being advertised as links to pirated software and games. In reality, these QR codes lead to download sites for an ISO file, which the user is encouraged to download. The ISO file contains two components. The first is an encrypted PowerShell script, which downloads a malicious chrome extension and installs it on the victim machine. The second is an executable file that decrypts the PowerShell script and installs it as a scheduled task which runs every ten minutes. The executable also shows an error message to the user to trick them into thinking the installation of their pirated software failed. The chrome extension is highly obfuscated and seems to be serving advertisements to victims, which are fetched from the C2 server every thirty minutes. The malware also hijacks search requests made to popular search engines. Evert three hours, metrics on the user's activity are sent to the C2 server. This appears to be the only functionality so far, but the analyst speculates that the loader could be used to deliver more destructive malware in the future.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Fake Office 365 Used for Phishing Attacks on C-Suite Targets
output: Sure. Here is a description for Fake Office 365 Used for Phishing Attacks on C-Suite Targets: Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign targeting executives at a variety of organizations. The phishing emails, in most cases, are sent via an RDP service hosted by FireVPS. The body of the email directs a user to click a link in order to prevent their Office365 password from changing. The link leads to a compromised site hosting an Office 365 phishing kit. The URLs used for the phishing kit follow a similar pattern. The phishing kit logs any entered credentials to be retrieved by the attackers. The researchers identified a few phishing kits that were misconfigured, allowing them to view the content of the log files, which included potential attribution information regarding the developer of the phishing kit. Investigating the phishing kit developer, they discovered the kit being advertised and sold on Facebook with the earliest version being released in July 2019. During the course of their research, they also identified credentials of C-level users being sold on both English- and Russian-speaking forums.

instruction: Explain: Joker Malware Found on the AppGallery App Store
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Joker Malware Found on the AppGallery App Store:

Doctor Web has published a blog post detailing their findings related to the Joker malware being hosted in Huawei's AppGallery. The Joker malware has been around since late 2019 and is delivered via trojanized Android applications. The researchers identified 10 different applications containing the malware with two unique developers distributing them. Keyboard, cameras, launchers, messengers, games, and more were trojanized. The application functions as expected, which increases the amount of time to discover the malicious activity. The malicious code that is added to these applications is minimal and is primarily responsible for downloading additional modules. Once installed, Joker connects to its C2 server in order to retrieve the configuration and additional components. The main purpose of this variant of Joker is to subscribe users to premium mobile services. It does this via a hidden browser window and intercepts SMS messages in order to obtain required subscription confirmation codes. Furthermore, Joker exfiltrates copies of all incoming SMS messages. Huawei has removed the identified applications from AppGallery.

instruction: Explain: Further on CacheFlow
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Further on CacheFlow:

Reported in December 2020, CacheFlow was a campaign that used a number of malicious browser extensions for the Chrome and Edge web browsers. The campaign was named CacheFlow by researchers from Avast. A new report from Avast provides further technical details on the campaign, which resulted in more than three million installs of the malicious plugins. The plugins were available through the Google and Microsoft stores, and were deleted from them in December. CacheFlow employed a number of techniques to avoid discovery and is thought to have operated since 2017. Once one of the malicious extensions was installed, the operators could gather information about the victim, redirect the victim to URLs of their choosing, and install other malware.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Telegram Utilized for Harvesting Credentials?
output: Cofense published a blog post analyzing the use of the Telegram API in a recent phishing campaign. The initial phishing email spoofs an internal support address and claims that there are emails that have been blocked and need to be manually reviewed. When a user clicks the link, they are redirected to a webmail phishing page customized based on the domain of the victim email address. The most interesting aspect of this campaign is that entering credentials leads to a POST request to the legitimate Telegram API. The attackers can then retrieve the email credentials from their Telegram account. After their credentials are exfiltrated, victims are redirected to the domain associated with their email.

instruction: Tell me about Enterprises Targeted by Hundreds of Compromised Accounts
output:
Certainly.
Enterprises Targeted by Hundreds of Compromised Accounts

Using a document delivery method, threat actors are targeting enterprises with already compromised accounts to further their foothold into these enterprises. The attackers are sending rapid-fire emails to organizations using businesses such as eFax to make these emails more personalized. Included in the emails are embedded links to previously unseen Microsoft Office365 domains used in phishing campaigns. These pages are hosted on sites just as Joom, Weebly, and Quip. Should an attacker's email be detected, the actors run a script to change the attack to a new impersonated sender and phishing link. This allows the attackers to continue the campaign unabated. This type of campaign is set up to avoid and bypass detection methods traditionally employed by large corporations. By using known accounts, this allows attackers into networks that would otherwise be stopped at the firewall, mail filters, or IDS/IPS points. Should an employee click on the document included in the email, they are taken to an Office365 landing page that impersonates a legitimate login page from where the attackers can harvest credentials. Since the attackers are using a constantly-changing landing page, detection of this attack has proven problematic. There have been systems that have been able to detect and stop these attacks.

instruction:
Given the description:
Emotet has had multiple sightings beginning on November 14, 2021 that it has returned to being an active threat. Emotet is a trojan whose capabilities include information stealing, network propagation, and the installation of additional malware. It is commonly spread via maliciously crafted emails or email attachments. Emotet originated as a banking Trojan and information stealer, however many variants of it have surfaced over the years and it is more recently used as a Dropper or Downloader for other malware, such as Trickbot. Upon execution, Emotet collects information about the infected system, such as the hostname and a list of running processes. This data is then encrypted using a combination of AES and RSA, and sent to one of the C2 server IPs which are hardcoded into the Emotet binary. The C2 server will then use the gathered information to determine what response or additional malware to send back. The C2 may also choose not to respond if it detects analysis tools on the system. This latest version is now using encrypted HTTPS instead of unencrypted HTTP for it's post-infection C2 communications.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Emotet Returns After Nearly 10 Month Hiatus

instruction: Explain: Yanluowang Ransomware Is Now Code-Signed
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Yanluowang Ransomware Is Now Code-Signed:

Trend Micro has discovered samples of the new ransomware known as "Yanluowang", which are code-signed with a valid signature. This ransomware was recently discovered and seems to be targeting US corporations from at least August 2021. It is currently unknown how this ransomware initially infects systems, but Trend Micro speculates that it would be executed via RDP, due to the requirement for certain arguments upon execution. The fact that these samples are code-signed allows the ransomware to appear legitimate to the victim's machine, enabling it to bypass some security measures. Upon execution, the ransomware encrypts files in specified filepaths before dropping the ransomware note. It also terminates processes associated with managing and backing up databases using the Windows API. Finally, it forcefully terminates any virtual machines that are running on the host.

instruction:
Given the description:
Although it has been around since 2018, a SANS ISC researcher has identified a recent version of the vjw0rm malware using new obfuscation techniques to avoid detection. The script was discovered being delivered by a phishing campaign. To perform obfuscation, a malicious data blob is passed to a custom decoding function. The malicious blob is comprised of a string of Unicode characters and the function translates each of the character codes of those characters to ASCII characters. Decoding part of the blob reveals some plaintext, such as a Registry key containing the string "vjw0rm," indicating this is a sample of the vjw0rm malware. Once on a system this worm connects to a C2 server from which it can receive a variety of commands. Additionally, its worming functionality allows it to spread across removable drives. For more information, see the SANS ISC blog post in the Reference section.

X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers used the information provided in the SANS ISC post to identify over a dozen additional samples and a few other C2 servers tied to this variant of the vjw0rm malware.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: Describe the following: New AdLoad Campaign Undetected by XProtect
output: SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the most recent AdLoad samples, which have been updated to evade Apple's defense systems. AdLoad is an adware loader targeting macOS system that has evolved since its appearance in late 2019. The dropper for AdLoad masquerades as an Adobe Flash Player update in the form of a .app file mounted as a DMG. Many of these files are signed with a valid signature or even notarized by Apple, assisting in its ability to evade detection. Once on the system, AdLoad establishes persistence via the user's LaunchAgents folder and, if privileges are obtained, via a launchd job. A Zsh script is used during the installation process to execute the final payload from the /tmp directory. As of right now, Apple's existing XProtect signatures do not detect this variant of AdLoad.

instruction: Tell me about Attempts to Exploit Spring4Shell to Deploy Cryptominers
output:
Certainly.
Attempts to Exploit Spring4Shell to Deploy Cryptominers

A report that provides an analysis of an attempt to exploit the Spring4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2022-22965) to install cryptominers has been published by Trend Micro. If the exploitation attempt is successful, a webshell is deployed which is then used to install a cryptominer. The execution flow depends on the operating system of the exploited computer. If it is a Windows machine, a PowerShell script is downloaded and executed. The script carries out a number of operations including disabling the firewall, killing other cryptominers, stopping processes listening on ports 3333, 4444, 5555, 7777, and 9000, and then downloading and executing the cryptominer binary in a hidden window. If the exploited system is running Linux, a shell script is used to kill other cryptominers, then download and deploy the cryptomining binary.

instruction: Tell me about The LockBit Exfiltration Tool - StealBit
output:
Certainly.
The LockBit Exfiltration Tool - StealBit

StealBit is a specialized exfiltration tool that was developed and is maintained by, the LockBit ransomware group. It is provided to affiliates of the LockBit ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation. It is used by the LockBit affiliates to exfiltrate data from systems prior to them being encrypted for double extortion purposes. Older versions of StealBit would not execute on systems located in former Soviet countries but the more recent versions will execute on systems regardless of their location. StealBit uses the Microsoft input/output (I/O) completion port threading model, interprocess communication (IPC) between multiple StealBit processes running on the same host, and parallelizes the exfiltration of multiple files to keep exfiltration time to a minimum. It has a GUI which supports dragging and dropping of files or folders that have been chosen for exfiltration. As Cybereason notes in the report StealBit is also incomplete as some advertised features were not present in some samples, and it also has bugs. For example, one sample failed to properly hide windows created by StealBit and does not compress the exfiltrated files.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Active CVE-2020-0688 Exploit Affects Over 247,000 Microsoft Exchange Servers?
output: BleepingComputer warns that over 247,000 Microsoft Exchange Servers on the Internet have not had the February update to address a remote code execution vulnerability, CVE-2020-0688. The issues resides in the Exchange Control Panel code, which is enabled by default, and could allow an attacker to gain control of the server if successfully exploited. In a survey of Exchange servers on the Internet, Rapid7 found 405,873 Exchange servers with 61% (247,986) still vulnerable to CVE-2020-0688. They also discovered 16,577 Exchange 2007 servers, which are no longer being supported by Microsoft, that were vulnerable as well.

instruction:
Given the description:
OpenSUpdater is a family of what Google's Threat Analysis Group describes as unwanted software. It is used to inject ads into a victim's browser and can also install other software. According to their report, OpenSUpdater samples frequently use a code signing certificate obtained from a legitimate authority. In mid-August however, OpenSUpdater samples were observed which use a malformed certificate, most likely to help evade detection. The X.509 certificate used is modified by replacing a NULL tag in the 'parameters' element of the SignatureAlgorithm with an End of Content (EOC) marker. Windows accepts the certificate as legitimate but OpenSSL will reject it as invalid. This means that security products which use OpenSSL to decoded or check the certificate may be unable to do so. Since the technique was first observed, the actor has tried other invalid encodings to avoid detection. The report notes that there does not appear to be any specific targeting but victims are typically located in the United States and who download game cracks and grey-area software.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Malformed Certs Used to Bypass Detection

instruction: Provide an overview for: New Version of Taurus Stealer Gets Analyzed
output: Sure. Here is a description for New Version of Taurus Stealer Gets Analyzed: A new version of the Taurus information stealer has been analyzed by Blueliv. The latest version has started encrypting all exfiltrated data. The stealer has anti-CIS, anti-C2 modification, and anti-VM (aka anti-sandbox) checks in place before it will continue to run as intended. The anti-CIS part means it will not run if it assumes the machine is operating in a country belonging to the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), which it does by checking the language identifier of the infected machine. Data that it steals comes from cryptocurrency wallets, Outlook data, Credential Manager information from Windows Vault, VPN configurations, two-factor authentication software, games, screen capture, and browser data, which includes browser history, cookies, and login data.

instruction: Tell me about State of Texas Impersonation
output:
Certainly.
State of Texas Impersonation

Abnormal Security has published a report of a recent phishing campaign impersonating Texas government agencies. The initial email spoofs the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) and claims to be a request for quotation (RFQ). The researchers note that this email was sent via a VPN service to hide the identity of the attacker. Replies to the email will not be sent to the spoofed DSHS address but instead will be sent to a domain masquerading as the NYC government. The body contains a message requesting a quote for laptops and hard drives along with a PDF containing fake details. The delivery address is left as TBD presumably in an attempt to social engineer the recipient into requesting it. The goal of the attack is to convince the recipient to send the laptops and hard drives to the attacker without payment who would then sell the stolen goods for a profit.

instruction:
Given the description:
Sentinal Labs has been tracking the ransomware LockBit and discovered some previously unseen behavior. The ransomware uses a legitimate VMware utility to load Cobalt Strike. The utility, VMwareXferlogs.exe, is used to transfer data to and from VMX logs and is vulnerable to DLL side-loading. LockBit has been seen using PowerShell to download the utility, a DLL file, and an encrypted Cobalt Strike loader. The DLL is a copy of a legitimate DLL, with only one desired function working properly. The malicious DLL is able to evade detection by bypassing event tracing and removing userland hooks, allowing it to decrypt the cobalt strike payload.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: What is Vidar Infostealer Spread Via Malicious Windows 11 ISO Files
output: Here is an overview on Vidar Infostealer Spread Via Malicious Windows 11 ISO Files: ZScaler ThreatLabz has discovered a new campaign spreading the Vidar infostealer. The researchers found newly registered domains that were spoofing the official Microsoft Windows 11 OS download portal. From these sites, the victims could download fake Windows 11 ISO files which are very large, and so can evade network security products. These files are signed with an expired certificate that is likely stolen during the 2019 AVAST compromise. The Vidar samples seen in this campaign are all packed with Themida and are very large in size, as they have been artificially inflated with padding bytes. The malware uses hardcoded URLs as dead drop resolvers, which directs them to various social media accounts on Telegram and Mastadon that host legitimate binaries for credential and data harvesting.

instruction: Explain: New Malware Set Identified Used by the SolarWinds Attackers
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for New Malware Set Identified Used by the SolarWinds Attackers:

FireEye has discovered a new sophisticated second-stage backdoor that is possibly connected to UNC2452, the same group believed to be behind the attacks against SolarWinds. Microsoft refers to the group as NOBELIUM. One notable feature available in this malware is the option to use decoy network traffic by mixing legitimate traffic with C2 queries. The initial vector used to deploy this backdoor has not yet been determined, but it's suspected to be a second-stage backdoor dropped after an initial compromise. FireEye has named the malware as SUNSHUTTLE, Microsoft named it GoldMax. The backdoor is capable of remotely updating its configuration, file upload/download, and arbitrary command execution.

instruction:
Given the description:
A new RAT has been observed by Cybereason's Nocturnus team. The RAT, PyVil RAT is being distributed by the cyber group, Evilnum. The group has been active for at least the past two years using a variety of tools. The group has historically targeted the Financial Technology industry and uses the Know Your Customer procedure to begin infection. Included in the new malware are deviations from the infection chain, persistence, infrastructure, and tools observed including modified, legitimate executables, a multi-process delivery of the payload, and the PyVil RAT. The new infection chain begins with spearphishing emails with attached ZIP archives containing LNK files, which drop a JavaScript Trojan. The attached files masquerade as utility bills, credit card photos, and driver license photos. Upon execution, a JavaScript file is written and executed which, in turn, replaces the LNK file with a PDF. This JavaScript is merely a dropper and has no C2 communication capabilities. This is but the first step in the new infection chain that culminates with the delivery of the PyVil RAT. After the PDF is placed, the JS file is copied which leads to the execution of ddpp.exe embedded in the LNK file. A registry key is entered for persistence and a scheduled task is created. The scheduled task is responsible for retrieving payloads. The executable ddpp.exe is a Java Web Start Launcher that has been trojanized to execute malicious code. The functionality of ddpp.exe is that of a downloader for next stage infection. From this point, shellcode is unpacked and connects to a C2 using a GET request. The malware downloads another encrypted executable, saved as fplayer.exe, which is then executed with a new scheduled task. This downloaded executable acts as an additional downloader. The payload is loaded into memory and is a fileless RAT. Again, at this point, the file is executed with a scheduled task named "Adobe Update Task." Several arguments are executed with this EXE file. This particular file appears to be a trojanized version of "Stereoscopic 3D driver Installer." When this file is executed, further shellcode is unpacked and connects to the C2 via a GET request. A final payload is received, which is the PyVil RAT. This RAT is heavily obfuscated to prevent decompiling the payload. The RAT has several functions such as: keylogger, running cmd commands, taking screenshots, obtaining more Python scripts, dropping and unloading executables among others. C2 communications are accomplished by POST HTTP requests and are RC4 encrypted with hardcoded keys. The C2 domain changes frequently but appears to resolve to the same three IP addresses.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Evilnum Group Releases PyVil RAT

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for ICS-CERT Security Advisories - November 24th, 2020?
output:
ICS-CERT has released two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related devices and software.

ICSA-20-329-01 addresses three vulnerabilities in Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk Linx, two heap-based buffer overflow vulnerabilities and an improper input validation vulnerability. If successfully exploited, potential impacts include denial-of-service conditions, remote code execution, or information leakage.

ICSA-20-329-02 addresses an out-of-bounds write vulnerability in Fuji Electric V-Server Lite. If successfully exploited, an attacker may be able to remotely execute arbitrary code.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for New Mirai Like Malware - Krane?
output: Krane is new malware, discovered and named by CUJO AI. Krane attempts to exploit systems by brute-forcing SSH passwords. If access is obtained to a system, Krane attempts to execute a download script that uses wget to download two main packages which are placed in hidden directories. One of the packages is named krax, it's responsible for cleaning up any pre-existing instances of Krane, deleting and recreating log files to hide activity, and executing a binary file which is an XMRig cryptominer variant. The other package is referred to as ssh, it contains one of the files, krane, that is also found in the first package, and another file named sshd. The sshd file is a bash script that is used as a secondary downloader. One of the packages downloaded by sshd is used to scan a range of IP addresses for hosts running SSH-2.0-OpenSSH that may be vulnerable to brute-force attacks, and if found, attempt to exploit them. This activity is carried out using a combination of bash and Python scripts. The IP address used for the C&C server is hardcoded in a configuration file.

instruction: Describe the following: Web Scrapers Using Facebook's Link Preview Feature
output: DataDome has published a blog detailing a POC about how the Facebook Crawler could be hijacked by threat actors to gather information on webpages used in the preview link function of Messenger and many other platforms. Since Facebook is a large consumer of user traffic, there are many threat actors seeking to use the whitelisting of the Facebook Crawler to extract large amounts of data from websites disguised as Facebook. The hijacking is done via providing a token linked to a Facebook account. Web scrapers could make thousands of requests per minute and many performed that action. Messenger, like many other platforms, provides a preview of links within the program using the Messenger preview API. The data presented in these previews could contain information about the pages purporting to be Facebook since the request is sent as FACEBOOK AS. The reverse DNS shows the IP address as that belonging to Facebook regardless of the actual IP address of the preview. The requestor could test product availability or presence, which could be of importance to sneaker bot operators as well as scalper bots. This technique has been seen in the wild by the DataDome researchers. The API used showed the data call came from Facebook rather than the scalper or other bot being used for the nefarious purposes.

instruction: Explain: An Usual Technique Used by an APT
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for An Usual Technique Used by an APT:

A report from Trend Micro shines some light on an unusual technique they describe as sophisticated. The investigation was triggered by the execution of an unusual command, "schtasks /create /tn <name> c:\programdata\<software name>\<file name>.bat /sc /once /st <time> /ru <user account>". The command was unusual because it was not to create persistence, nor did it appear to relate to privilege escalation, and it executed a .bat file. Eventually, it was found that the unusual command was traced back to a PlugX infection. The scheduled task was created and the .bat file was one of two files dropped onto the system. The second file which is executed by the .bat file was a tool used to gather information.

One of more popular open-source PBX environments, Asterisk, has published two security advisories (AST-2020-003 and AST-2020-004) detailing issues corrected in their latest release. instruction: Can you please give me and overview for IBM QRadar SIEM is Vulnerable to an Authorization Bypass?
output: The version of Google APIs google-oauth-java-client used by IBM QRadar SIEM could allow a remote attacker to bypass security restrictions. This vulnerability is caused by a lack of PKCE support. An attacker could use a specially-crafted application to obtain the authorization code and potentially bypass security restrictions. Versions of QRadar 7.3 and 7.4 are affected by the vulnerability. Updates to address the vulnerability are available.

instruction: Describe the following: Declassifying UNC1945
output: Based on a Mandiant report, Yoroi decided to declassify information about the group UNC1945 (Mandiant label) in their own report. Yoroi identifies the group with the term TH-239. UNC1945 uses a Linux QEMU virtual machine with all of the tools needed to achieve its goals. The version of Linux bundled for the attack is Tinycore Linux 7.2. This distribution is about four years old but was seen being used in attacks during 2020. Inside the disk image, three directories stand out - "deploy", "python", and "responder". The deploy directory contains a number of tools designed to attack various kinds of machines. The python directory contains various exploits written in the Python language. Some of the exploits include EternalBlue, EternalChampion, EternalSynergy, and EternalRomance. The responder directory contains a tool that listens on the network for NetBIOS Name Service and Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution broadcasts for hostnames. It is used to steal NTLMv1/v2 password hashes.

instruction: Describe the following: Unknown Threat Group Using Hades Ransomware
output: Accenture has published their analysis of the Hades ransomware, which they identified as part of attacks against three multi-national organizations since December 2020. It is unknown whether this ransomware is operated by a single threat actor or distributed under an affiliate model. During incidents involving Hades, Accenture observed highly targeted, "hands on keyboard" activity. Initial access appears to have been obtained via public-facing systems via RDP or VPN with legitimate credentials. Once on the network, the threat actors used Cobalt Strike and Empire for persistence and lateral movement. As with many ransomware families, it deletes shadow copies, traverses local directories and network shares to identify files to be encrypted, encrypts files and adds an extension, and leaves a ransom note. The ransom note includes a unique URL for a TOR site to pay the ransom. Hades also leverages the double-extortion model, which involves exfiltrating sensitive files as a secondary method of extortion, threatening to release these files publicly if the victim does not pay the ransom.

instruction: Explain: Evolution of Fake Alert and Technical Support Scams
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Evolution of Fake Alert and Technical Support Scams:

As the Sophos article states, "For nearly as long there have been web advertising networks, there have been malicious web ads." A lot of work has been accomplished by browser vendors to protect the user, but there are still unscrupulous ad networks that do not monitor or restrict what is being sent to the user. Some ads use a "pop-under" technique to bypass any "pop-up" restrictions that the browser may have employed. These "pop-under" techniques may deploy JavaScript or Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) features to convince the user their system has a real problem that only the contents of the ad can resolve. Technical support calls of the past, where a potential victim was cold-called over the phone, have evolved to use web pages, maliciously designed, that pull the victim to the fake call center for "assistance with their problem". It isn't just the desktop being attacked, either. Mobile devices have similar attack patterns. Ads on mobile devices may lead to tech support scams or to PUAs (Potentially Unwanted Applications). The PUAs may even reside in Google's or Apple's app stores because there's no real malicious code within the app to trigger anti-malware detection software.

instruction: What is Palmerworm Targets the Media, Finance, and Other Sectors
output: Here is an overview on Palmerworm Targets the Media, Finance, and Other Sectors: Symantec has published a report on recent Palmerworm (aka BlackTech) attacks. Their main targets are media, construction, engineering, electronics, and finance organizations in Japan, Taiwan, the U.S., and China. The initial infection vector of the attacks analyzed for this blog post is unknown, but Palmerworm has been known to use spear-phishing emails in the past. Once on a victim network the group leveraged dual-use tools and custom malware. In terms of the dual-use tools, they were seen leveraging Putty for remote access and data exfiltration, PSExec for lateral movement, SNScan for network reconnaissance, and WinRAR for file compression and extraction. Custom tools seen in use during this campaign were backdoors not previously seen. Symantec has named these backdoors Consock, Waship, Dalwit, and Nomri. While the group sometimes maintained access to victim environments for several months, they also observed the group spend only a couple days in a network. Attribution to Palmerworm is based on code similarities with the malware, shared infrastructure, use of the same tools, and targeting.

instruction: Tell me about Attack Campaign Using DLL Side-Loading Triad, FoundCore
output:
Certainly.
Attack Campaign Using DLL Side-Loading Triad, FoundCore

Kaspersky's researchers, observed an attack campaign operating between August 2020 and January 2021 that used the DLL side-loading triad known as FoundCore (Remote Administration Tool, RAT). Initial infection is believed to have been carried out using spearphishing emails which led to downloading malicious RTF files. Other malware discovered included DropPhone (RAT) and CoreLoader (shellcode loader). The attacks were largely targeting Vietnam's government and military sectors. Kaspersky attribute the campaign, with low confidence, to the Cycldek APT group. Cycldek is also known as Goblin Panda and tracked by IBM X-Force as Hive0045.

instruction: Provide an overview for: The Many Faces of Gozi
output: Sure. Here is a description for The Many Faces of Gozi: Originally a small banking Trojan, Gozi has undergone massive changes in the number of variants available to threat actors. Operating continuously since 2007, Gozi has infected millions of machines and done untold damage to all types of industries and users. At its core, Gozi variants carry similar traits across the board. Some of the similarities between versions are strings contained within the binary's .bss section, man-in-the-browser attack, specific C2 check-in format, obfuscation of the C2 check-in, keylogging, email, FTP, IM accounts data and certificate grabbing, among others. Some of the specific strains carry differences that could easily be overlooked as most of the functionality of the RAT remains the same across the board. Goziat, an older variant, makes use of built-in Windows utilities and uses a different resource directory instead of the standard "images" directory. This can be configured during the build phase. Additionally, this variant typically targets .at top-level domains. Another variant, Gozi2RM3 or Gozi IAP2.0, has changes to the C2 structure. Communication is set in two stages. Stage 1 contains a hardcoded C2 in the initial infection binary. An ISP/geolocation deny list is also employed to pre-filter connections that could be researchers. Once the first stage is passed, the second stage pushes the main payload and true configuration. There appears to be a connection between Goziat and Gozi2RM3. Both variants use additional encryption steps by adding a serpent key in addition to the server's RSA key. Goziv3 RM3 targets mostly Australia, Italy, and the U.S. Some significant differences between this version include the use of a PX format, WD structure as opposed to Joined Resources (JJ), a word list is kept in one of the WD structs for generation of registry key names, the use of forfiles.exe for APC injection, and the communications method uses the request body instead of the URI for check-in. As with Gozi2RM3, a geofencing solution is in place. This particular variant has been bundled with a loader used by Emotet and Dridex. There are several variants of Gozi which have become unused. These include Dreambot, Saigon, and ISFB3/Ursnif-A. It's easy to mistake one strain of Gozi for another; however, with the differences pointed out, triage and analysis should help to identify which strain of malware is presented.

instruction: Explain: Adobe Security Updates May 2021 -  Acrobat and Reader Vulnerability Exploited in the Wild
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Adobe Security Updates May 2021 -  Acrobat and Reader Vulnerability Exploited in the Wild:

Adobe has released twelve security updates. The updates are for Acrobat and Reader, After Effects, Animate, Creative Cloud Desktop Application, Experience Manager, Genuine Service, Illustrator, InCopy, InDesign, Magento, Media Encoder, and Medium. Ten of the updates address at least one vulnerability rated by Adobe as Critical. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-28550) addressed in the Acrobat and Reader updates is reported as having been exploited in the wild. The vulnerability could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code.

instruction: Explain: Android Trojan Targets Banking Users In Malaysia
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Android Trojan Targets Banking Users In Malaysia:

Cyble published a blog post analyzing a banking Trojan targeting Malaysian users. The malware masquerades as an Android booking application for a Malaysian cleaning company. Once on the device various intrusive permissions are requested, with the RECEIVE_SMS permissions being heavily abused in particular. The payload abuses this permission to listen for incoming messages and upload any that are received to a C2 server. Additionally, the fake application is designed to steal victim data. It uses the cleaner booking application theme to request payment details, specifically via online banking. Navigating to the payment screen provides victims with a list of Malaysian banks to choose from. Selecting a bank then leads to a fake version of its login page. Any entered credentials are subsequently exfiltrated to the attacker.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for DarkRadiation Ransomware?
output: Trend Micro has published a blog post analyzing a new Bash ransomware, dubbed "DarkRadiation." This ransomware was discovered hosted in an attacker's hack tools directory alongside other Bash scripts used in the infection chain. Victims are initially compromised via SSH by a Bash script that operates as an SSH worm that uses compromised credentials or brute force tactics. Various tools from the hack tools URL are downloaded to the system, including rootkits, reconnaissance tools, obfuscators, exploits, and more. The attacker's ultimate goal is to execute a ransomware payload. Both the worm and the ransomware payload include Telegram C2 communication capabilities to notify the attacker of successful infections and encryption. The ransomware waits for the presence of a specified file on the hack tool server before beginning encryption. Once the file is observed, AES with CBC mode encryption is performed against various directories. A ransom note is left on the system requesting the victim contact the attackers by email. Based on the use of Yellowdog Updater, Modified (YUM) package manager to install prerequisite packages, the worm and ransomware are currently designed to target CentOS, RHEL, and Debian-based Linux distributions. Shortly after Trend Micro's publication, SentinelOne released their analysis of the payload, also noting indications of targeting of Docker containers.

instruction: Tell me about Gafgyt Using Pulse Secure Vulnerability
output:
Certainly.
Gafgyt Using Pulse Secure Vulnerability

Avira Labs has observed an increase in IoT malware binaries. These binaries have the capability to exploit CVE-2020-8218. This increase led to the discovery of a new variant of Gafgyt. Its functionality is mostly the same as the original Gafgyt with some inclusion of functionality from other malware families. One such family is Tsunami and its use of DNS amplification, which is incorporated into this new variant. The threat actors have included multiple architectures in an effort to deploy this malware to as many different types of processors as possible, thus widening their potential footprint and success rate. The malware attempts to print "bigB04t" using an API call. Gafgyt then attempts to prevent the affected device from restarting by manipulating the watchdog. The payload of the malware is downloaded from the IP addresses located in the IoC section below. The vulnerability itself allows an unauthenticated user to run arbitrary code remotely. This requires administrative privileges but can be accomplished through a malicious link clicked by an administrator.

instruction: Explain: Cracked Software Being Used as Victim Bait
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Cracked Software Being Used as Victim Bait:

Users searching for cracked software are the targets of some Malware as a Service (MaaS) offerings that provide droppers that deliver multiple payloads. SEO techniques are used to promote links in search results that point to a bait page, the bait pages have typically been hosted on WordPress sites. The bait pages have a download button for the cracked software the victim was seeking. If the button is clicked, the request is passed through intermediary sites which carry out a number of checks such as operating system and geolocation are carried out, with the victim finally being provided a download link which leads to the dropper. The dropper is usually contained in a password-protected .zip file which is contained in another .zip file along with a text file that contains the password to decrypt the dropper .zip file. The droppers can deliver multiple payloads which Sophos have observed to include clickfraud bots, cryptomminers, information stealers, and the Conti and STOP ransomware.

instruction: Describe the following: An Analysis of RedLine Stealer
output: RedLine Stealer is an infostealer malware that is currently the largest contributor of stolen information being sold on Russian-speaking sites on the dark web. Researchers from Insikt Group at Recorded Future have analyzed the malware and published a comprehensive report on the malware's capabilities. The infostealer has been distributed since early 2020 by a group known as "REDGlade" or "Glade". According to these actors, there are two subscription licenses available - a lifetime license for 800 dollars, or monthly service for 150 dollars. This malware is normally distributed via phishing emails, as well as over social media. It has also been found masquerading as legitimate programs, including as an installer for Telegram. Once installed, the malware can perform a wide array of functions. At its core, it can steal usernames, passwords, cookies, saved credentials, and credit card information from browsers. It can also gather files from cryptocurrency cold wallets and other locations. Beyond that, RedLine Stealer is capable of performing basic download and execute functions, meaning it can be used as a loader in a multi-stage attack. RedLine is being continually developed by a competent C# developer, and so new versions of this malware are being released regularly. The volume of advertisements for log information stolen by this malware has increased over the past year, which corresponds to the increase in interest across many dark web sources.

instruction: Tell me about AR20-268A - Federal Agency Compromised by Malicious Cyber Actor
output:
Certainly.
AR20-268A - Federal Agency Compromised by Malicious Cyber Actor

CISA responded to a cyberattack against a federal agency in which a threat actor established persistent remote access to the victim environment. Initial access was obtained using Microsoft O365 credentials. The stolen credentials were used to log into a user's O365 account which was then used to download a file from a SharePoint site. The actor also connected to the organization's VPN server, which CISA believes may have been done via exploitation of CVE-2019-11510, a Pulse Secure VPN vulnerability. Reconnaissance activities included searching emails and files, using Windows command line tools to map the network and system, and enumerating Active Directory and Group Policy. Persistence is established via a few methods including a SSH tunnel/reverse SMB SOCKS proxy, a multistage malware, and a locally mounted remote share. The SSH tunnel and SOCKS proxy had related scheduled tasks created to ensure that the machine would be reinfected if needed. Exfiltration of data from an account directory and server directory was performed using tsclient. The possibility of further exfiltration exists based on the fact the actor collected files and directories inside a ZIP archive.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Western Digital My Cloud NAS Devices Security Vulnerabilities
output: Sure. Here is a description for Western Digital My Cloud NAS Devices Security Vulnerabilities: Comparitech researches have published a paper on five vulnerabilities found in Western Digital network-attached storage (NAS) devices. If successfully exploited, the exploitation of these vulnerabilities could lead to remote code execution. Also possible is the ability to compromise data and files on a vulnerable device or allow the installation of malware on the device. An update for the device has been available since late October. A process to automatically update vulnerable devices is not present, so owners must manually apply the firmware update.

instruction: Provide an overview for: New Technique Used by Attackers in NPM to Avoid Detection
output: Sure. Here is a description for New Technique Used by Attackers in NPM to Avoid Detection: Checkmarx researchers have encountered a number of packages exhibiting the technique of utilizing the Node package manager (NPM} for offensive cyber operations. The technique uses packages constructed by the attackers which have a low major version number, and minor and patch version numbers being high. The objective is to cause dependency confusion which may lead to the attacker's packages being installed by NPM. The attacker's goal is to exfiltrate all the victim machine’s environment variables to the attacker via a webhook of the legitimate service “pipedream”.

instruction: What is Geopolitical Situation Update: ITG09 Activity Surrounding the South China Sea
output: Here is an overview on Geopolitical Situation Update: ITG09 Activity Surrounding the South China Sea: Between 2019 and late-2020, ITG09 targeted global entities associated with key Chinese geostrategic interests, especially those affiliated with economic prospects in the South China Sea. In addition, ITG09 expanded activity to include targeting of unique unmanned underwater technologies and upgraded their techniques to include cloud services and open source techniques to increase obfuscation. It is highly likely ITG09 activity will continue for the foreseeable future given its consistent operational tempo and technical evolution, combined with China’s regional state ambitions. IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has released a report providing an overview of recent ITG09 activities and predictions on future activity.

instruction: Describe the following: SolarMarker SEO Campaigns
output: The SolarMarker malware, also known as Jupyter and Polazert, is an information stealer that emerged in 2020. A report from Sophos provides an analysis of SolarMarker and SEO campaigns that were used to distribute it throughout 2021. The SEO operations were, according to Sophos, were very effective with the results for their search phrases appearing high in the Google search results. To achieve the results the campaigns used three main methods, web pages and PDF documents hosted on compromised sites, and Google Groups discussions where the campaign operators would create fake conversations with between 500 and 600 entries. From the initial pages, a victim would be redirected to another site that has been known for hosting malware for some years. The victim would eventually be delivered an MSI installer that contained two files, a malicious PowerShell script, and a decoy executable. The decoy file was typically a legitimate installer for Wondershare's PDFelement or Adobe's Acrobat Pro DC. The SolarMarker payload is embedded in the PowerShell script, it is base64-encoded and encrypted. When the script is executed it carries out a number of operations including dropping the payload in the form of a DLL, establishing persistence, and creating a smokescreen directory that contains a large number of randomly named junk files, and a randomly named file which the payload is copied to. An LNK file is used to ultimately begin the process of decrypting the payload which is a DLL and then reflexively loading it.

A report from Sophos provides an analysis of SolarMarker and SEO campaigns that were used to distribute it throughout 2021. The SEO operations were, according to Sophos, were very effective with the results for their search phrases appearing high in the Google search results. To achieve the results the campaigns used three main methods, web pages and PDF documents hosted on compromised sites, and Google Groups discussions where the campaign operators would create fake conversations with between 500 and 600 entries. From the initial pages, a victim would be redirected to another site that has been known for hosting malware for some years. The victim would eventually be delivered an MSI installer that contained two files, a malicious PowerShell script, and a decoy executable. An LNK file is used to ultimately begin the process of decrypting the payload which is a DLL and then reflexively loading it.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Analysis of Kinsing Malware's Use of Rootkit?
output: Trend Micro has published their analysis of a Kinsing malware sample using a rootkit to evade detection. As with most Kinsing infections, a series of shell scripts are used to install the malware. After downloading and installing the backdoor, miner, and rootkit payloads, along with disabling resource-intensive services and processes, the rootkit installation process begins. This process is only able to be performed if the malware has root privileges. First, the immutable file flag from /etc/ld.so.preload is removed. Then the rootkit is downloaded onto the system and a new /etc/[ld.so](http://ld.so).preload file is created with a link to the rootkit. Without root privileges, persistence is established via a system service. Additionally, a cron job is created so that the installation script is repeatedly downloaded and executed. The rootkit, once installed, provides a variety of functions to hide malicious activity, such as hiding files, running processes, and active network connections. With this in place, the attacker can carry out their backdoor and mining activities with a decreased risk of detection.

instruction: Describe the following: Remcos RAT Delivered via Visual Basic
output: Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the most recent tactics being used by the Remcos RAT. The threat actors are still leveraging ZIP and IMG attachments on financially-themed malspam emails as an initial infection vector. These archives, however, now contain a Visual Basic script instead of an executable file. This script kicks off an infection chain that involves multiple stages of PowerShell downloading and executing additional obfuscated VB scripts. The final script is responsible for injecting an embedded PE file into aspnet_compiler.exe. The executable is the Remcos RAT, which provides its operator with the ability to fully control the victim system and steal sensitive information. The various Visual Basic scripts were all hosted on the legitimate Archive.org to evade detection. Additionally, all samples of the final payload called back to an IP address and port, but no C2 communication was observed.

instruction: Tell me about Google Play Apps That Delivered Out of Context Ads
output:
Certainly.
Google Play Apps That Delivered Out of Context Ads

Malicious apps can make their way onto the Google Play store if they manage to bypass security protocols. A number of apps that used various versions of the Tencent Legu packer to hide their malicious code were discovered on the Play store by the White Ops Satori Threat Intelligence and Research Team. The number of apps discovered exceeded 240 and collectively the apps were downloaded some 14 million times and at peak, the apps generated some 15 million ad impressions, per day. The apps were mainly based on Nintendo (NES) emulators which the authors of the malicious apps obtained from legitimate sources. The ads delivered to the users were made to appear to come from applications and social media platforms such as Youtube and Chrome. The apps tracked the device's screen on and off times in an effort to deliver ads when the user was more likely to see them. Once an app had contacted its C&C server, an ad would be displayed around every 10 minutes. The C&C server located by the White Ops team was running on what appears to be a legitimate, but compromised server. The malicious apps discovered by White Ops have been removed from the Play store.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for SAP Security Patch Day - December 2020?
output: SAP has released a security patch for December that fixes fourteen security vulnerabilities. Issues include a missing authentication check, a missing XML validation, code injection, path traversal, unrestricted file upload, formula injection, missing encryption, cross-site scripting, content spoofing, and an open redirect. Products affected include SAP AS ABAP, SAP BW4HANA, SAP Business Warehouse, SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform, SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform, SAP Disclosure Management, SAP HANA Database, SAP NetWeaver, SAP NetWeaver AS, SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP, SAP NetWeaver Application Server, SAP S4 HANA, SAP Solution Manager, and SAP UI.
