instruction: Provide an overview for: Log4j Exploitation on VMware Horizon Servers
output: Sure. Here is a description for Log4j Exploitation on VMware Horizon Servers: Rapid7 published a blog post analyzing attacks exploiting Log4j vulnerabilities on VMware Horizon servers. The researchers observed five different post-compromise infection chains in such attacks. Most commonly, PowerShell was used to download a Batch or PowerShell script from a remote server. These scripts are then used to install a cryptocurrency miner. The subsequent three post-compromise attack chains also use PowerShell to download a remotely hosted payload. Payloads included a reverse shell, a backdoor, and a Cobalt Strike payload. The final post-compromise activity used Node, a piece of software included with VMware server, to execute JavaScript code for the purpose of establishing a remote shell. Patches have been released by VMware to address the Log4j vulnerabilities and should be installed as soon as possible.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Buer Loader Malware-as-a-Service?
output: Sophos has published a blog post analyzing the Beur loader and its recent appearance in Ryuk campaigns. This loader is offered as malware-as-a-service that offers payloads, C2 hosting, and technical support, as advertised in forum posts. A C2 panel provided by the service allows attackers to deliver files to endpoints and track their successful infections with details about each host. The specific infection chain that the Sophos article focuses on is that observed as part of Ryuk campaigns. The infection chain is relatively similar to those using Emotet or Trickbot's Bazar loader for access instead. A spear phishing email provides a link to a file hosted on a legitimate cloud storage platform, such as Google Docs or Constant Contact. If a user opens the downloaded file, a macro drops an executable on the system. This executable is the packed installer for the Beur loader payload. Once installed, if it passes anti-analysis and regional checks, the loader establishes communication with its C2 server. From this point the attacker can deliver further payloads to the victim system. The Ryuk operators used the loader to first deliver a Cobalt Strike beacon, which, in turn, was used deliver the final ransomware payload. Similar emails that appear to be a part of the same campaign were seen delivering Bazar or ZLoader instead, both of which have been used in Ryuk attacks in the past.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for FIN7 Distributing Windows 11 Alpha-Themed Maldocs?
output: Anomali Threat Research discovered six maldocs using a Windows 11 Alpha release theme. The documents claim to have been created using Windows 11. Anomali attributes the maldocs, with moderate confidence, to the threat group FIN7. Other names associated with FIN7 include Anunak, Carbanak Group, and Carbon Spider. IBM X-Force tracks FIN7 as ITG14. Anomali have not determined the vector used to distribute the maldocs but their analysis provides a strong likelihood the maldocs were attached to spearphishing emails. The maldocs contain Visual Basic macros that when the document is opened, and if macros are enabled, deliver JavaScript payloads. One of the payloads is a JavaScript back door. During the execution of the JavaScript payloads, a number of checks are carried out for criteria such as Eastern European language, the system's available memory, and if the system is running inside a virtual machine. Perhaps the most notable check is for a specific domain (CLEARMIND) that Anomali note appears to be related to a Point-of-Sale (POS) service provider. Depending on the results of the checks, the code may exit without delivering further payloads.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Browser Hijacking Campaign Targets MacOS
output: Sure. Here is a description for Browser Hijacking Campaign Targets MacOS: Crowdstrike has discovered a macOS browser hijacking campaign. The first stage of the campaign uses a DMG file that masquerades as a legitimate file. The user is tricked into mounting this and clicking on the icon to execute a malicious script. The script hides any terminal windows and checks for existing infections. The script then downloads a chrome extension and installs it. It gains persistence by using launch agents which are executed periodically. These are disguised as components of the Chrome browser. The extension contains a hardcoded C2 address and an ID. The extension is built to serve ads to the victims by redirecting a random proportion of user searches to a predetermined site. The extension contains the functionality to remove extensions with conflicting purposes. The researchers also found a variant of this targeting the Safari browser.

instruction: Describe the following: Trickbot and Emotet Delivery Methodology
output: A new phishing campaign is showing Emotet and Trickbot using similar droppers and phishing documents for delivery. Emotet, previously quiet for five months, has begun a new campaign recently with several national governments taking note and issuing warnings of the latest activity. Phishing targets will typically receive an email with a Word document attached. The .DOCX contains an embedded image which hides text. Upon initial inspection, the document appears as though it needs a password to view the obscured image; however, closer examination reveals that increasing the font size and color will show hidden text. Within the hidden text are strings used to run code and, ultimately, download malware. The document contains a macro, which is obfuscated to deter examination. The macro is not triggered through user interaction but is triggered when the document is closed. Once the values are extracted from the Word document, the non-encoded strings are deleted, thus making further reverse-engineering difficult. This type of "one use" scripting is uncommon but is successful. The strings included allow for the download of Trickbot, which is hidden under the guise of a PDF file. It is at this point where Trickbot is executed. These techniques seem to link the two malware families.

instruction:
Given the description:
The Cybereason Incident Response and Nocturnus research teams collaborated on this report. The team analyzed the Winnti malware and was able to provide detail on the deployment chain. Cybereason has named possible attribution to the malware as the Winnti APT Group, a Chinese cyber threat actor. The report describes an updated Winnti malware instance that includes Deplolog. This undocumented malware also includes Spyder Loader, Privatelog, and Winnkit. The initial compromise is with Spyder Loader. This loader has the ability to decrypt files and has protocols against analysis environments and sandboxes. Part of the overall phased approach of Winnkit is to utilize Microsoft’s Common Log File Systems (CLFS) to obfuscate activities.

instruction: Explain: RealTek Vulnerability Exploited
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for RealTek Vulnerability Exploited:

A remote code execution vulnerability has been seen being exploited in the wild according to Juniper Threat Labs. The vulnerability, CVE-2021-35394, was disclosed by IoT Inspector Research Lab. The attack targets Related RTL8xxx SoC chipsets used in wireless routers and other embedded devices. As of this writing all download servers used in the campaign are operational and attacks continue. One particular item of interest is a UDP server running on port 9034. This particular vulnerability was patched in another vulnerability dated 2015, however this patch simply provided a mitigation technique of verification of command strings containing a prefix of "orf". This mitigation technique is ineffective due to the inclusion of the "orf" prefix to any injected command string. By including the "orf" prefix, the command is ingored and a shell script is downloaded, renamed, and executed. Specific architectures targeted are ARM (v5 and v7), MIPS (both big- and little-endian), and SuperH. The executables seen are variants of the Mirai botnet. IP addresses in this campaign overlap with those seen in other campaigns. The previous attacks focuses on HTTP; UDP allows more attacks utilizing fewer resources.

instruction: Tell me about Recent Zoom-Themed Phish
output:
Certainly.
Recent Zoom-Themed Phish

Cofense has published a blog post detailing the most recent in an extensive list of Zoom-themed phishing campaigns. This one uses a highly customized email to create a sense of legitimacy. The sender is spoofed to match the company domain, and mentions of both the recipient's first and last name and the company name are found throughout the email. Recipients are requested to click a link in order to see more details regarding the supposed meeting invite. The final destination of the link is hidden behind a MailChimp redirector URL. The landing page is a fake Microsoft login page hosted on a compromised WordPress site. Submitting credentials will ultimately result in their exfiltration to the attacker.

instruction: Tell me about IBM QRadar Network Security Affected by NTP Vulnerabilities
output:
Certainly.
IBM QRadar Network Security Affected by NTP Vulnerabilities

A Security Bulletin for IBM QRadar Network Security has been published to address vulnerabilities in NTP which could allow for a denial of service condition. The vulnerabilities (CVE-2020-11868 and CVE-2020-13817) could allow a remote attacker to send spoofed packets to an affected device and potentially prevent synchronization, change a device's time, or cause the NTP daemon to crash. QRadar Network Security 5.4.0 and 5.5.0 are affected. Updated versions of firmware, 5.4.0.12 and 5.5.0.7, are available to mitigate the vulnerabilities.

instruction: Tell me about Facebook's Stand Against Chinese Hackers
output:
Certainly.
Facebook's Stand Against Chinese Hackers

Facebook release a blog post about its actions agains Chinese hackers, Earth Empusa or Evil Eye, after observing nefarious actions using the platform as a pseudo-distribution point. The group has previously hacked the accounts of Uyghurs from Xinjiang activists, journalists, and dissidents living abroad in various countries, according to the post. The group's actions have shown all of the familiar signs of a well-resourced and persistent group. Facebook analysts observed the group sending links to malicious websites as opposed to sharing the malware directly on the Facebook platform. The security professionals report that the group is using selective targeting and exploit protection, compromising and impersonating news websites, social engineering, fake, third-party app stores, outsourcing malware development, and industry tracking as part of their research into the hacking group's activities on Facebook.

instruction: Explain: Malicious Ads for Home Depot Being Used in Google Search
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Malicious Ads for Home Depot Being Used in Google Search:

A malvertising campaign has been underway using an ad for Home Depot as a redirect to tech support scams. These types of campaigns are nothing new. Previously, Amazon Prime, PayPal, and eBay have been observed being used in the same type of activity. Threat actors use malicious search ads to point users to a seemingly innocuous result for Home Depot in this case. Upon hovering over the link, the legitimate URL for Home Depot appears and provides the victim with a false sense of security. In their research, Bleeping Computer was able to find the malicious link on the first attempt at doing so. Upon clicking on the link, they were redirected through ad services until they reached a tech support scam website purporting to be "Windows Defender - Security Warning". The scam page opens the Print dialog box which makes closing the web page difficult. In an effort to deter diagnosis of the ads, the scam will only run once every 24 hours, per IP address. Any clicks after the first sends the victim to the legitimate web page. The scam web page contains a phone number the victim is to call to "remedy" the security issue.

instruction: Explain: Samba Security Advisories - October 29th, 2020
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Samba Security Advisories - October 29th, 2020:

Samba published three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in their software.

CVE-2020-14318 is a missing permission check vulnerability in the SMB ChangeNotify concept. If successfully exploited, an attacker with unprivileged access could obtain file name information. CVE-2020-14323 is an improper input validation vulnerability in winbind that, if successfully exploited, could cause a NULL pointer dereference, which would in turn cause a crash. CVE-2020-14383 addresses an error handling vulnerability with the Samba dnsserver RPC pipe that could allow an authenticated, non-admin user to crash a server by adding invalid DNS records.

Samba has released patches and mitigation advice alongside all three advisories. We recommend reviewing the advisories and implementing their guidance as soon as possible.

instruction: Describe the following: MuddyWater Now Targeting Turkish Organizations
output: Cisco Talos has observed activity from the APT group MuddyWater (tracked by IBM as ITG17). The campaign is targeting organizations in Turkey, establishing access that will allow them to carry out espionage, theft, and data destruction. The initial entry point seems to be malicious PDFs, which the users are tricked into opening. The PDF then downloads various maldocs from a remote server and tricks the users into opening these. The maldocs contain macros that establish persistence and download the final stage payload. One interesting difference in this campaign to previous ones is the use of canary tokens. These tokens are embedded in the maldocs which trigger when the document is opened and makes an HTTP request to the canary site, logging the activity for the threat actor to see. This allows them to track who is detonating the malicious code, and see which social engineering techniques are more effective.

instruction: Explain: Identifying Taidoor RAT Samples
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Identifying Taidoor RAT Samples:

ReversingLabs has published a report on the unique characteristics of the Taidoor RAT that enabled them to identify previously unreported samples. Taidoor infections consist of both a loader and the main RAT payload, which is decrypted and executed by the loader. Attempts to find samples of the loader were unsuccessful; however, pivoting to main payloads proved fruitful. The first methodology used to find a starting set of samples was to use a proprietary file similarity algorithm, resulting in 10 samples from 2018 and 2019. One of the main commonalities between the samples was the exports and original file name, providing a new pivot point. This returned 3 samples not previously discovered, which were also connected through the use of the same AES key. The main difference between these additional samples and the previous samples was an additional layer of encryption for the configuration. The filename search was broadened to look for similar file names, again returning more samples that also can be tied together by the same AES key. Further pivoting on filenames found samples dating back to 2011 that leveraged RC4 for encryption of the configuration rather than AES, all sharing the same RC4 key.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for RedLine Stealer Delivered Through FTP?
output: A SANS Internet Storm Center's InfoSec Handlers Diary entry delves into a malicious Python script that ultimately leads to the installation of the RedLine stealer. The Python script begins by connecting to a C2 server over FTP using a hardcoded IP address and credentials. From this server, which was hosting multiple payloads, it downloads an encrypted file. The Python script then loads this payload, which was identified as the RedLine stealer, and some shellcode into memory. The shellcode is simply used to execute a previously-loaded RedLine stealer. The C2 address that RedLine attempts to communicate with over port 37819 was down at the time of analysis.

instruction: Tell me about IBM QRadar SIEM Security Bulletins - May 2021
output:
Certainly.
IBM QRadar SIEM Security Bulletins - May 2021

IBM has published eight security bulletins that apply to QRadar SIEM. In total, seventeen vulnerabilities are addressed in the bulletins. The potential impacts from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities includes a remote attacker being able to cause denial of service conditions, obtain sensitive data (including session credentials), and execute arbitrary commands or code. The vulnerabilities are present in QRadar versions 7.3.0 to 7.3.3 Patch 7, and 7.4.0 to 7.4.2 Patch 2. We recommend updating to the latest fixed versions at the earliest opportunity.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Four Severe Vulnerabilities Patched in Ninja Forms?
output: Wordfence published a blog post detailing four severe vulnerabilities that they discovered in the Ninja Forms WordPress plugin. The first vulnerability is related to the SendWP plugin and could allow for the disclosure of a secret key. If successfully exploited, an attacker with low-level access could monitor all data sent via forms on the victim website or trigger a password reset for an administrator's account. The second vulnerability is in the Add-on Manager and could allow an attacker with low-level access to establish an OAuth Connection with the victim site given a successful social engineering attempt. The third vulnerability is an open redirect vulnerability that could allow an attacker to redirect an administrator to a malicious website. Lastly, a cross-site request forgery vulnerability in the Add-on manager may allow an attacker to disconnect OAuth connections. All of the vulnerabilities are pending CVE assignment. Ninja Form has released updates that fix all of the issues.

instruction: Tell me about FamousSparrow - A New Cyber Espionage Group
output:
Certainly.
FamousSparrow - A New Cyber Espionage Group

ESET researchers have identified a new APT group which they have given the name FamousSparrow. These actors have been observed using remote code execution vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange servers (including ProxyLogon) to infect them with custom malware. The actors drop three files onto their targets, two malicious library files, and a legitimate executable. This legitimate program calls a malicious library, which is then used to execute shellcode to extract and build the custom loader, which has been named SparrowDoor. The loader can receive commands from a C2 server to manipulate files, create processes, and exfiltrate data. Once this is established, the group tends to use tools such as a custom version of Mimikatz, an LSASS dumper called procdump, and a NetBIOS scanner to further compromise their targets and gather information. This group has been seen mainly targeting hotels, although it is thought that they may be interested in espionage as they have been seen targeting other sectors, such as governments, international organizations, engineering companies, and law firms.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Operation "Kremlin" Analysis
output: Sure. Here is a description for Operation "Kremlin" Analysis: Operation Kremlin is the name of a campaign observed by ClearSky. The campaign uses a malicious .DOCX file containing an obfuscated URL to a remote template, which contained malicious VBA and led to the execution of VBS on the victim machine. Using the VBS, the attacker's attempted to use stealth in the form of avoiding external executables in order to exfiltrate data. Familiarity with the victim is suspected due to the escalation of activity on certain days of the week. The initial lure was described as a bonus payment from the Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation. The malicious file contained an embedded XLS file, which is displayed upon the opening of the document. The .DOCX file uses remote template injection in order to hide the URL to the malicious file as opposed to adding a hard-coded IP address. In addition, a .DOTM file containing VBA that writes a VBS file and, subsequently, executes it is leveraged. Wednesday is the specific day of the week used in the attack. The VBS will attempt to find a key in the registry, and, if the drive is a CD/DVD drive, the VBS will continue and will then check the drive letter. This allows further exploitation by executing a search for folders that start with, for example, "PROGRA". Should an interesting file exist, it is sent as a "sendme" parameter. The "sendme" function works if WinRAR exists. This is done, presumably, to avoid large file exfiltration. Much of the code for this particular malware is written in Russian, leading to speculation this is a Chinese campaign targeting Russian victims. Whether the campaign is state-sponsored is not addressed.

instruction: Describe the following: Phishing After ProxyShell Exploitation
output: According to a report published by Cybereason, an attacker recently compromised an Exchange by exploiting one of the ProxyShell vulnerabilities, CVE-2021-34473. The attackers then sent phishing emails to internal and external addresses. The emails were replies to existing email threads the attackers obtained from the Exchange server. The links in the emails led to a .zip archive that contained a malicious DatopLoader Excel file. When executed, a macro in the DatopLoader Excel file was used to download three DLLs which were then executed using regsvr32.exe. The first DLL executed deployed the initial payload, QBot, which then took control and established persistence and began communicating with its C&C server. The attacker then conducted reconnaissance on the compromised system's environment and Cobalt Strike beacons were deployed on other hosts in the network.

instruction:
Given the description:
While many threat actors carry out data exfiltration using common or public tools such as FTP or RClone, LockBit gang has developed their own tool. Researchers from Yoroi ZLAB step through how a custom tool named StealBit is used by the LockBit gang. The tool utilizes some anti-analysis techniques. Additionally, it is used to conduct massive data theft and uses HTTP in a design that is to be as fast as possible. The data is not compressed or encrypted. In it's configuration is a listing of files, extensions, and registry hives that are excluded from being exfiltrated. The systems indicated by the IP addresses noted to be used by StealBit have also been seen to be used in different operations by different criminal organizations.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Domain Wide Systems Encrypted Systems Without Ransomware?
output: The DFIR Report has published their analysis of a ransom attack in which no ransomware was used. In addition, virtually no malware was used in the attack. It began with the attackers compromising a vulnerable MS Exchange server by exploiting the three vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-34473, CVE-2021-34523, and CVE-2021-31207) collectively known as ProxyShell. Post compromise, three different web shells were installed and "Plink" to create an SSH tunnel which allowed the attackers access to RDP on the compromised system. Plink is the command line SSH client that is part of the well-known PuTTY Telnet and SSH client for Windows. Persistence was achieved by enabling the default built-in DefaultAccount, setting a password on the account, and adding it to Administrators and Remote Desktop Users groups. Discovery was largely conducted by running cmd and PowerShell commands from the web shells. A tool named KPortScan was used to scan the internal network. Lateral movement was carried out using RDP with domain admin credentials. It doesn't appear that any data, aside from LSASS dump which was compressed into a ZIP archive exfiltrated, was collected or exfiltrated by the attackers. Command and control was through the aforementioned web shells, and RDP. It was on the third day the attackers had access to the system that most of their activities, including encrypting systems, domain-wide. The encryption of systems was carried out using two different mechanisms. On servers, a BAT file was used to encrypt drives using BitLocker. On workstations, DiskCryptor, a third-party encryption solution that can encrypt all disk partitions, was used to handle the encryption process. And lastly, a ransom note requesting $8,000 USD was placed on a domain controller that was not locked out. The points of contact provided in the note were a Telegram account and a ProtonMail account. While the note included a threat of data having been copied and readied for sale should the ransom not be paid, the only data that appeared to have been exfiltrated by the attackers was the LSASS dump. What is most unusual about this attack is the absence of typical malware such as loaders, droppers, RATs, no use of Cobalt Strike, and most distinctively, no ransomware.

instruction: Provide an overview for: BHUNT - A New Family of Cryptostealer
output: Sure. Here is a description for BHUNT - A New Family of Cryptostealer: Bitdefender has discovered a new family of malware they are calling BHUNT. This malware functions as a cryptostealer, that can exfiltrate wallet contents, stored passwords, and clipboard contents. The samples seen by the researchers were heavily obfuscated, and so the code had to be dumped from memory before it could be analyzed. Machines infected with BHUNT tended to have some form of crack for windows on their system, so the researchers speculate that this could be how the malware was introduced to the victim systems. Once installed, the malware checks for the existence of various crypto wallets, and sends this to the C2 server, along with victim host information. The malware has several methods for stealing data. It can read the contents of a wallet and directly exfiltrate it. It can also search for Firefox profiles that contain account tokens and exfiltrate them, before killing any Firefox processes. The C2 server used by the sample used a dynamic DNS server, meaning that the researchers can't obtain a persistent IP address used by the attackers.

instruction: Provide an overview for: MedusaLocker Ransomware Analysis
output: Sure. Here is a description for MedusaLocker Ransomware Analysis: First appearing in 2019, the MedusaLocker ransomware has been involved in attacks on targets in a variety of industry sectors, most prevalently, the healthcare sector. The Cybereason Nocturnus Team has published an analysis of the MedusaLocker ransomware. According to the Cybereason report, decryption of files encrypted by MedusaLocker is almost impossible without a decryption key provided by the MedusaLocker operators. MedusaLocker uses AES and RSA-2048 encryption standards. A new variant of MedusaLocker, named AKO, reportedly adds the threat of extortion by way of publishing a victim's sensitive data if a ransom is not paid. Once the MedusaLocker payload has been delivered to a victim system, typically in the form of a .bat file and a .txt file, the first step in the encryption process is to create a Windows service. Registry keys are changed to allow the service to run in Safe Mode, and the system is then rebooted in Safe Mode. Once rebooted, the service runs a PowerSploit script which searches for a particular mutex, if found, the process terminates. UAC bypass techniques are used to allow MedusaLocker to execute its operations with elevated privileges. Persistence is achieved using a scheduled task. It will attempt to terminate certain processes and services, some of which are related to security applications which may be installed on the system, and backups are deleted. MedusaLocker will scan the subnet the victim system is connected to looking for hosts and shared folders. As is typical of ransomware, system files are not encrypted as the system needs to remain operational for the victim to read the ransom note. The ransom note provides email addresses for the victim to contact regarding the amount and payment of the ransom.

instruction: Describe the following: Quantum Locker Ransomware
output:
Cybereason’s Nocturnus research team has been analyzing several incidents that included the Quantum Locker Ransomware. The team describes these attacks as RansomOps. These are operations that involve targeting using complex attack sequences and are carried out by sophisticated threat actors. Cybereason also gave this ransomware attack a risk assessment of high due to the “destructive” potential that could be the result of the Quantum Locker compromise. 

This particular ransomware has been around since September of 2020 and has gone by the name AstroLocker and XingLocker. The initial vector of compromise is a phishing attack that utilizes IceID. This malware was formerly a banking trojan. This malware contains a loader payload in the form of a DLL file that masquerades as a document. Once loaded the IcedID malware sends the output back to the C2, the threat actors decide if it is an organization that they are interested in. Once selected, the threat actor executes RDP connections to servers and remote WMI to test credentials.

instruction: What is TA413 Targets Tibet and Europe with Sepulcher Malware
output: Here is an overview on TA413 Targets Tibet and Europe with Sepulcher Malware: Proofpoint has published their analysis of recent activity being carried out by TA413. The first campaign they report on targeted European diplomatic and legislative bodies, non-profit policy research organizations, and global organizations dealing with economic affairs, which is not the usual target of this group. However, infrastructure and TTP overlaps allow for attribution to the APT. These targets received COVID-19 themed phishing emails with weaponsized RTF documents. An RTF exploit is used to drop a WMF file, which, in turn, drops and installs the Sepulcher malware. The WMF file is also responsible for setting up persistence via a scheduled task. The second campaign was aimed towards the group's more common target, the Tibetan community. Once again, infrastructure and TTPs from older TA413 campaigns were leveraged in this campaign. The initial attachment, however, was a malicious PPTX attachment that downloads the Sepulcher malware from a remote server and executes it. Upon execution, the Sepulcher malware reaches out to its C2 server, which is defined in a configuration saved to the Registry. After initial communication is established, Sepulcher provides basic RAT functionality to the operator. This includes capabilities such as file operations, reconnaissance, spawning a shell, and interacting with services and processes.

The second campaign was aimed towards the group's more common target, the Tibetan community. Once again, infrastructure and TTPs from older TA413 campaigns were leveraged in this campaign. The initial attachment, however, was a malicious PPTX attachment that downloads the Sepulcher malware from a remote server and executes it. Upon execution, the Sepulcher malware reaches out to its C2 server, which is defined in a configuration saved to the Registry. After initial communication is established, Sepulcher provides basic RAT functionality to the operator. This includes capabilities such as file operations, reconnaissance, spawning a shell, and interacting with services and processes.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Zero-Day Sophos Firewall Exploitation?
output:
Volexity researchers conducted an assessment of a Sophos firewall after detection of suspicious traffic from the device. The investigation suggested the firewall was compromised via the internet-exposed User Portal component.  Researchers identified suspicious and repeated access targeting a valid JSP file (login.JSP). Further analysis of the firewall revealed that the threat actor established a webshell backdoor through modification of a legitimate component file. The threat actor utilized this webshell in order to establish multiple VPN user accounts and associated certificate pairs for legitimate network access persistence. The attacker also modified specific DNS responses on the compromised device to conduct Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attacks targeting hostnames, which belonged to the victim organization.

The MITM attacks allowed the attacker to conduct credential and session cookie theft from administrative access to the websites' content management systems (CMS). Veloxity's investigation identified multiple instances of successful access, via legitimate session cookies, to the client's CMS admin pages attributed to the attacker. These sessions were used to upload a variation of the Weevely webshell. These webshells then were used to upload additional malware.

instruction: Provide an overview for: VBA Purging Leading to Decreased Detection
output: Sure. Here is a description for VBA Purging Leading to Decreased Detection: VBA Purging is a technique that uses the Compound File Binary Format (CFBF) found in Microsoft Office 97 documents. The technique works by erasing a key component in the VBA source code called "PerformanceCache" data. This changes the value of MODULEOFFSET to 0 and removes all SRP streams, which allows the VBA script to avoid detection. Regular documents using the .***x extension still contain the SRP data. Detection for the regular documents is 36 of 60 engines on VirusTotal. With the VBA Purging technique, the detection rate drops 66% to 12 of 60, making it a particularly useful technique. As stated above, this only works with Office 97 documents. A tool released by Mandiant has the ability to identify purged documents. A YARA rule provided allows for the identification for a large number of malicious documents on VirusTotal, which shows the technique is prevalent in the wild and in use. There is evidence, however, that shows false positives can be still be seen.

instruction: Provide an overview for: O365 Security Update Phish via PDF
output: Sure. Here is a description for O365 Security Update Phish via PDF: Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign leveraging a Microsoft O365 security update theme. The email uses the company's name throughout the email to make it more targeted and, thus, create a sense of legitimacy. The body of the email requests the recipient open an attached PDF, which in turn directs the user to a link that will supposedly apply a required update. Google Ad Services is used to create a redirect link leading to a secondary redirector, ultimately leading to the landing page. If a user clicks through the fake updated terms and enters their password, the data is exfiltrated to the campaign operator. The victim is ultimately redirected to the legitimate Microsoft Services Agreement page in an attempt to hide that any malicious activities had occurred.

instruction: What is CISA Alert AA20-258A
output: Here is an overview on CISA Alert AA20-258A: The Cybersecurity and Information Security Agency has issued an alert detailing the suspected actions of Chinese Ministry of State Security-affiliated cyber threat actors. These actors are using publicly available information and well-known TTPs in order to target U.S. government agencies. Additionally, the actors use easily obtained exploit kits to infiltrate target networks. In addition to the targeting of the U.S. Government, the actors have also been observed targeting various other industries including high-tech manufacturing, medical devices, civil and industrial engineering, business, education, gaming software, and others. Through the use of open-source tools, it is suspected the actors have low-complexity capabilities. The actors have been mostly successful in the infiltration of networks that are misconfigured or have a weak password management profile.

instruction: Tell me about Uber Account Phishing Campaign
output:
Certainly.
Uber Account Phishing Campaign

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing an SMS phishing campaign targeting Uber users. The threat actor sends a phishing link to targets via a spoofed phone number. This causes the text message to appear alongside legitimate messages from Uber. The domain used contains was registered on October 24th, 2021 and contains the word "uber" in an attempt to trick users. Visiting the link leads to a site with fake Uber branding. The first page requests the target's phone number followed by a page claiming that suspicious activity happened and the account needs to be verified. The following two pages request personal information, such as name and date of birth, and credit card information. Victims are ultimately redirected to the legitimate Uber homepage.

instruction: What is BlueNoroff Targets Cryptocurrency Businesses
output: Here is an overview on BlueNoroff Targets Cryptocurrency Businesses: A report published by Kaspersky provides information on the TTPs used by BlueNoroff, an element of the widely known North Korean APT Lazarus, in a campaign they refer to as SnatchCrypto. Initially, BlueNoroff targeted banks and SWIFT servers but now focuses solely on cryptocurrency businesses. BlueNoroff's current infection vectors are typically either Windows shortcut files that arrive in a .zip file or weaponized Word documents, both attached to emails. In the case of the .zip files, the archive contains two files, one pretending to be a txt file that contains the password to the included document but is a Windows .lnk file. When the file is executed a combination of VB and PowerShell scripts are used to fingerprint the host system and deliver a backdoor. The backdoor can in turn be used to deliver further payloads. The second vector is weaponized Word documents that exploit a remote template injection vulnerability and may use VB script and PowerShell scripts to deliver the backdoor payload. BlueNoroff uses social engineering heavily and spends time gaining an understanding of the interactions between individuals and potential topics of interest. The actual spearphishing emails may appear to come from a colleague or from a compromised account such as a LinkedIn account. BlueNoroff will observe their victim for some time before taking any steps to obtain the victim's cryptocurrency. In a case noted by Kaspersky, they replaced a victim's Metamask plugin that is used to manage crypto wallets, with a modified version that allowed them to monitor and modify transactions.

instruction: Describe the following: Weaponizing An Antivirus Driver
output: Researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba ransomware toolset that is used to bypass security controls. The technique involves the use of a legitimate driver, in this case, Avast's Anti Rootkit kernel driver, to terminate a number of AV and EDR processes. Three variations of the technique were observed by Aon, all of which involve installing the driver and then using either an executable or PowerShell script that calls the DeviceIoControl API to terminate specific AV and EDR processes. The Aon report notes that the most recent version of the Cuba toolset contains a list of 110 processes to terminate if found.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for New Campaign Using Bespoke Tools To Weaponize Benign Documents?
output: Cisco Talos has observed a new campaign targeting Afghanistan and India using malicious documents to deliver a variety of malware to victims. The attacks use RTF documents to deliver dcRAT and QuasarRAT by exploiting CVE-2017-11882 — a memory corruption vulnerability in Microsoft Office — and AndroidRAT to target mobile devices. The campaign consists of two parts: a reconnaissance phase and an attack phase. The reconnaissance phase starts with the malicious RTF document, which exploits a vulnerability to execute a malicious PowerShell command to extract and execute a PowerShell script. This script decodes a loader and activates it on the victim machine. The loader establishes persistence and loads the final payload of this phase. It consists of C# code and is a file enumerator and infector. It can weaponize benign documents with malicious OLE objects it can use to propagate the attack to other hosts. The attack phase is the same, except instead of the final payload, it uses a BAT file to download and execute commodity malware. The researchers have attributed this campaign to a threat actor called "A.R. Bunse". They use a front company to procure the infrastructure used in the attacks. Their actions indicate that although they are using commodity malware, their custom tools suggest they are moving away from this approach.

instruction: What is Hartford School District Hit by Ransomware
output:
Here is an overview on Hartford School District Hit by Ransomware: Hartford School District in Connecticut issued a statement informing the public that the schools would delay opening due to critical systems being down after a ransomware attack. Specifically, they note that the system that organizes bus routes was unable to be restored in time for schools opening. The following is part of the statement published on the school district's website:

"We have been informed by Metro Hartford Information Services (MHIS), our City of Hartford shared services team that manages our network infrastructure, that the ransomware virus caused an outage of critical systems and the restoration of those systems are not complete. This includes the system that communicates our transportation routes to our bus company and it is preventing our ability to operate schools on Tuesday."

BleepingComputer reports that the ransomware family is rumored to be Hermes. Additionally, the mayor of Hartford has stated that no data was stolen to their knowledge and there is no plan to pay a ransom, although supposedly no ransom demand was given as part of the attack.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Magniber Ransomware Evolving To Infect Chrome and Edge?
output: The ASEC analysis team has been tracking the ransomware known as Magniber and its distribution methods. This ransomware is traditionally spread by exploiting Internet Explorer vulnerabilities and continues to be spread in this way. However, Magniber has recently been seen on both Microsoft Edge and Google Chrome. When the distribution pages are navigated to on these browsers, the user is asked to install an APPX file which is supposed to update the browser. Interestingly, the APPX file for both browsers contains a valid certificate, so the installation is allowed to go ahead. The result of this operation is a malicious executable and DLL file, which work together to download the ransomware and execute it in memory.

instruction: Describe the following: Bitcoin Scam Leads To Millions For Threat Actors
output: ZDNet reported on a resurgence of Bitcoin attacks, as threat actors capitalize on vulnerabilities within Electrum's application backend infrastructure, allowing threat actors to create false servers, using them as bait for users of the original application. This simple, yet well-orchestrated scheme, combines human error and phishing tactics, enticing users of the application to install a malicious version of the original app. Users are then duped into providing a requested one-time passcode after receiving notification for an update. If threat actors are successful up to that point, there is a high chance users of Electrum's wallet application have given approval for the malicious wallet to transfer all of their funds to an attacker's account. Electrum, understands the impact of malicious servers and have applied preventative measures to reduce the tempo of attacks such as: a server blacklisting system and updates preventing servers from showing HTML formatted popups to end users.

instruction: Tell me about Phishing Campaign Aiming to Steal One-Time Passwords
output:
Certainly.
Phishing Campaign Aiming to Steal One-Time Passwords

ZScaler researchers discovered a sophisticated phishing campaign targeting customers of top Indian banks. The phishing campaign is designed to capture the customer's banking credentials and install malicious SMS stealers on the user's phone or tablet. These websites are convincing fakes of the banks and contain forms meant to harvest victim data. The form attempts to collect the account number, name, mobile number, as well as bank card information. Once all of this has been entered, the site attempts to download an android app onto the device, with the user being informed that the app is a banking support app. The app is named SBOI Quick Support. Once the app is installed, it requests permissions to send/view messages from the phone. Lastly, after all the permissions are granted, the app displays a fake form for submitting a complaint number. In the background, the app monitors all messages that the device receives and exfiltrates them along with device information to the C2 server. This campaign aims to retrieve the banking details and monitor the victim's device for any one-time passwords that may be received from the bank, allowing the attackers complete access to the victim's accounts.

instruction: Describe the following: A New Infostealer Named dmechant
output: A phishing campaign using malspam, which delivers a previously undocumented infostealer was discovered by the FortiGuard Labs team. The emails have a malicious Word document attached which uses macros and JavaScript to download an executable disguised as a PDF. The sample email in the FortiGuard analysis is written in Spanish. The executable file contains the payload which FortiGuard has named dmechant. Persistence is achieved using a Registry run key. The malware has a hard-coded list of ten crypto wallet applications and if any are located, the applications directory and files are copied into an archive. The malware also steals credentials from certain applications including web browsers, and email, vpn, and ftp clients, which it copies into a text file. The stolen data is then exfiltrated using SMTP.

instruction:
Given the description:
Trend Micro investigated data they gathered from January 2020 through September 2021 that has been attributed to an advanced persistent threat (APT) group they call Earth Karkaddan or APT36. Earth Karkaddan has historically targeted Indian military and diplomatic resources. They have been known to use social engineering and phishing lures as an entry point. In addition to phishing using malicious documents attached to spam email and the use of USB worms, they have used Android RATs using phishing links. The group has favored the use of Crimson RAT in the past, and in late 2021, Trend Micro saw them leverage CapraRAT, an Android RAT with similarities in design.

instruction: What is Ghostwriter Operation Targets Ukraine
output: Here is an overview on Ghostwriter Operation Targets Ukraine: Cluster25 has been tracking the threat group UNC1151 and its activities in Ukraine. In July 2020, this group was reported to be responsible for a political influence campaign called GhostWriter. More recently, this group has been seen spreading malware for espionage purposes. Cluster25 researchers found a malicious document designed to spread malware. This document purports to be from the Ukrainian President's office and secret services offering advice on dealing with bombings. The document runs a stealthy script that drops the malware. This malware was compiled at the end of January 2022 and is a backdoor that reaches out to a C2 domain. This can execute several commands, including data collection, downloading files, and executing commands.

instruction: Tell me about Wormable Android Malware Spreading Through Social Media
output:
Certainly.
Wormable Android Malware Spreading Through Social Media

Quick Heal published a blog post analyzing malicious applications abusing the Android auto-reply feature to spread payloads. Links to download the payload often come from a trusted sender who was previously infected by the same malware. The lures claim that the links provide free streaming content or feature upgrades for WhatsApp. In particular, Quick Heal investigated two applications using this method, "WhatsApp Pink" and "Online stream." Based on the code signing certificate, the same developer is behind both of these applications. Once installed, the necessary permissions are requested by the application. With this access in place, the malware begins to monitor for notifications from a variety of messaging apps. If a notification is received, the malware uses the auto-reply feature to send its download links to new potential victims. While the current functionality only includes monitoring of notifications, icon hiding, and auto-reply, it is possible for the developers to add further malicious capabilities in future variants.

instruction: What is Malware Leveraging XML-RPC Vulnerability to Exploit WordPress Sites
output: Here is an overview on Malware Leveraging XML-RPC Vulnerability to Exploit WordPress Sites: Zscaler reports on a new campaign leveraging XML-RPC in an attack chain against WordPress websites. It begins with an executable masquerading as a legitimate Microsoft system file. While some of the metadata used matches that of real Microsoft executables, other fields indicate that the malware is still in development due to comments like "TODO" being present. Upon execution, the malware first decrypts the C2 URI to be leveraged and a domain name using an XOR loop. The domain that is decrypted is used to perform a blockchain DNS lookup in order to identify the C2 IP to be used by the malware. This IP, in combination with the aforementioned URI, is leveraged for the initial C2 communication. The C2 server, in turn, downloads an updated version of the malware. It then gathers system information to report back to the C2. Its final functionality is then implemented. Specifically, it performs a brute force attack against a list of targets provided by the C2 server. It uses XML-RPC in combination with a cURL script to attempt cookie-based authentication to WordPress login pages until valid credentials are identified.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for MuddyWater Targeting Turkey and Arabian Peninsula in Malware Campaign?
output: In a recent report from Hacker News, the Iranian state sponsored threat actor known as MuddyWater, tracked by X-Force as ITG17, is responsible for attacks targeting Turkey and the Arabian Peninsula. MuddyWater is believed to have been active since 2017 and is also believed to a "conglomerate of multiple teams operating independently rather than a single threat actor group." According to U.S. Cyber Command this is a state sponsored group and they have been attributed to the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security. This latest campaign uses phishing in order to attempt to deliver malicious Microsoft Excel documents with the intent to deploy a remote access trojan called SloughRAT. Additionally, it also seems to pick up where a November 2021 campaign left off that targeted Turkish private organizations and government institutions with PowerShell-based backdoors.

instruction:
Given the description:
Imperva published reports detailing the KashmirBlack botnet and its operation. The botnet, which has been around since November 2019, targets CMS platforms with exploits for known vulnerabilities. Probably the most interesting aspect of this botnet is its sophistication infrastructure that uses DevOps to allow for changes to be made easily and to support heavy traffic. Along with a C2 server, this botnet also leverages load balancers and multiple repositories for obtaining payloads. The infection process begins with turning a victim server into a spreading bot or pending bot. The first occurs when a remote code execution vulnerability is exploited to run a Perl script which, in turn, downloads and runs a Python script that can communicate with the C2. The pending bot is created using a simple PHP webshell. The spreading bot waits for commands from the C2 that will subsequently be used to turn pending bots into another spreading bot or a cryptomining, spamming, or defancement bot. With regard to the repositories hosting the payloads, the attackers originally used compromised websites but have since switched to using Pastebin and Github in order to hide their traffic via legitimate services.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: KashmirBlack Botnet

instruction: Provide an overview for: OpenSSL Security Advisory March 2021
output: Sure. Here is a description for OpenSSL Security Advisory March 2021: Two vulnerabilities have been addressed in a new version of OpenSSL, version 1.1.1k. Both the vulnerabilities have been rated as High by the OpenSSL Software Foundation. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-3449) could allow a remote attacker to cause a denial of service condition by sending a maliciously crafted renegotiation ClientHello message from a client. All versions of OpenSSL 1.1.1 are affected by the vulnerability. The other vulnerability (CVE-2021-3450) could allow for a failure to reject certain invalid certificates. OpenSSL versions from 1.1.1h onwards are affected by this issue.

instruction: Provide an overview for: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - October 13th, 2020
output:
Sure. Here is a description for ICS-CERT Security Advisories - October 13th, 2020: ICS-CERT has released six security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in various ICS devices.

ICSA-20-287-01 addresses 6 vulnerabilities in NPort IAW5000A-I/O Series devices. Types of vulnerabilities addressed in this advisory are session fixation, improper privilege management, weak password requirements, cleartext transmission of sensitive information, improper restriction of excessive authentication attempts, and exposure of sensitive information. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include session hijacking, privilege escalation, authentication bypass, and access of sensitive information.

ICSA-20-287-02 addresses an out-of-bounds read vulnerability in LCDS LAquis SCADA devices. If successfully exploited, an attacker may be able to execute code under the privileges of the application.

ICSA-20-287-03 addresses an untrusted search path vulnerability in Flexera InstallShield software. If successfully exploited, an attacker may be able to execute a malicious DLL.

ICSA-20-287-04 addresses a stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability in Fieldcomm Group HART-IP and hipserver devices. Exploitation of this vulnerability may allow an attacker to crash the device or perform remote code execution.

ICSA-20-287-05 addresses 3 vulnerabilities in Siemens Desigo Insight products. Types of vulnerabilities addressed in this advisory are SQL injection, improper restriction of rendered UI layers or frames, and exposure of sensitive information. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include access of sensitive information or modification of data.

ICSA-20-287-06 addresses an authentication bypass vulnerability in Siemens SIPORT MP software. An authenticated attacker may be able to impersonate other users of the system and perform actions on behalf of those users.

All vendors have provided either patches or workarounds to address these issues. We recommend reviewing the advisories and taking appropriate actions as soon as possible.

instruction: Tell me about New Cryptbot Has been Optimized and Upgraded
output:
Certainly.
New Cryptbot Has been Optimized and Upgraded

ASEC labs have analyzed the latest version of the Cryptbot infostealer. The infostealer is normally distributed on websites that claim to host cracked software and tools. The actors optimize these pages so they appear at the top of search results, increasing infection probability. The latest version of the malware removes several features for simplification. This includes the anti-sandbox routine and the use of multiple C2 addresses. The actors have also removed behavior that allows the malware to collect TXT files and take screenshots. The new version has been updated so it can steal from the latest version of Chrome. However, the biggest improvement is that previous versions of Cryptbot would fail if any data that the malware was targetting didn't exist. The bug has been fixed so the malware can run regardless of the success of the stealing behavior.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Phishing Campaign Uses Court Case as Lure?
output: A phishing campaign using a Supreme Court Contract Agreement as a lure has been observed by Cofense. The email contains a malicious link with a calendar invite. If a victim clicks on the calendar invite, a URL is displayed. Should the victim still be intrigued enough to click the URL, they are redirected to a landing page with multiple email services, such as Outlook, Office365, or Office Mail. In a departure from the norm, the URL contained within the calendar invite is not formatted in a typical fashion. The URL uses hex coding with no top-level domain. Instead, a browser will convert the hex code into decimal to form an IP address. It is speculated the URL may be part of the reason it slips by so many security email gateways. Once the victim is on the landing page and enters credentials, those credentials are sent back to the attacker. The document appears obfuscated and provides an incentive for the victim to enter their login details in order to view the document.

instruction: Explain: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-048G - AppleJeus: Ants2Whale
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-048G - AppleJeus: Ants2Whale:

From the Malware Analysis Report (AR21-048G)  
MAR-10322463-7.v1 - AppleJeus: Ants2Whale

This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) is the result of analytic efforts among the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), and the Department of Treasury (Treasury) to highlight the cyber threat to cryptocurrency posed by North Korea, formally known as the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK), and provide mitigation recommendations. Working with U.S. government partners, FBI, CISA, and Treasury assess that Lazarus Group—which these agencies attribute to North Korean state-sponsored advanced persistent threat (APT) actors—is targeting individuals and companies, including cryptocurrency exchanges and financial service companies, through the dissemination of cryptocurrency trading applications that have been modified to include malware that facilitates theft of cryptocurrency.

This MAR highlights this cyber threat posed by North Korea and provides detailed indicators of compromise (IOCs) used by the North Korean government. The U.S. Government refers to malicious cyber activity by the North Korean government as HIDDEN COBRA. For more information on other versions of AppleJeus and recommended steps to mitigate this threat, see Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA21-048A: AppleJeus: Analysis of North Korea's Cryptocurrency Malware at <https://www.us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/AA21-048A>.

There have been multiple versions of AppleJeus malware discovered since its initial discovery in August 2018. In most versions, the malware appears to be from a legitimate-looking cryptocurrency trading company and website, whereby an unsuspecting individual downloads a third-party application from a website that appears legitimate.

The U.S. Government has identified AppleJeus malware version—Ants2Whale—and associated IOCs used by the North Korean government in AppleJeus operations.

instruction: Explain: Dridex Activity on the Rise
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Dridex Activity on the Rise:

Until this past week, Dridex activity had seemingly come to a halt; however, new activity has been uncovered by the ISC. A VirusTotal search revealed three documents containing the Dridex malspam malware. The documents obtained followed the same infection process as previous iterations of Dridex. In order to deploy Dridex on a vulnerable Windows host, the victim must download the document and enable macros. Upon doing so, the macro will cause Powershell to retrieve a DLL over HTTPS encrypted traffic. This DLL is the installer for Dridex and is immediately run. Post-infection, Dridex makes HTTPS calls in order to obtain the requisite malspam data. Persistence is obtained via three simultaneous methods: Windows Registry update, scheduled task, and Windows Startup menu shortcut. The malware uses existing EXE files to load the malware. The specific DLLs used by Dridex are named in such a way that they match legitimate DLLs and would be run by corresponding EXEs. Beyond any blatant changes, the Dridex malware is unchanged and traffic patterns are the same.

instruction:
Given the description:
Volexity conducted an analysis of a system that was suspected to have become infected with malware. The system's owner is according to the report, frequently targeted by North Korean actors. Volexity discovered the BLUELIGHT and RokRAT payloads on the system and attributes the attack to APT37. Volexity tracks APT37 as InkySquid, IBM X-Force tracks them as ITG10. Volexity was unable to determine the initial infection vector due to the time between infection and investigation, and the system having been rebooted multiple times. There were two loading mechanisms for the payloads, the first involved installing a version of Python, and storing an encoded blob and a loader script. A Scheduled task was created to run the loader which executed the blob. This provided the BLUELIGHT payload. The second mechanism operated in the same way, but in this case, Ruby, two encoded blobs and a loader script were used. This provided the RokRAT payload.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: What is Cybercriminals Distribute Backdoor With VPN Installer
output: Here is an overview on Cybercriminals Distribute Backdoor With VPN Installer: Trend Micro has published their analysis of a fake VPN installer distributing a backdoor. Victims are initially convinced to download what they believe is the Windscribe VPN installer but are instead downloading a malicious bundled application. The bundle drops three files: the legitimate VPN installer, a malicious downloader, and a VBS script. The VBS script is responsible for executing both the legitimate installer and the downloader. While the installer is distracting the user from any malicious activity, the downloader obtains the backdoor payload from a remote website. The downloaded file is an encrypted JPG file. After decryption, a backdoor executable is revealed. This backdoor contains basic functionality including downloading, executing, and updating files, taking screenshots, and gathering system information.

instruction: Explain: Hacktivist Attack Targeted Cisco Smart Install Protocol
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Hacktivist Attack Targeted Cisco Smart Install Protocol:

Cisco describes Smart Install as "a plug-and-play configuration and image-management feature that provides zero-touch deployment for new switches". In mid-May, Lumen Technologies' Black Lotus Labs team discovered an attack that targeted devices that were running the Smart Install protocol and were accessible from the Internet. The attack, believed to have been carried out by unidentified hacktivists, replaced the vulnerable device's configuration file with one which contained a political statement. More than one hundred organizations were targeted in the attack and at least in some cases, caused network disruptions or outages.

instruction: What is Lazarus Targeting Covid-19 Related Intelligence
output: Here is an overview on Lazarus Targeting Covid-19 Related Intelligence: While monitoring the threat-group Lazarus, Kaspersky Labs discovered that they had attacked a pharmaceutical company in September and a government health ministry in October. In the ministry attack, two Windows servers were compromised by a yet unknown infection vector. The malware used in the attack was called wAgent, a memory resident-only application that pulls additional modules, as needed, from a remote server. Persistence is achieved by downloading an additional module for this purpose. In the pharmaceutical attack, the malware package called Bookcode was deployed in a supply chain attack, coming in through a South Korean software company. Although different types of attacks and malware were used, Kaspersky indicated they had enough evidence to tie both attacks to the Lazarus group.

instruction:
Given the description:
Bitdefender published a blog post detailing an active cryptomining campaign carried out by a threat group they believe is based in Romania. The initial infection vector used by the group is brute forcing of SSH credentials. A limited number of source IPs for these brute force attacks indicates that compromised systems are not being used for spreading to other victims in a wormable fashion. Bitdefender found the group's full toolset when they discovered a C2 server hosting an open directory containing loader observed in a cryptomining attack. Along with loaders, this directory contained a Demonbot variant and bash scripts for propagating it, a Perl IRC bot, reconnaissance tools, and more. The loaders are obfuscated using a shell compiled (shc) and use Discord for C2 communication. Another tool that is highlighted by Bitdefender is a previously unreported SSH brute forcer written in Golang. The use of an API key to execute the tool suggest is operates on an "as-a-service" model. The attackers implement various persistence mechanisms, including a service, cron job, new sudo users, and adding SSH keys to the authorized_keys file. Ultimately, the threat actors use their access to deploy a cryptominer, specifically the XMRig Monero miner.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Active Cryptomining Campaign by Romanian Threat Group

instruction: What is LATAM Banking Trojan – Numando
output: Here is an overview on LATAM Banking Trojan – Numando: The Numando banking Trojan is used primarily to target bank users in Brazil. It has been known on rare occasions to have been used in campaigns targeting users in Mexico and Spain. According to ESET, The actor behind Numando has been active since 2018 however, Numando is not frequently updated and does not appear to be under continuous development. It provides features common to banking Trojans such as overlay windows and backdoor access to an infected system. Currently, Numando is distributed using malspam with a ZIP file containing an MSI installer attached to the emails. Inside the installer is a CAB archive that contains an injector, an encrypted DLL which is the Numando payload, and a legitimate application. The legitimate application is used to sideload the Numando DLL. One other infection chain that was used by Numando starts with a downloader that downloads a ZIP file but ignores its content. Instead, it extracts the ZIP file's comment which is a hex-encoded and encrypted string that when decrypted provides the URL of the actual ZIP file whose contents are used in the infection chain. Numando uses a remote configuration that is stored in either Pastebin or YouTube pages.

instruction: Provide an overview for: DeepBlueMagic Ransomware Group Abuses Legit Encryption Tools
output: Sure. Here is a description for DeepBlueMagic Ransomware Group Abuses Legit Encryption Tools: Varonis published a blog post analyzing tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) observed in a DeepBlueMagic ransomware group attack against an Israeli hospital. The attackers gained access to the network via a Pulse Secure VPN vulnerability. Once on the network, little is known about their activity with regards to reconnaissance, lateral movement, and privilege escalation. The primary finding by the researchers is DeepBlueMagic's use of off-the-shelf encryption tools rather than a custom ransomware payload. Specifically, the group used Jetico BestCrypt on hosts with multiple partitions or volumes and BitLocker on single-volume hosts. It is likely the command-line utilities for the tools were leveraged as opposed to the GUI application.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Increase in FakeClicky Skimmer Activity
output: Sure. Here is a description for Increase in FakeClicky Skimmer Activity: The FakeClicky skimmer has been in existence for two years or more and a number of variants have been observed. Zscaler ThreatLabz has reported a recent increase in activity involving the FakeClicky skimmer. In the activity observed by Zscaler, the skimmer is loaded onto compromised e-commerce sites using tags on the sites' pages that give the appearance of loading a legitimate Google Tag Manager script. No information regarding how the e-commerce sites have been compromised is provided in the report. The skimmer code is hosted on recently registered domains that have resolved to one of two IP addresses. The domains are named to appear to belong to legitimate services. When a victim uses a compromised site's checkout page, the skimmer extracts the page's data, encodes it using Base64 and exfiltrates the data to the skimmer operator's system.

instruction: Tell me about Successor to npm "fallguys" Undetected for 5 Months
output:
Certainly.
Successor to npm "fallguys" Undetected for 5 Months

New npm packages discovered by the Sonatype Security Research team have been identified legitimate looking packages as malicious. The four new packages were published by the same author whose npm account was responsible for previously identified malicious packages. Automated malware detection systems flagged a package, wsbd.js, for potentially malicious behavior. The author, who has previously released packages not appearing to be malicious, had three other packages stand out aside from the aforementioned wsbd.js. The first package, discord.dll, which conducts activity that is well hidden. It uses a legitimate instance of Discord.js npm to distract from malicious activities. This package has been on the npm downloads site for more than 5 months. The package contains multiple files which are obfuscated and have numerous base64-encoded strings. The code included with the package has references to Discord, web hooks, setting and getting cookies, sending data, Discord tokens, and web browser files. One such encoded string is a URL to a logo from the Anonymous collective. This does not indicate an alliance or tie-in with the group. Web browsers of interest to the DLL are Opera, Yandex, Brave, and Google Chrome. The most obvious sign of relation to "fallguys" is the exfiltration of Discord and web browser's leveldb files. References such as data collection of IP address, PC username, discordcanary files, and others is noted. A deobfuscated "Webhook.js" file shows exfiltration of collected data to a webhook address. At present, it appears as though the webhook is no longer in use. Multiple files within the package are obfuscated JS files that would take longer to analyze. The other files launch EXE files called, "bd.exe", "dropper.exe", and "lib.exe." The researchers were unable to confirm the usage nor how the files make their way onto a victim's system. Each of these packages contained only one line of code. An npm package called Discord.app launches a script which then launches dropper.exe. Each of the four files have been downloaded a minimum of 38 times and were published between 14 days and 5 months ago.

instruction: Describe the following: An Analysis of Monero Miner Variants And Techniques
output: Trend Micro has published details of the various vulnerabilities being used to spread cryptomining malware, as well as the techniques used to perform the attacks. In the vulnerabilities listed, it is noted that they are all well-documented and have several proofs of concept published. The samples investigated in this project worked on both Windows and Linux systems. This fact, coupled with the wide range of CVEs used, allows attackers to establish a presence on many hosts, making the campaigns very lucrative. One method of note was the use of valid content delivery mechanisms to bypass IP allowlists. In the Windows samples, a compromised service would download the miner scripts from commonly-used, legitimate sites, such as GitHub or Netlify. This traffic is encrypted, meaning it could be missed by IDS/IPS systems, and the domains are unlikely to be blocked in most environments. Analysis of the wallets associated with the miners shows that these samples are active in the wild and are continuing to spread and mine for cryptocurrency.

instruction: Tell me about Purple Fox Rootkit Now Propagates as a Worm
output:
Certainly.
Purple Fox Rootkit Now Propagates as a Worm

Guardicore has published a blog post analyzing Purple Fox's new worm-like propagation method. The initial infection vector is either a phishing email attachment that exploits a browser vulnerability or through compromise of a vulnerable exposed service. Once on the system, the first-stage creates a service that will provide persistence and execute a command to retrieve and install the Purple Fox payload. The installer is an MSI installer masquerading as a Windows update package. The MSI package contains a 32-bit and 64-bit DLl and an encrypted rootkit file. Firewall rules are created to block traffic in order to prevent reinfection or exploitation by competitors. Upon restart, the malware begins its worming attempts by scanning a list of IP ranges to identify and brute-force exposed SMB services. If successful, this infection chain repeats itself.

instruction: What is LodaRAT Improves Espionage Capabilities
output: Here is an overview on LodaRAT Improves Espionage Capabilities: Cisco has published a blog analyzing a new version of LodaRAT for Windows and the release of an Android version of the tool. Hybrid campaigns were identified that targeted both Windows and Android users in Bangladesh and other countries. The campaigns were connected due to the use of shared C2 infrastructure between the Android and Windows samples. As with previous LodaRAT campaigns, the Windows payload was delivered via a malicious RTF document that uses a memory corruption exploit to download a malicious SCT file. Unlike previous campaigns, however, this campaign used an AppLocker bypass technique to execute the SCT file. The SCT file is responsible for the download and installation of the LodaRAT payload. This new version of LodaRAT added several commands, such as those for RDP remote access capabilities and an improved method of recording audio. The newly discovered Loda4Android has overlapping C2 infrastructure and a similar beacon creation routine and C2 protocol. It provides functionality similar to most Android RAT applications, allowing the operator to spy on user activities and control the device.

instruction:
Given the description:
The Mirai botnet has become such an overused commodity in the world of cyber attacks that it seems as though every threat actor employs it in some form or fashion. A group known as "Priority" has taken the source code and repurposed it in its latest campaign. This particular threat actor has used several iterations of Mirai including DemonBot and the version of Mirai written by an actor named, "Scarface." Having been active since September 10, 2020 to the present, the activity curve has continued to rise. Attacking on ports 5500, 5501, 5502, 5050, and 60001, the group employs a simple GET request to leverage the MVPower DVR Shell Unauthenticated Command Execution, reported by Unit 42 as being part of the Omni Botnet variant. During most employments of Mirai, three to seven exploits are used. With Priority, the number of exploits employed is a singular with most of the targeting focusing on port 60001. Additionally, all attacks originate from a single IP address. A file downloaded contains a script with the IP address of the host machine containing the malware. Most files are packed with UPX while some are completely unpacked. These strings show this is a variant of Mirai. At first analysis, these strings contain "NeTiS and Thisity," as well as "FoReHeAd We BiG L33T Has." Future versions include significant references to "Priority." The group shows some sophistication in the understanding of code modification for its specific purposes.

To which threat report this description is related to?

instruction: What is Bom Skimmer is Newest Malware from Magecart Group 7
output: Here is an overview on Bom Skimmer is Newest Malware from Magecart Group 7: RiskIQ researchers have discovered a new skimmer that they have named Bom Skimmer. This new skimmer has been active since 2019 and is currently running on a large number of fake and compromised online stores. The researchers have traced this skimmer back to the notorious Magecart Group 7, which was responsible for high-profile attacks, such as the attack on British Airways in 2018. This skimmer injects its payment form into compromised sites and then exfiltrates the captured data using both an actor-controlled server and a compromised server. Using dual exfiltration paths has been seen in other Magecart skimmers, and assists with attribution. Within this article, RiskIQ also identifies another skimmer in the same family as the Bom Skimmer, which they are calling the MakeFrame skimmer. This skimmer has a lot of the same functionalities as Bom Skimmer, but only uses one exfiltration path at a time, rather than using both compromised and actor-owned infrastructure. Another notable difference is that the MakeFrame skimmer can exfiltrate using either POST or GET requests, whereas Bom skimmer can only use GET requests. Despite this, the researchers assert that MakeFile and other skimmers were integrated into the version of the Bom skimmer that is in use today.

instruction: Explain: BABYSHARK Used In Espionage Campaign Against Nuclear Think Tank
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for BABYSHARK Used In Espionage Campaign Against Nuclear Think Tank:

Huntress researchers were initially requested to investigate a file that had been attempted to be downloaded onto a client's system, by a task that had persistence. This scheduled task would run a Visual Basic script while masquerading as a Google service. The file in question was a highly obfuscated file, which gets decrypted by the VB script. The script checks that it is being run by a specific user or else it won't run, showing that this was a highly targeted attack. The malware was found to be a version of the BABYSHARK malware, which is malware linked to North Korean groups and allows some attribution. The malware was found to have two C2 servers, both of which returned tools used in the attack. Knowing the TTPs of the group, the researchers were able to track down and crack a password-protected zip containing a malicious word document. This document contained macros to check for antivirus and perform a DLL hijacking attack. It was found that the initial phishing email was targeted at a single individual in the business with an interview request. There was some back-and-forth with the threat group to gain trust before being sent the malicious payload.
