instruction: What is ICS-CERT Security Advisory - December 3rd, 2020
output:
Here is an overview on ICS-CERT Security Advisory - December 3rd, 2020: ICS-CERT has released a security advisory (ICSA-20-338-01) addressing a vulnerability in National Instruments' CompactRIO.

CVE-2020-25191 is an incorrect permission assignment to an API affecting CompactRIO driver versions prior to 20.5. If successfully exploited, an unauthenticated attacker could reboot a device remotely.

National Instruments has released an update that fixes this issue.

instruction: Tell me about Avos Ransomware Group Expands Capabilities
output:
Certainly.
Avos Ransomware Group Expands Capabilities

The team at Talos was recently asked to assist a Cisco customer. When they responded to the request their analysis revealed that the customer was targeted by the Avos ransomware group. This threat group goes back to 2021 when they initially targeted Windows instances. Recently a new variant of their ransomware known as AvosLocker is targeting Linux environments. Avos ransomware is known as ransomware-as-a-service. In past campaigns, Avos used spam emails to compromise victims. During the investigation of this incident, Talos researchers found that the threat actor had utilized an ESXi server that was exposed as the initial vector. This particular server was exposed because of the VMWare Horizon Unified Gateways that were vulnerable to the Log4Shell.

instruction: Describe the following: LimeRAT Being Used in Targeting of Colombia
output: Beginning with an infection via email and using generic topics, threat actors have been attempting to lure unwitting victims into opening a malicious attachment that is, in fact, an image containing a link to download a compressed file from Microsoft's OneDrive. Topics for the phishing email are typically subpoenas or bank payments. These types of lures are attractive because they indicate either a financial windfall, a financial deficit, or court actions for a myriad of reasons. Because of the attractiveness of the lures, the actor(s) have some success using these techniques. Within the image is a .rar file containing a poorly-obfuscated Visual Basic Script that launches a PowerShell script. More confusing is the use of the Internet Archive for storage of the first stage download. There is speculation this usage of the Internet Archive is employed to help prevent discovery but has not seen much in the wild usage. The script downloads a series of other scripts that are dropped in folders on the victim machine. Additionally, a Registry key is written to provide persistence to the actors. Most of the scripts are focused on disabling anti-virus software. Two DLLs written in .NET are loaded. One is used as a loader for the other, which appears to be the RAT in question. One final piece of speculation focuses on the usage by an APT group named APT-C-36, or Blind Eagle. The group has targeted the same area. There is no definitive information on whether the APT group is behind this attack, but the coincidences cannot be ignored.

instruction: Describe the following: Cisco Security Advisories April 28 2021
output:
Cisco has published thirteen Security Advisories. Of the advisories, five are rated as High and eight are rated as Medium. For all advisories listed below, it is noted that Cisco's Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is "not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities" that are described in the advisories.

## Advisories Rated High

 **Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Software and Firepower Threat Defense Software Web Services Buffer Overflow Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-memc-dos-fncTyYKG  
A vulnerability in the web services interface of CiscoAdaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a buffer overflow on an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1493  
Base 8.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-memc-dos-fncTyYKG>

 **Cisco Firepower Threat Defense Software SSL Decryption Policy Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-ftd-ssl-decrypt-dos-DdyLuK6c  
A vulnerability in the software-based SSL/TLS message handler of CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to trigger a reload of an affected device, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition.  
CVE-2021-1402  
Base 8.6 CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-ftd-ssl-decrypt-dos-DdyLuK6c>

 **Cisco Firepower Threat Defense Software Command Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-ftd-cmdinj-vWY5wqZT  
A vulnerability in the CLI of CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges on the underlying operating system of an affected device that is running in multi-instance mode.  
CVE-2021-1448  
Base 7.8 CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-ftd-cmdinj-vWY5wqZT>

 **Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Software and Firepower Threat Defense Software Web Services VPN Denial of Service Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-asa-ftd-vpn-dos-fpBcpEcD  
Multiple vulnerabilities in CiscoAdaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1445 CVE-2021-1504  
Base 8.6 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-asa-ftd-vpn-dos-fpBcpEcD>

 **Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Software and Cisco Firepower Threat Defense Software SIP Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-asa-ftd-sipdos-GGwmMerC  
A vulnerability in the SIP inspection engine of CiscoAdaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a crash and reload of an affected device, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition.The vulnerability is due to a crash that occurs during a hash lookup for a SIP pinhole connection. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted SIP traffic through an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to cause a crash and reload of the affected device.  
CVE-2021-1501  
Base 8.6 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-asa-ftd-sipdos-GGwmMerC>

## Advisories Rated Medium

 **Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Software and Firepower Threat Defense Software for Firepower 1000 and 2100 Series Appliances Command Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-asa-cmdinj-TKyQfDcU  
A vulnerability in the upgrade process of CiscoAdaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to inject commands that could be executed with root privileges on the underlying operating system (OS).  
CVE-2021-1488  
Base 6.7 CVSS:3.1/AV:L/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-asa-cmdinj-TKyQfDcU>

 **Multiple Cisco Products Snort HTTP Detection Engine File Policy Bypass Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-http-fp-bp-KfDdcQhc  
Multiple Ciscoproducts are affected by a vulnerability in the Snort detection engine that could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to bypass a configured file policy for HTTP.  
CVE-2021-1495

instruction: Provide an overview for: New Tax Refund Themed Phish
output: Sure. Here is a description for New Tax Refund Themed Phish: Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign using a tax refund themed email to steal sensitive information from users. The email sender masquerades as the IRS and claims the recipient is eligible for an extra tax refund, likely referencing stimulus checks. The sender is spoofed to appear to come from an internal business address but in reality is from an external, compromised email account. Visiting the link directs users to a fake IRS form hosted on the AWS Amplify service. It even leverages a pop-up box about authorized usage, similar to that on the legitimate IRS website, in order to increase legitimacy. The form requests a variety of personal information, such as social security number, ID numbers, date of birth, and address. If a user falls victim and provides this data, the threat actor will receive the provided data and the victim will be redirected to the legitimate IRS website.

instruction: Describe the following: PseudoManuscrypt Malware
output: ASEC published a blog post analyzing PseudoManuscrypt's infection chain and functionality. The malware is distributed in Korea via fake cracking and keygen software installers linked to in search results. The researchers note that this initial infection vector is similar to that leveraged by the Cryptobot malware, with additional overlaps present in the execution flow of the malware. The initial download is an NSIS installer that executes a 7z SFX archive. Within this archive are multiple executables including a dropper that continues the infection process. Ultimately, a loader is used to decode and execute shellcode stored in a .dat file. The shellcode is injected into memory and used to execute the malware. Persistence is established via a service. Once installed, PseudoManuscrypt is capable of gathering system information, network share, clipboard data, audio recordings, and more. This data is subsequently exfiltrated to a C2 server. The attacker can also issue further commands via the C2 server for activities such as file download and cmd command execution.

instruction:
Given the description:
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence analysts, since March 2020, have been tracking malicious campaigns using phishing emails to deploy Visual Basic Script (VBS) files that fingerprint infected machines and download and execute the Griffon JScript backdoor. The Griffon backdoor, in use since early 2018, is custom malware that has been attributed to ITG14 (aka FIN7). This group is an advanced cybercriminal group known for conducting illegal operations since 2016 against organizations within the retail, restaurant, banking, and hospitality sectors worldwide. These campaigns demonstrate ITG14’s continued efforts, despite several arrests since 2018, to attack commercial organizations for financial gain using new methods and malware.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: ITG14 Fielding VBS Loader for Victim Reconnaissance

instruction: Tell me about Signed XLL File Email Attachment Delivers Buer Loader
output:
Certainly.
Signed XLL File Email Attachment Delivers Buer Loader

FortiGuard Labs discovered a spam campaign that was sending out an attached malicious Microsoft Excel document with an .XLL file extension. The file is also signed which will often allow it to evade endpoint security products. The spam campaign is not targeting any particular set of organizations or users from particular countries. After the file is opened, it will download a loader named Buer Loader. Buer Loader is a popular Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) used by various threat actors and can be used to deliver any number of other malware software. This is a newer variant of Buer Loader that has been completely rewritten.

instruction: Tell me about Malvertising Making a Comeback
output:
Certainly.
Malvertising Making a Comeback

New statistics observed by MalwareBytes indicates malvertising is, once again, on the rise. Researchers have seen Raccoon Stealer and RIG exploit kit in their observations. The adult website, xhamster.com, has seen the largest malvertising campaign in more than a year. One malvertising actor was offering bids for ads on adult websites with the majority of victims located within the U.S. with 56% of the observed traffic. A popular ad network, ExoClick, was abused with redirection pages. The first domain used in the campaign was disguised as a web design agency; however the page was simply a decoy page. The actor used server-side cloaking to redirect victims to a Fallout exploit kit landing page. This page attempted to exploit CVE-2019-0752 and CVE-2018-15982. These CVEs attack Internet Explorer and Adobe's Flash Player respectively. Nearly two weeks later, a new domain was used and employed a 302 redirect. This instance used the RIG exploit kit to disseminate Raccoon Stealer. A second malvertiser (malsmoke) has been tracked for months and uses Smoke Loader malware. The actor placed their malicious ad on the xhamster.com website. This campaign used a different and more sophisticated redirection technique with client-side fingerprinting and connectivity checks in an effort to target only legitimate IP addresses. For this attack, both Raccoon Stealer and ZLoader were downloaded and deployed. This group has a propensity to switch ad networks with rapid pace to continually perform its malvertising campaigns. Due to the continued use of Internet Explorer, it is suspected that these attacks and campaigns will continue using the aforementioned CVEs.

instruction: Explain: ESPecter - A Persistant UEFI Bootkit
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for ESPecter - A Persistant UEFI Bootkit:

ESPecter, named by ESET who discovered it, is a UEFI bootkit that traces its roots back to 2012 when it was a legacy BIOS bootkit. According to ESET the major change in the bootkit was the move to targeting UEFI systems with little other change in ESPecter's components. The sample analyzed by ESET was found on a compromised system. Also found was a user-mode client component that has the ability to log keystrokes and steal documents. ESET believes that ESPecter is primarily used for espionage. The method used to distribute ESPecter remains unknown. To achieve the infection of a system, a legitimate Windows Boot Manager binary is modified to allow the attacker to execute ESPecter early in the boot process and provides the ability to bypass Windows Driver Signature Enforcement allowing ESPecter to load its unsigned driver. However, Secure Boot must be disabled for this to work on Windows 8 and later. Secure Boot is not supported on versions of Windows prior to Windows 8. ESET has been unable to determine how the attackers were able to disable Secure Boot but note that they could have achieved it through having physical access to the system, Secure Boot may have already been disabled, or by exploiting a vulnerability in the UEFI firmware. The driver is used to load two user-mode payloads, WinSys.dll and Client.dll, which are used to log keystrokes, take screenshots, collect and exfiltrate documents, handle C&C communications, and can download further payloads. ESET was not able to attribute ESPecter to a known threat actor but given that there are debug messages in Chinese in the user-mode client component, it is possibly the work of an unknown Chinese-speaking actor.

instruction: Tell me about HMRC Phishing Scam Abuses Mail Service
output:
Certainly.
HMRC Phishing Scam Abuses Mail Service

Threat actors continue to abuse and exploit the legitimate email delivery service SendGrid to collect sensitive credentials. By utilizing some of SendGrid’s features, threat actors are able to bypass spam filters and email security products. The malicious webpages in a specific campaign analyzed by BleepingComputer mimic the HMRC and GOV.UK appearance, requesting information such as: UTR number, NINo number, passport number and expiry dates, driving license number, name, DOB and, address information. According to the information BleepingComputer received, what made this campaign so successful was the spoofed “From email” field with an outgoing address likely designed to trick the victim.

instruction: What is Scouts Victoria Hit with Data Breach
output: Here is an overview on Scouts Victoria Hit with Data Breach: Scouts Victoria in Australia was hit with a data breach on September 24, 2020. The unauthorized access occurred through the company's email system via a phishing attack. The attack resulted in two staff email accounts and a shared file folder being compromised. Among the data compromised are names, email addresses, residential addresses, driver's licenses, Medicare information, tax file numbers, and signatures. This data could be potentially harmful to the victims affected as it introduces the possibility of identity theft or even personal attack. "The investigation found that correspondence relating to a number of individuals associated with Scouts Victoria is among the data potentially accessed by unauthorized third parties," a statement from a Scouts Victoria spokesperson said.

"The investigation found that correspondence relating to a number of individuals associated with Scouts Victoria is among the data potentially accessed by unauthorized third parties," a statement from a Scouts Victoria spokesperson said.

instruction: Explain: IcedID Deployed Through Spearphishing
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for IcedID Deployed Through Spearphishing:

FortiGuard Labs analyzed a spearphishing email that was sent to a Ukrainian fuel company. The email was a fake invoice that claimed to be from another fuel company and contained text in both Ukrainian and English. Attached to the email was an archive file that contained an ISO file. When the ISO file was mounted it showed an LNK file named "document". In addition, there was another file named "main.dll". When the LNK file was executed, it used Regsvr32 to register the DLL which was a loader used to deploy IcedID which then used a number of Windows command-line utilities to collect information about the infected system. It would then attempt to communicate with a C&C server chosen from a list and if successful, a copy of the payload was written to a temp directory and registry entries added to make it persistent.

instruction: Provide an overview for: Digital Point Database Exposed Data of 800,000 Users
output: Sure. Here is a description for Digital Point Database Exposed Data of 800,000 Users: On July 1st, researchers at WebsitePlanet identified a public, open Elasticsearch database hosted by Digital Point, a webmaster forum and web related services marketplace. Among the data in the database was user emails, names, internal user IDs, and user posts. The researchers note that threats related to this data include domain hijacking and social engineering. Data related to over 800,000 unique users was included in the leaked database. Upon discovery, the researchers reported their findings to the company, which quickly removed public access to the database; however, the researchers never received any response to their reports.

instruction: Describe the following: Apple Security Updates April 26 2021 - Exploitation in the Wild Reported
output: Apple has published security updates for iCloud for Windows, Xcode, Safari, iOS and iPadOS, watchOS, tvOS, and macOS: Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave. Collectively, the updates address eighty-two CVE-numbered vulnerabilities. The potential impact from successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities are privilege escalation and the remote execution of arbitrary code. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-30657) addressed in the updates for macOS Big Sur and Catalina has been independently reported as being exploited in the wild. Apple notes in their release details that the vulnerability may allow malicious applications to bypass Gatekeeper checks. A report from Jamf notes that a variant of the Shlayer malware is being spread through a malicious application. The application comes as a DMG file, which, when mounted and the contained application executed, will install Shlayer without any quarantine, signature, or notarization verification.

instruction: Tell me about New Group Karakurt Ramping Up Operations To End The Year
output:
Certainly.
New Group Karakurt Ramping Up Operations To End The Year

A new threat group calling themselves "Karakurt" has started ramping up their attacks, according to a report by Accenture Security. This group first emerged in June 2021, where they registered various domains for their use, as well as a Twitter account which was created in August 2021. This group claims to have compromised over 40 victims, without any specific industry being targeted. The majority of these attacks occur in North America, with a small portion occurring in Europe. Their goal seems to be data theft and extortion, rather than destructive encryption often seen with this type of group. Attacks generally start by using legitimate stolen credentials to log into internet-facing systems. It is currently unclear how these credentials are stolen. The group tends to use "living off the land" tools to avoid detection, but has also been known to deploy common tools such as Mimikatz and Cobalt Strike in their attacks to establish persistence and escalate their privileges.

instruction: Provide an overview for: XSS Bug in Google Maps Identified
output: Sure. Here is a description for XSS Bug in Google Maps Identified: Under Google's bug hunter program, a security researcher discovered a bug in Google Maps. The bug starts with the create your own map functionality. Upon building the map, the user is able to export the map in KML. KML is similar to XML with some extra features. In his research, he created a map and exported with KML; however, upon submission of the exported file to the server, some XML responses were received. The culprit in the vulnerability is the inability to close the CDATA tag. Mr. Shachar was able to find a way to close the tag by using special characters at the beginning of the payload. In his case, he used the map name tag. It is at this point where the introduction of arbitrary XML code can be introduced. This leads to the XSS. This discovery and submission of this bug garnered Mr. Shachar a bounty and an email stating the bug had been addressed. In order to check the fix, the researcher performed the same steps and found the only way to close a CDATA tag was to add another CDATA tag. This allowed him to bypass the first fix. This information was passed to Google with the promise of another fix and, for Mr. Shachar, an additional bounty.

instruction: Provide an overview for: SystemBC RAT - New Features and Involved in Ransomware Attacks
output: Sure. Here is a description for SystemBC RAT - New Features and Involved in Ransomware Attacks: SystemBC was originally a SOCKS5 proxy and RAT but recently began using the Tor network for C&C communications. According to a report from Sophos, it has also recently been used, along with other commodity malware, in Ryuk and Egregor ransomware attacks. When initially executed, SystemBC checks if it was started as a service and, if not, creates a copy of itself creates a scheduled task to execute the copy as a service. Each time the scheduled task is run, SystemBC reports certain system information to a C&C server. The domains used by SystemBC are hardcoded in the malware. The C&C communications consist of two parts, a beacon that connects to TCP port 4044 on the remote server, and the Tor communications. Sophos notes that it appears the code used for the Tor communications is based on an open-source library named mini-tor. The capabilities of SystemBC include the ability to perform reconnaissance, exfiltrate data, and run scripts and executable files. Sophos speculates that SystemBC may have been integrated into a ransomware-as-a-service offering.

instruction: What is Molerats Campaign Targeting the Middle East
output: Here is an overview on Molerats Campaign Targeting the Middle East: Molerats, referred to by Proofpoint as TA402, is also known as the Gaza Cybergang. Molerats has been operating since 2011 and has primarily targeted government entities located in Israel, Palestine, and the wider Middle East. Molerats are believed to operate from the Middle East. The current campaign began sending spear-phishing emails, weekly, in February 2021 but beginning in March, ceased the sending of emails for two months before resuming in June. Proofpoint speculates the cessation of emails may be due to Ramadan or the situation between Gaza and Israel through that time period. The campaign is targeting organizations with diplomatic relationships and government entities in the Middle East. The spear-phishing emails sent by Molerats are usually written in Arabic and contain either links or an attached PDF file which is also written in Arabic. The theme of the emails and PDFs typically relate to geopolitical topics relating to the Middle East and in particular, the Gaza conflict. If the attached PDF is opened and macros are enabled, a passworded RAR file that contains an executable file will be dropped onto the system. In other cases, links to a Google Scripts file are used. In all cases, geofencing is used to make sure the victim is located in a region of interest. Users outside the regions of interest are directed to benign websites. The malware delivered in the campaign is referred to by Proofpoint as LastConn and is believed to be an updated version of the SharpStage malware. LastConn is used to carry out reconnaissance and exfiltrate data.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Phishing Campaign Utilizes DocuSign to Evade Detection?
output: Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign using DocuSign to evade security email gateways. By sending the lure as a shared document via DocuSign, security controls will recognize the sender and link within the body as legitimate. The messaging used alongside the share link spoofs a legitimate person and company and references a proposed document. Visiting the link leads to a DocuSign file with an embedded link to supposedly view the document via Adobe Document Cloud. The link uses a shortened URL to redirect users to the final landing page. From here, email credentials are requested and any entered data is exfiltrated to the attacker.

instruction:
Given the description:
Trend Micro's latest paper discusses their findings of a three year old mobile malware package called Joker. In the past, it has been capable of signing its victims up for premium services without their knowledge, compromising SMS messages, and stealing contact information. The code is in constant flux in attempts to bypass Google Play's security defenses. Another means of skirting Google security is to provide a non-malicious version of the application on Google Play that then "updates" itself with malicious code. The sample examined was found to use Github as its malicious payload repository. As a lure to entice victims to download and install, Joker claims to be a HD and 4K wallpaper application. Joker has been known to only infect devices with specific SIM cards from a selected few countries. This particular sample appears to only infect devices in Thailand.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Github Hides Joker's Payload

instruction:
Given the description:
Xen has published three advisories detailing issues that have been patched.

  
XSA-345 describes a race condition within the code that handles the hypervisor's page tables. A malicious guest operating system could use this oversight to cause the hypervisor to write to a page that had been freed. This could potentially cause data corruption, privilege escalation, or a denial of service condition.

  
XSA-346 corrects an issue that occurs when guest pages are coalesced. Due to possible removal of pages from guest pages, the fragmentation may not be accounted for during the coalesced flush. Potential impacts include data corruption, data leaks, privilege escalation, or denial of service condition.

  
XSA-346 addresses an issue with an AMD CPU that updates memory table entries in a step-by-step fashion. This could potentially result in the IOMMU accessing a partially updated table entry. Data corruption, data leaks, privilege escalation, or denial of service condition are potential outcomes.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Xen Advisories - October 2020

instruction: What is MosesStaff Targeting Israeli Countries
output: Here is an overview on MosesStaff Targeting Israeli Countries: Check Point published a blog post analyzing MosesStaff's tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) and payloads. The group began targeting Israeli organizations in Septemeber 2021 and, unlike many other threat actors, encrypts and leaks data without a ransom demand, solely operating for political purposes. Initial access is obtained via exploitation of public-facing applications, such as Microsoft Exchange. Vulnerabilities are exploited in order to install a basic webshell. The webshell is, in turn, used to drop several scripts and tools onto the system. With access obtained, the attackers begin to perform reconnaissance. A payload named PyDCrypt is used to decrypt drop a secondary payload (DCSrv) and PSExec, modify firewall rules to allow SMB, Netbios, and RPC, spread its infection to other hosts on the network, and clean up artifacts. DCSrv, based on DiskCryptor, is used to carry out the group's main goal of encrypting systems and installing a boot loader to prevent access. Attribution is unknown, but the researchers note that the group appears to be operating out of the Middle East based on file metadata.

instruction: What is Amnesty Report on FinSpy Activity
output: Here is an overview on Amnesty Report on FinSpy Activity: Amnesty’s Security Lab has been tracking FinSpy usage due to its use in a number of operations to spy on what Amnesty describe as Human Rights Defenders. FinSpy is commercial spyware developed by the German company FinFisher Gmbh. Amnesty has observed variants of FinSpy for Windows, Mac, Linux, and Android. In its report, Amnesty looks at the NilePhish group who developed several droppers which include a fake Flash Player updater, macro enabled Word documents, and a .NET application. Early in 2020, NilePhish began testing Cobalt Strike, using an obfuscated VB script for installation. The versions of FinSpy for Mac and Linux share very similar modules which Amnesty notes could indicate a shared codebase, the launchers and infection chain are modified for Linux. All versions are configurable and employ various techniques to hinder detection and analysis.

instruction: Tell me about CrimsonIAS Backdoor
output:
Certainly.
CrimsonIAS Backdoor

ThreatConnect published their analysis of the CrimsonIAS backdoor, including potential attribution. The backdoor operates on Windows hosts, is written in Delphi, and dates back to at least 2017. Upon execution, the malware points to the MZ header to run embedded shell code. The shell code is responsible for calling a reflective loader function that loads the binary and jumps to its entry point. Unlike most Windows backdoors that beacon to a C2 server to retrieve commands, CrimsonIAS simply opens a listener that waits to receive commands from the attacker. There are three available commands an attacker can pass to the backdoor: run a command, receive a file, or send a file. Researchers believe that this backdoor could potentially be attributed to the Mustang Panda APT due to a few key similarities. First, the payload is encrypted with an XOR key that is prepended to the binary. Additionally, it leverages the MZ header to store shell code. Lastly, an exported library named Loader is used to reflectively load the binary. This also means that existing Mustang Panda PlugX archives could be used to launch CrimsonIAS instead of a PlugX DLL.

instruction: Describe the following: IBM Security Guardium Security Bulletin January 20 2021
output: IBM has published a security bulletin addressing vulnerabilities in IBM Security Guardium. Security Bulletin 6405952 addresses two vulnerabilities in the IBM Java SDK which is used by Guardium. If successfully exploited, the vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the system via command injection, or a remote attacker to view, add, modify or delete information in the back-end database via SQL injection.

instruction: Describe the following: Credential Stealing Malware Uses AHK
output: Trend Micro discovered a credential stealing campaign that began in early 2020. The campaign has mainly targeted the customers of Canadian and U.S. banks. A malicious Excel file is used to kick off the infection chain by using a VBA AutoOpen macro to drop an AHK script compiler and an AHK script file. AHK is an open-source scripting language that runs on Windows. When the compiler is executed, it runs the script which is a client for downloading and executing further AHK payloads. It is also used for creating persistence by creating an autorun link in the startup folder and profiling the victim system. Commands issued to the malware by its C&C server are downloaded as individual scripts for each task. This means there is no single, large payload on the victim system and allows the operator to create custom commands for victims as required. The malware's primary function is to steal credentials from victims' browsers. The browsers it targets include Edge, Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox, and Opera.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for ICS-CERT Advisories April 29 2021?
output: The ICS-CERT has published 4 advisories that affect Texas Instruments SimpleLink, Cassia Networks Access Controller, Johnson Controls Exacq Technologies exacqVision, and Multiple RTOS. The Multiple RTOS advisory (ICSA-21-119-04) covers the "BadAlloc" vulnerabilities in real-time operating systems (RTOS) published by Microsoft.

instruction: Provide an overview for: New npm Malware With Bladabindi Trojan Spotted
output: Sure. Here is a description for New npm Malware With Bladabindi Trojan Spotted: Over the Thanksgiving holiday, Sonatype discovered two malicious npm packages named jdb.js and db-json.js. According to the analyst, jdb.js contains the credential stealing RAT, njRAT. The npm package contained three files and conducts multiple malicious activities such as: data gathering, reconnaissance, and launching patch.exe which is the njRAT dropper. Before C2 communication is initiated, the malicious executable edits Windows firewall rules to avoid connection and communication issues. The db-json.js package eludes malicious intention by appearing to be a safe and legitimate JSON DB creation package but works in conjunction with the jdb.js package. According to the analyst, what was even more interesting, was the effective implementation of the db-json.js package. After infecting the desired target, the end-user’s machine is then open to a multitude of nefarious acts, granting the attacker the ability to, log keystrokes, alter registry values, inaugurate system shutdown, initially granting a level of C2 to the attacker. Furthermore, putting developers at risk who may be unaware of the malware.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for Aggah Campaign Using Zendesk and GitHub to Host Malicious Files?
output: Aggah malware campaigns have in the past been known to host malicious content on legitimate services such as BlogSpot, Pastebin, and WordPress. According to a report from Juniper Threat Labs, an Aggah campaign is now using Github and Zendesk to host malicious files. Juniper analyzed a malicious PowerPoint file that was downloaded from Zendesk. The file contained a macro that used mshta.exe to download and execute a malicious script from Blogspot. One of the operations the script carries out is to add a registry run key that is used to trigger the download of another PowerShell script that contains the Oski infostealer. Another PowerShell script that is downloaded from GitHub installs the Agent Tesla infostealer and RAT.

instruction: Provide an overview for: FormBook Exploits Office 365 0-Day Vulnerability
output: Sure. Here is a description for FormBook Exploits Office 365 0-Day Vulnerability: Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing a campaign distributing a new variant of the FormBook infostealer. Like previous FormBook campaigns, the infection chain begins with a malicious Word document attached to a phishing email. If opened, the document exploits CVE-2021-40444, a recent Office 365 0-Day remote code execution vulnerability. The exploit implements anti-debugging techniques to protect the JavaScript code from analysis. Successful exploitation leads to the download of a first-stage PowerShell script, which simply downloads the second-stage PowerShell script hosted on the Discord CDN. Finally, a .NET injector is used to execute the FormBook payload, which can then be used to steal sensitive data.

instruction: Describe the following: Dropping the Anchor Trickbot Anchor Analysis
output: Known as Anchor_Linux, this malware carries a Windows executable created to infect Linux and Windows systems on the same network by dropping and executing payloads on Windows machines. According to the analysts, the malware functions as a backdoor tool in the UNIX environment, allowing the malware to maneuver to Window machines. Analysts at NetScout also discovered threat actors began porting the Anchor_DNS malware components of the Trickbots code on to Linux operating systems, maximizing their ability to covertly communicate with C2 Servers and infect more machines. According to the analysts, operators of this version of Trickbot are still building on to the many capabilities of the malware, and encourage end-users operating on Linux systems and IoT devices to have sufficient protection and monitoring in place to assist with identifying and eradicating threats like Anchor_Linux.

instruction:
Given the description:
Cofense published a blog post analyzing a campaign leveraging nested archives to deliver the BazarBackdoor. Some email security gateways (SEGs) will be unable to identify nested archives as malicious due to limitations of how many layers of compression can be analyzed. In this case, the body of the email simply mentioned a proposed event for Environmental Day with references to the attached RAR and ZIP files. Both of these archives contained two additional layers of compression with the same format. Decompression eventually leads to an obfuscated JavaScript file that downloads a payload with a PNG extension over HTTP. Although it masquerades as a PNG, in reality the file is a BazarBackdoor executable. Once on the system, BazarBackdoor provides its operators with the ability to establish a foothold and deploy additional malware.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: BazarBackdoor Delivered via Nested Archives

instruction:
Given the description:
Akamai published a blog post analyzing a unique cryptomining package. The malware appears to originate from Romania based on the presence of Romanian strings in multiple files. As with many cryptominers, the malware is delivered inside a TAR package. This TAR, however, contained additional files of interest. First, it contained two XMRig miners, one with TLS support and one without. A base64-encoded, modified version of Perl Bot v1.0 was also included. Perl Bot is a DDoS attack tool that leverages IRC for C2 communication. The installation script is a simple shell script that clears shell history, sets the shell to not track history, ensures all the files are executable, and then runs several of the files. The files executed include a script to kill of existing cryptomining infections, a compiled library to hide malicious processes, and a script to establish persistence via cron job entries.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Romanian Cryptomining Infection

instruction: Explain: February 2021 Update on Iran’s Nuclear Program
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for February 2021 Update on Iran’s Nuclear Program:

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has provided an update on Iran's nuclear program beginning with January 2020 to present. Major milestones of the reporting include Iran's withdrawal from JCPOA in January 2020. In March 2020, Iran announced the installation of centrifuges at its Natanz facility. April 2020 saw the re-opening of the Bushehr nuclear facility. In July 2020, there was a report of an explosion at the Natanz facility that severely damaged the facility. November 2020 saw the installation of additional centrifuges at the Natanz facility. December 2020 revealed a report from IAEA about the possible installation of even more centrifuges, which was confirmed by satellite images. Finally, January 2021 revealed Iran was developing uranium metal, used in nuclear weapons.

instruction: Describe the following: Investigating an Infection Chain
output: During an investigation, analysts from Trend Micro noticed an unusual event. A process, nslookup.exe, had been executed and attempted query a malicious URL. While not necessarily suspicious, the researchers investigated further to find that certutil had also been executed. In this case certutil was used to decode a file named Roccia.xltm to Fu.mp4, which is, in reality, an SFX CAB archive that contains four other files. A setup routine was executed that checks for various conditions that, if met, will exit. Eventually, the routine leads to the spawning of a process-hollowed copy of nslookup.exe, which is what triggered the researchers interest. The hollowed nslookup.exe is used to obtain the payload, which was determined to be an information stealer that compresses and uploads any information obtained to the malware's C&C server. It was discovered that the whole process had commenced when a user executed a file named setup_x86_x64_install.exe.

instruction: What is White Rabbit Evasion Techniques Analyzed
output: Here is an overview on White Rabbit Evasion Techniques Analyzed: White Rabbit is a new ransomware family discovered by Trend Micro with a potential connection to the threat group Fin8. It looks like it could be loaded onto systems using systems already compromised and infected with Cobalt Strike. Trend Micro has published details of the evasion tactics used by the malware. The payload is a small file with no notable strings or activity. The way to activate the ransomware and decrypt the internal configuration is via a command-line password - a technique also used by the ransomware family Egregor. Upon execution, White Rabbit will terminate several processes, including processes related to antivirus. Once complete, the ransomware drops a ransom note which threatens to leak the victim's stolen data if the ransom is not paid.

instruction: Tell me about Malicious Advertising Used To Trick Victims
output:
Certainly.
Malicious Advertising Used To Trick Victims

Talos researchers have identified a new distribution campaign using fake software installers to trick users into installing malware. They speculate that this campaign uses false advertising to reach potential victims into using the fake installers of legitimate software. The end goal of this campaign is to deliver three pieces of malware to the victim. The first is a commodity password stealer. At first, Azorult was used, but more recently the attacker has been using RedLine. The second piece of malware is a backdoor, which has been named "MagnatBackdoor". This backdoor prepares the system for RDP access and periodically ping the C2 server. Finally, the installer adds a chrome extension (called "MagnatExtension" by the researchers) which can steal data from the browser and execute code. The victims of this campaign are fairly focused in Canada, with some infections seen in the US and Australia. This is consistent with the use of malvertizing as a distribution method.

instruction: Describe the following: Trickbot Modules
output: When Trickbot surfaced in 2016, it was primarily a banking Trojan. Since 2016, many features have been added to Trickbot. Its current primary use is in initial infections, spreading within a LAN, providing initial access to others, and acting as a loader for other malware, as it has done for the Ryuk ransomware. A report from Kaspersky provides a list of more than sixty Trickbot modules, and a description of their functionality. The functionality the modules provide includes the ability to steal credentials and sensitive information, spread itself within a LAN using either stolen credentials or exploiting vulnerabilities, act as a proxy, conduct brute-force attacks, and provide remote access, as well as acting as a loader for other payloads. So far in 2021, just under 50% of Trickbot's victims are located in only five countries, which are in order, the USA, Australia, China, Mexico, and France.

instruction:
Given the description:
The Mozilla Foundation has released Firefox 88.0.1 and Firefox for Android 88.1.3. There are two vulnerabilities addressed in the update of which one is rated as Critical and one as High. The critical vulnerability only affects the Android version and potentially leaves the browser vulnerable to a universal cross-site scripting attack. The high rated vulnerability could potentially be exploited to execute arbitrary code remotely. Also released are Firefox ESR 78.10.1 and Thunderbird 78.10.1. Both of these updates address a single vulnerability which on versions of Windows 10 prior to build 1709, could potentially allow a remote attacker to stop the browser update service.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Mozilla Security Advisories - May 5 2021

instruction: What is Malicious Run-Only AppleScripts
output: Here is an overview on Malicious Run-Only AppleScripts: SentintelOne has improved its capabilities with regard to analyzing run-only AppleScripts in order to analyzing a cryptominer campaign that has been operating for at least five years. Since its original appearance, the malware has evolved to use multiple run-only scripts and retrieve additional payloads hosted in the source code of external websites. The first AppleScripts file is responsible for establishing persistence via plist, running, and executing an embedded secondary AppleScripts file, downloading the first stage of the cryptominer, and gathering system information. The secondary AppleScripts file is used for anti-analysis and evasion tasks, such as killing security software and system monitoring processes. The first URL contacted by the parent script for downloading the next stage has a URL embedded in the source code, which points to a payload masquerading as a PNG. The downloaded file is a cryptominer set up script for XMR-STAK-RX, an open source Monero miner. The setup script configures the miner with a pool address, password, and other configuration information. A folder is created that drops config files and a compressed folder. When decompressed, a Mach-O executable is revealed, leading to the download and installation of the final XMR-STAK miner payload.

instruction: Provide an overview for: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - December 17th, 2020
output:
Sure. Here is a description for ICS-CERT Security Advisories - December 17th, 2020: ICS-CERT has released three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related devices and software.

ICSA-20-352-01 addresses an improper authentication vulnerability in Emerson's Rosemount X-STREAM that, if successfully exploited, could allow an attacker to download files and obtain sensitive information.

ICSA-20-352-02 addresses three vulnerabilities in PTC's Kepware KEPServerEX. These include a stack-based buffer overflow, heap-based buffer overflow, and use after free vulnerability. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include a denial-of-service condition, data leakage, or remote code execution.

ICSA-20-352-03 addresses an incorrect default permissions issue with PTC's Kepware LinkMaster that, if successfully exploited, could allow a local attacker to globally overwrite the service configuration to execute arbitrary code with NT SYSTEM privileges.

instruction: Tell me about CISA Issues Alert on BlackMatter Ransomware
output:
Certainly.
CISA Issues Alert on BlackMatter Ransomware

The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) issued alert AA21-291A on the BlackMatter ransomware. BlackMatter is a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) group, operating on an affiliate model where they profit from those who purchase the payload for use. The sample analyzed as part of the alert uses embedded, previously-compromised credentials to perform its operations. First, running processes and services are enumerated. Then network reconnaissance is performed using LDAP, SMB, and MSRPC. It has the capability to encrypt discovered remote shared over SMB. Additionally, a separate binary exists for the encryption of Linux and ESXi hosts. Backups are completely wiped or reformatted instead of being encrypted. Outside of the capabilities provided by the ransomware payload, tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) observed in BlackMatter incidents may vary depending on the affiliate carrying out the attack.

instruction: Tell me about Android Malware TeaBot Targets Banks in Europe
output:
Certainly.
Android Malware TeaBot Targets Banks in Europe

TeaBot (aka Anatsa) is a Trojan banking app in the Android landscape. Upon analysis by the researchers, this Trojan does not appear to be related to any other banking Trojan family. TeaBot is used to steal credentials and SMS messages for fraudulent actions against more than 60 banks. Interestingly, the trojan allows for a "livestream" view of the victim device as well as providing the ability for interacting through Accessibility Services. Injections were first observed in March 2021 against Italian banks. In May 2021, injections were seen against Belgium and Netherlands-based banks. At present, the trojan appears to be in early development. Other capabilities seen include key logging, stealing Google Authentication codes, and full remote control over an Android device. Anti-analysis techniques are implemented, such as junk code, a dynamic 2nd stage, and partially encrypted network communications using an XOR algorithm.

instruction: Describe the following: Debian Redis Servers Being Exploited to Deploy Muhstik Bot
output: Beginning on March 11th, Juniper Threat Labs observed an attack targeting a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2022-0543) in Redis servers used in certain versions of Debian Linux. According to Juniper's report, the actors behind the attack have previously exploited vulnerabilities in Confluence and Log4j. If exploitation is successful, wget or curl are used to download a file named "russia.sh" which is then executed. The file downloads and executes binaries that Juniper identifies as variants of the Muhstik bot. Muhstik is a bot that connects to an IRC server and has the ability to download files, execute shell commands, brute force SSH, and participate in DoS attacks.

instruction: What is A New Campaign Using Trickbot
output: Here is an overview on A New Campaign Using Trickbot: In the past, Trickbot campaigns typically used malicious documents as the infection vector, A new campaign observed by Menlo Security, that delivers Trickbot, is instead using URLs contained in emails. The links lead to a page, that in the example shown in the report, alleges the recipient has committed a traffic violation and provides a link that supposedly, provides more information. The link leads to a .zip file that contains a malicious JavaScript file which will download and execute the payload. The insurance and legal sectors are reported to have been targeted by the campaign.

instruction:
Given the description:
RansomExx has undergone some developmental improvements which allow for the infiltration of Linux servers in addition to Windows servers. Trend Micro researchers have found evidence of RansomExx compromising companies in the U.S., Canada, and Brazil. They were also able to observe Linux variant activity. The campaign is using IcedID as its infiltration vector. Vatet loader is the payload delivery method and Pyxie and Cobalt Strike as post-intrusion tools. The entire attack took about 5 hours to complete. Initially, a phishing email with an attached password-protected ZIP file is used as a lure. The ZIP file is actually a macro-infected Word document. The document downloads the IcedID Trojan from a malicious URL. IcedID uses steganography to deliver the payload by using a PNG file. Once decrypted, the payload is injected into memory and persistence is accomplished via a scheduled task that runs hourly by using regsvr32.exe to execute the malicious DLL. Once Cobalt Strike is deployed, it attempts to connect to the C2 server. This step then collects machine information and moves laterally. Vatet loader is used to deliver any payload that uses the correct XOR operation. At present, infection vectors to Linux servers is unknown with 3 separate RansomExx observed.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: RansomExx Improving and Expanding Capabilities

instruction: Tell me about Three Quarters of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack
output:
Certainly.
Three Quarters of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack

Unit 42 has done an in-depth study on the state of security in the healthcare sector. Specifically, in connected devices that are accessible over the internet. The study looked at results from open-source scans of over 200,000 infusion pumps on hospital networks. They found that 75% of the infusion pumps that were scanned had known security issues. Together, the pumps represented almost 40 different known security vulnerabilities, as well as almost 70 other known security issues commonly found in IoT devices. A more alarming statistic was that over 50% of the pumps were vulnerable to two known vulnerabilities that were rated 'critical' and 'high' severity. The majority of vulnerabilities were found to be related to sensitive information leakage. There were also several vulnerabilities that would allow a malicious actor to take a device offline, or give them unauthorized access to the device.

parsed_raw_data.title: Three Quarters of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack
parsed_raw_data.overview: Unit 42 has done an in-depth study on the state of security in the healthcare sector. Specifically, in connected devices that are accessible over the internet. The study looked at results from open-source scans of over 200,000 infusion pumps on hospital networks. They found that 75% of the infusion pumps that were scanned had known security issues. Together, the pumps represented almost 40 different known security vulnerabilities, as well as almost 70 other known security issues commonly found in IoT devices. A more alarming statistic was that over 50% of the pumps were vulnerable to two known vulnerabilities that were rated 'critical' and 'high' severity. The majority of vulnerabilities were found to be related to sensitive information leakage. There were also several vulnerabilities that would allow a malicious actor to take a device offline, or give them unauthorized access to the device.

instruction: What is Commercial Spyware Operation Uncovered
output: Here is an overview on Commercial Spyware Operation Uncovered: A report from Citizen Lab looks into a commercial spyware operation. The spyware can infect devices running Android, iOS, macOS, Windows, and also monitor cloud accounts. Leaked documentation suggests the spyware can be installed in a number of different ways including through malicious links, man-in-the-middle attacks, and physical attacks. There is another vector offered which claims to be able to install the spyware on Android, iOS, and Windows, which Citizen Lab speculates may be a browser-based zero-click vector. The documentation notes that the spyware can steal and exfiltrate data from a variety of applications and accounts including Facebook, Gmail, Skype, Telegram, and web browsers. It also has the ability to take screenshots and turn on an infected device's microphone and webcam. Additional modules are offered for sale, including a remote shell that allows the operator access to the infected device. Fees for the spyware and additional modules, based on the number of devices infected and monitored, can run into tens of millions of Euros. A notable feature of the operation's infrastructure is the use of domain names that often impersonate media and advocacy organizations.

instruction: What is Industroyer2 Targets Ukrainian Energy Company
output: Here is an overview on Industroyer2 Targets Ukrainian Energy Company: ESET researchers recently collaborated with the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) to investigate suspicious computer network activities directed at a Ukrainian energy provider. ESET personnel discovered a variant of Industroyer malware used in the attack and are referring to the new loader as Industroyer2. Industroyer malware was used in 2016 by Sandworm, a Russian cyber threat actor, to cause a power blackout that affected the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv. Reporting indicates that Sandworm is now utilizing Industroyer2 to target a Ukrainian energy provider. Sandworm attempted to deploy Industroyer2 against high-voltage electrical substations. The Industroyer2 malware targets Linux and Solaris instances and loads destructive malware families including CaddyWiper, Orcshred, Soloshred, and Awfulshred. The process launched by the attacker was a worm that was used for the wiper component. Industroyer2 was deployed as a single Windows executable and shares a number of code similarities with Industroyer.

instruction:
Given the description:
GitLab published a security release on April 14, 2021, to address a critical remote code execution vulnerability in the service's web interface. The vulnerability was originally identified by GitLab as an authenticated vulnerability caused by passing user-supplied photos to the service's embedded version of ExifTool. ExifTool's mishandling of the files could allow a remote attacker to run arbitrary commands as the git user. Since being published, the vulnerability has been upgraded to critical, as it has become clear that authentication is not required to exploit it. There have since been multiple exploits for CVE-2021-22205 published, and it is being actively exploited in the wild. Patches for the GitLab vulnerability have been available for over six months. However, an examination of GitLab instances that are accessible via the internet indicates that a significant proportion are still susceptible. GitLab users should update to the most recent version as soon as possible. Furthermore, GitLab should ideally not be an internet-facing service. Consider putting your GitLab behind a VPN if you need to access it from the internet.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Critical GitLab Vulnerability Exploited In The Wild

instruction: Tell me about Skimmers Being Spread By Cloud Video Platform
output:
Certainly.
Skimmers Being Spread By Cloud Video Platform

Palo Alto researchers have discovered a skimmer attack that is affecting over 100 real estate sites. They have determined that the source of this attack was a supply chain attack, where the attackers have leveraged a cloud video platform to allow them to reach a greater number of victims. The attackers injected malicious JavaScript into a specific video hosted on the cloud platform. Any site importing this video will also be infected, without the attackers having to perform any further attacks. The researchers also observed the attackers modify the script and re-upload it, which was then propagated to all previously infected sites. This is far more efficient than manually updating the skimmer on each site. The researchers retrieved the code from a compromised site and found that it was highly obfuscated to deter manual code analysis. Furthermore, the script includes code to detect if the code is being debugged and stops if the browser console is open. The end goal of this script is to steal any entered personal details such as names, emails, phone numbers, and credit card details and send them to a collection server.

instruction: Describe the following: South Korean and Australian Users Targeted with Malicious Emails Disguised as Accounting Ledgers
output: Bitdefender published a brief blog post detailing a malspam campaign targeting users in South Korea and Australia. The body of the email simply claims an "account ledger" is attached for review, enticing the recipient to open the malicious file. This theme aligns with upcoming filing deadlines for income tax returns in South Korea, increasing the chances a user may believe these claims. Opening the attached file leads to the execution of malware on the victim system. Specifically, a remote access Trojan (RAT) is installed, allowing the attackers capabilities such as accessing sensitive information, taking screenshots, monitoring user activity, and downloading additional payloads.

instruction: What is Intezer discovers New Linux Backdoor Named RedXOR
output: Here is an overview on Intezer discovers New Linux Backdoor Named RedXOR: Intezer discovered a new, sophisticated backdoor targeting Linux systems. It's likely to have been developed by Chinese nation-state actors based on the TTPs observed. Intezer has named the backdoor RedXOR due to it's encoding scheme based on XOR. RedXOR masquerades itself as polkit daemon. Intezer compares the similarities between RedXOR and malware PWNLNX backoodr, XOR.DDOR and Groundhog botnet, all attributed to Winnti. The backdoor is capable of a reverse shell, updating itself, file operations, remote command execution, and running as a proxy.

instruction: Describe the following: Internet Being Actively Scanned for ZeroLogon Vulnerable Servers
output: Kevin Beaumont has posted his findings on DoublePulsar regarding the expansion of his honeypot to include systems vulnerable to the ZeroLogon vulnerability. Microsoft patched this vulnerability in their August patch release. The Active Directory server he used was fully patched up to Microsoft's July release. Ports 135 (MS-RPC), 445 (SMB), and RPC high ports were left open to the Internet while all other ports were blocked. On September 26th, his server received hundreds of login attempts that closely matched the ZeroLogon exploit chain. These attempts were successful in resetting the domain controller's admin password to a blank password. All of the attempts were from the same IP address, listed in the IoCs section below. The successful exploitation of the ZeroLogon vulnerability was accomplished without any credentials and provided the attacker with full remote code execution ability.

instruction:
Given the description:
ESET researchers have been tracking a new variant of Korplug they are calling Hodur. This is being spread by the threat actors Mustang Panda via a phishing campaign. The campaign dates to at least August 2021 and is ongoing. The phishing lures are continually updated and reference current affairs such as COVID-19 restrictions and the invasion of Ukraine. Targets of this campaign are mostly located in East and Southeast Asia with a focus on Mongolia, and the industries targeted include diplomatic missions, ISPs, and research entities. The malicious attachment downloads a legitimate executable, a malicious module, and an encrypted Korplug file. Using DLL search hijacking, the malicious module is executed using the legitimate executable, which then decrypts and executes the payload.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: New Korplug Variant Spread Via Phishing Lures

instruction:
Given the description:
GDATA has published a blog post analyzing a new Java RAT, dubbed "STRRAT," and its infection chain. Targets first receive a spam email claiming to be associated with a "new order." Attached to the email is a JAR file. Notably, Outlook does not allow JAR attachments to be opened without a Registry override, reducing the chance that users will be able to open the file. If a user is able to open it, the file acts as a dropper for a VBScript that leverages PowerShell to execute a secondary script. The secondary script attempts to install Java Runtime Environment (JRE) and add it to the Registry, a strange step given JRE already needed to be installed for the initial JAR attachment to be executed. The script also writes the final RAT payload to the system as a JAR file and creates a Registry Run key for persistence. This payload is packed using Allatori and the configuration file is encrypted using AES. Once connected to its C2 server, the RAT can receive a variety of commands from its operator including those related to file operations, command execution, remote desktop connections, keylogging, credential harvesting, and more. Additionally, a supposed "ransomware" module exists, but rather than encrypting files it simply appends a new extension and does not drop a ransom note. In the campaign observed by G DATA, German users were being targeted.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: STRRAT Java RAT

instruction: Tell me about New Magecart Group 12 Skimmer
output:
Certainly.
New Magecart Group 12 Skimmer

MalwareBytes published a blog post analyzing a newly observed PHP web skimmer tied to Magecart Group 12. This skimmer was found targeting end-of-life Magento 1.x servers, as have previously been targeted by Magecart Group 12. The group uploads a PHP file masquerading as a PNG favicon file to the comprised ecommerce site. The PHP file operates as a malicious web shell, providing the attackers backdoor access. One of the functions of this webshell is to retrieve base64-encoded JavaScript code from a remote server. Analysis of this code reveals credit card skimming capabilities. Unlike many client-side skimming attacks, the use of the web shell to dynamically load the skimming code leads to the attack remaining server-side, making detection more difficult. Attribution to Magecart Group 12 was made due to shared infrastructure and the usage of fake favicon files.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for IBM Security Guardium Vulnerability - Execution with Unnecessary Privileges?
output: IBM Security Guardium is affected by a vulnerability that is caused by an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required. This could allow an attacker to obtain sensitive data, cause issues with integrity, or cause a partial denial of service. Versions of Guardium 11.2 are affected. An update is available that mitigates the issue.

instruction: Tell me about APT28 Exploiting Follina Vulnerability in Campaign Targeting Ukraine
output:
Certainly.
APT28 Exploiting Follina Vulnerability in Campaign Targeting Ukraine

APT28, also commonly referred to as Sofacy or Fancy Bear, is believed to be a Russian state-sponsored APT actor that is thought to have been active since at least 2004. A report from Malwarebytes Labs looks at a recent campaign conducted by APT28 that targeted Ukraine and delivers a malicious document named "Nuclear Terrorism A Very Real Threat.rtf". While the report doesn't specify the delivery mechanism for the document, spearphishing emails would be the likely vector. The document exploits the Follina vulnerability to deliver and execute PowerShell code that deploys a variant of an unnamed infostealer that APT28 has used in previous attacks. The infostealer collects website credentials and cookies from the Chrome, Edge, and Firefox web browsers. The collected data is then exfiltrated using the IMAP protocol.

instruction: Tell me about Chinese APT Group Cicada Conducting Sustained Espionage Campaign
output:
Certainly.
Chinese APT Group Cicada Conducting Sustained Espionage Campaign

Cicada, also known as APT10, has been linked to espionage operations dating back to 2009. Symantec has discovered a new campaign starting in mid-2021 targeting a much broader scope than the initial activity which targeted Japanese-linked companies. The new campaign targets a wide range of Government and non-governmental organizations in multiple countries. In a number of instances, initial access was gained on Microsoft Exchange servers, hinting that there may have been a zero-day vulnerability used in the attacks on Exchange servers. Once access was gained, the group used a custom loader and a backdoor called Sodamaster. This malware is believed to be used exclusively by Cicada, which allows for attribution. It is a fileless malware that can evade detection and collect system information, as well as download more malware. It can also obfuscate and encrypt C2 traffic.

instruction:
Given the description:
The Uptycs threat research team has been tracking the activities of the Black Basta ransomware group. The ransomware, which was first seen in April 2022, now appears to be infecting ESXi servers. Researchers were able to attribute this behavior to the group behind Black Basta due to the similarities in the encrypted file extension and the chat support link. In this example, the ransomware looks for the directory which stores the virtual machines on the server and encrypts the files present. Multithreading is used to speed up the encryption process, and the malware uses the fast 'chacha20' encryption algorithm.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Black Basta Ransomware Now Targeting ESXi Systems

instruction:
Given the description:
Cisco Talos recently discovered a campaign operated by the North Korean Kimsuky APT group delivering malware to high-value South Korean targets — namely geopolitical and aerospace research agencies. The attackers used Blogspot in this campaign to host their malicious artifacts. These blogs delivered three previously unseen components - an initial beacon script, an exfiltrator, and an implant instrumentor. This instrumentor delivers three further modules, used for internal reconnaissance and keylogging. Although these modules are all previously unknown, they share a large portion of their code with the Gold Dragon/Brave Prince family of implants. This has allowed the researchers to attribute this activity to Kimsuky with high confidence. In this campaign, there is a strong focus on finding documents associated with North Korea. The research also showed that the attackers were targeting aerospace companies with work relating to South Korea. The attackers were focusing on restricted research papers and project design documents to steal.

To which threat report this description is related to?
output: Kimsuky Using Blog Sites to Deliver Malware

instruction: Provide an overview for: Ukrainian Organizations Targeted by Destructive Malware
output: Sure. Here is a description for Ukrainian Organizations Targeted by Destructive Malware: Ukrainian organizations are being targeted with destructive malware that overwrites the MBR of an infected system according to a report from Microsoft. No notable associations between these attacks which began on January 13th and attacks by known threat groups have been located by Microsoft and they are tracking the actor behind this activity as DEV-0586. Microsoft has named the malware WhisperGate. There is no information in the Microsoft report as to the vector used to deploy the malware onto systems. The malware itself pretends to be ransomware and is executed in two stages, the first of which is executed when the system is powered down and overwrites the system's MBR with a fake ransom note. In all cases, the ransom notes ask for $10,000 and contain the same Bitcoin wallet address and Tox chat ID. WhisperGate's second stage is a downloader that is used to download a file corrupter which searches the system for files that match a hard-coded list of specific extensions and when found overwrites the file's content with a fixed number of 0xCC bytes and changes the file's extension to what appears to be a random four-byte extension. At the time the Microsoft report was written, Microsoft noted that the malware has been located in dozens of systems belonging to government, and information technology and non-profit organizations located in Ukraine.

instruction: What is VMware Security Advisory - December 15th, 2020
output: Here is an overview on VMware Security Advisory - December 15th, 2020: VMWare has published a security advisory, VMSA-2020-0028, addressing a vulnerability in VMware Carbon Black Cloud macOS Sensor. CVE-2020-4008 is a vulnerability resulting from an installer file overwrite issue. Exploiting the vulnerability requires the malicious actor to have local access to the macOS endpoint and timing the exploit to occur at a specific point in the install process. A patch has been released to fix the issue.

instruction: Can you please give me and overview for 4 Types of Dropper Malware in Microsoft Office & How to Detect Them?
output: Deep Instinct researched activity that involves the use of dropper malware utilizing Microsoft Office. A threat group known as Aggah is assessed to be conducting operations to deliver malware such as RevengeRAT. This threat actor utilizes Microsoft Office documents. One technique to evade detection used by Aggah in their VBA scripts is to include the string "MsgBox" in comments as this may lead AI-based detection tools to identify the code as "benign". The report also details how Dridex and Emotet droppers obfuscate their malicious VBA code in Microsoft documents.

One technique to evade detection used by Aggah in their VBA scripts is to include the string "MsgBox" in comments as this may lead AI-based detection tools to identify the code as "benign". The report also details how Dridex and Emotet droppers obfuscate their malicious VBA code in Microsoft documents.

instruction: Tell me about New MirrorBlast Campaign Targets Financial Companies
output:
Certainly.
New MirrorBlast Campaign Targets Financial Companies

Morphisec published a blog post detailing recent MirrorBlast activity. The campaign began in September and is targeting financial institutions. The infection chain begins with a phishing email either with a malicious Excel file attached or a link to download the Excel file. Macros within the Excel file are used to download and install a Windows MSI package via msiexec. During their research, Morphisec uncovered two variants of the installer: a Rebol version and a KiXstart version. In both cases, the installer drops the required language interpreter along with the malicious script. Finally, the script connects to a remote server to download a next-stage payload. At the time of analysis, Morphisec was unable to obtain this payload, but another researcher identified the FlawedGrace RAT as the final payload in the attack chain. Between the use of the FlawedGrace RAT, the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used by the threat actor, overlapping indicators, and the targeting, Morphisec has attributed this activity to TA505.

instruction: Describe the following: JobCrypter Ransomware Analysis
output: Yoroi has recently observed the JobCrypter ransomware active in campaigns across Italy, despite its relative simplicity to the larger, double extortion ransomware groups widely discussed across the cyber landscape. This ransomware family often spreads via email attachments sent to victims enticing them to open the file in order to initiate the infection. The researchers' analysis begins with the JavaScript loader employed by the threat actors. Inside the script is a hex-obfuscated payload that is dropped into the user's %TEMP% folder and subsequently executed. The payload is packed using a .NET packers and employs anti-debugging checks before performing its primary malicious activities. If anti-debugging checks pass, a configuration file is decrypted for use by the malware. Persistence is then established via a JavaScript file in the Startup folder that simply launches the ransomware executable. Plaintext SMTP is used in order to send the decryption key to be used to the attacker's C2 server. This means that if an organization is capturing the contents of outbound emails, the decryption key could be obtained and used without paying the ransom. Finally, Triple DES encryption is performed and a ransom note requesting the victim email the attacker's to pay the ransomware is dropped on the system.

instruction: Describe the following: New Spyware Blackmails iOS and Android Users
output: A new spyware app, dubbed Goontact, running on iOS and Android and targeting Chinese, Korean, and Japanese users is the subject of a new Lookout report. Based on the types of sites used to distribute the app, Lookout suggests that the end goal of the app is either extortion or blackmail. Information gathered includes device identifiers, phone number, contacts, SMS messages, photos, and location information. To hide its real purpose, the app often disguises itself as a secure messaging application. The victim, when visiting illicit sites, such as escort services, is led to believe the app is necessary to communicate with individuals on the site. Once installed and gathered data is exfiltrated back to the criminals, the victim is contacted in an attempt to extort money for not releasing potentially damaging information.

instruction: Explain: Dark Caracal: Undisclosed IoCs Can Pose Risks
output:
Sure. Here is an overview for Dark Caracal: Undisclosed IoCs Can Pose Risks:

Researchers at WhoisXML API, decided to analyze an old threat group dubbed Dark Caracal, to gain a better understanding of the risk their IoCs pose, after a recent report. According to researchers, Dark Caracal is a threat group operated by an unknown group of hackers, since 2012; suspected to be state-sponsored and linked to the Lebanese government. According to researchers, Dark Caracal utilizes various malicious tools such as Bandook, CrossRAT, FinSpy, and Pallas. What researchers found interesting was one of the tools, utilized by Dark Caracal, dubbed FinSpy, resurfaced in a recent report by Amnesty International. Researchers then began collecting a list of publicly available Dark Caracal-related IoCs via Lookout from which they were able to retrieve 6 email addresses, 13 IP addresses, and 36 domain names. Researchers then began utilizing Reverse WHOIS searches and DNS lookups to help identify other possible IoCs that weren’t included in Lookout's available list. Successful in their efforts and using the 36 domain names collected from the Lookout report; researchers were able to collect 12 IP addresses, 11 domain names, and 4 additional domain names not openly disclosed as Dark Caracal previously.
